comment: Shareece, a recent graduate, writes: "I love this school ... the teachers are wonderful, the principal (Mr.Ciani) is so kind. I've learned so much through my years at PS 34 ... I thank all my teachers, my principal, and other staff members for encouraging me and motivating me to excel in life."

"As a former PTA President 1999-2002, we had decent after school programs (project read/math), parent participation (dance-step programs) parent/teacher participation," writes a parent. "Ongoing meetings with my former principal solved 75-98.9% of all problems. The 1.89% had been settled on district level, then submit to principal. We didn't need parent coordinators in every school, but had an excellent district parent coordinator."

Principal Mark Dempsey was one of the lowest-rated principals on the 2010-11 School Survey. Among teachers, 79.5 percent reported that they believe the principal is a weak manager and they don't trust the principal.

I ATTENDED THIS SCOOL BACK IN THE LATE 80'S & I HAD GREAT TIMES THERE. I ACTUALLY MADE A PAGE ON FACEBOOK SO THAT I CAN FIND MY FRIENDS & PEOPLE HAD A PLACE TO FIND EACH OTHER, REMINISCE & HAVE CONVERSATIONS WITH FRIENDS & TEACHERS. CHECK IT OUT @

i loved this school especially mr licata
"My daughter loves everything," says a kindergarten mother. "She mostly likes computer: the games and the learning."

"My daughter likes reading. She's doing very well," a kindergarten parent says. "She gets a good amount of homework. The school has changed (my daughter graduated from here five years ago). The teachers have changed. The new principal is better."

"It's a nice, small, and cozy school," says a teacher. "The [student] population has changed. Kids have gotten lower on the academic scale in the last few years. We're lucky to have good, hard-working teachers."

Ps 36 is a great school. The main problem here is not the teachers or the staff many of the school issues is the parenting. Many times the parents are not involved in their children's education. Like many schools ps 36 has a meet the teachers night, parent teacher conferences, or school enrichment meeting, ask me how many parents show? However, this doesn't mean the parents don't care  about their child's education, but when your child is always on the promotion and doubt list every year from first grade to fifth grade, who do you blame.It's really sad  that the teachers have to deal with the disrespect of the parents everyday. I would be exhausted. Anyway, my daughters had great teachers like Mrs. Tinglin, Mrs Rose, Mrs A, Mrs Connon and Mrs Way and the principal  Mrs Lynn S, really cares about her children and the school.
I LOVE PS 36  #1 SCHOOL IN QUEENS. MR. PRICE

My children went to this school and so did I. PS 36 was a good schools then and I hope is a better school today. "Even if you're in the 5th grade, teachers your child had still talk to you," said a 4th grade mother. "Every teacher who has had my son is helping. I feel very supported."

"My son likes this school very much," said a 1st grade father and kitchen worker. "He likes his teacher and has opened up to his classmates. He's himself here. I have an opportunity to be in this school and see what is going on. There are a lot of extra-curricular activities, lots of things he can be exposed to at a young age. I think that's important."

"My son likes the reading and writing workshop," said a 2nd grade mother and 1st grade teacher. "I wish the school had more interactive, hands-on things likes trips. They [the students] need more links to the community and outside world."

"I've been here for five years and seen so many improvements," said a teacher's assistant and 3rd grade mother. "Ms. [Principal Cynthia] Hunter has done so much. She's expanded the after-school programs. My son loves it here. It's a warm, family environment, and he feels at home."
"She's a wonderful, wonderful principal and has really pulled this school up," said a special education teacher.

"She [Principal Cynthia Hunter] is phenomenal," said a 2nd grade teacher. "She greets the children each morning. They love her. She has given Thanksgiving and Christmas dinners for teachers and makes sure that we get whatever we need. She could come into any school and turn it around."

"With my students, there is not sufficient support at home," said a teacher. "I have kids who have been bringing the same book home since October. They don't read at home. And if I'm not sitting with them here, they're not reading. We have to teach a lot of other skills: how to sit, not to hit [other children]."
"We get a lot of ELA [English Language Arts] support," said a 4th grade teacher. "It's so hard to get everything done. There are too many standards and not enough time to meet them."

I am thinking about sending my granddaughter to this school, but she is very ahead on reading and writing for her age. Is this a good school for her to get her first start? We as a family work very hard with her and she is very smart. She has a good support system and we all work together to maintain a healthy life for her. We as parents, educators,grandparents, should give our  all to make sure these children get the best education. The white community put everything in their childrens education and we have to do better.
"We need more time to integrate other subjects like social studies and science," said a 4th grade teacher."

"This new [reading and writing] program assumes that children have already had some learning," said one instructor. "It's like pulling teeth getting some things done. Students don't have 'print-rich' [literate] environments at home. Language support there is not sufficient."
"It is the best school I could ever go to," writes Mary A., a student. "The staff is polite and caring. If you were to go you would never want to leave."
Dads from PS 37 Cynthia Jenkins School are featured in an article on the U.S. Department of Education's blog Homeroom. You can read the blog here.
I remember when I was in this school I was a brilliant student
i like this school it fun i love every teachers in this school they sweet

Yvette Hinds-Joseph earned a "Lifetime Achievement Award" from the West Side Spirit as part of that newspaper's 2008 Blackboard Awards. Hinds-Joseph is a 22-year-teaching veteran of the 4th and 5th grade who stresses her strong expectations of students from Day One.

"Children know when you have their interests at heart," she said.

Parent Michelle writes that she is excited about the school's new administration and praises the chorus program. However, the school needs more parent involvement, she writes: "If there were more parent involvement and community donations to this school then there would be more extracurricular activities for the students."

"This school is a great elementary school, with great teachers, food, and the principal," writes Maha, a former student. "I used to have trouble in reading and writing but P.S.37 has made it possible."
"The music instructor is a musician of all musicians," a parent said.
"We need more supplies at this school," said a teacher. "There aren't any science labs. Kids can't really do experiments. They can only read about them."
Maha, a former student, writes: "I miss the school so much! I wish I was there right now."
The Wall Street Journal writes that math teachers at PS 38 Rosedale report better learning and higher levels of engagement in students with a curriculum developed by nonprofit Eureka Math.
miss ruland was very rued and mean.
Principal Lenon Murray has been named community superintendent of District 29, beginning in July.
"My son loves it here," said a 5th grade parent. "He enjoys doing homework and he loves math. He gets 90s and 100s. I wish they had art classes. That would be beneficial."

"Her teacher is responsive to the class," said a 2nd grade mother. "She's energetic and praises them. My daughter gets an appropriate amount of homework -- reading, math. If she doesn't understand something, she just tells the teacher."

"Every day, he uses words like 'brilliant,' 'spectacular' and 'awesome,'" said a 2nd grade mother. "My husband asks, 'Where does he get these words?' He gets them at school. The school could use more teachers, money, space, and after-school programs, if the government would just hold its hand out.

"We're a small school," said a 3rd grade father and PTA president. "I like the family-type orientation here. Most parents are familiar with each other. They're here every morning and you get to know them. My brother-in-law, my wife's family, and my kids went here. It's my daughter's home away from home. She's into reading and poetry. And she gets her share of homework. The administration is working well, but we need more space. We need a bigger building."

"My daughter has been here since kindergarten," said a 3rd grade mother. "She loves it. It was hard when she started reading and math, but now she reads all the time. They have journals that she loves to write in. It's a different way of reading. She reads a story and responds in an essay. That's how she became more interested. We need more space, more room."

"At first, he didn't like the new curriculum," said a 1st grade mother. "It's more advanced than when my [high school sophomore] daughter went here. Now he's better at reading and writing. They need programs. Right now, parents pay for outside organizations to pick them up."

"She gets a lot of homework," said a 4th grade father. "She usually finishes it by 7:00 or 7:30 p.m. at the latest. She feels challenged, but not overwhelmed. When she doesn't understand, she gets help."
"I like that we're smaller than most schools," said a teacher. "The DOE says it's saving all of this money. Where is it? I get $200."
"You make do with what you have," said a teacher. "Recently, there was a two week period when we had extra kids every day. It's a close-knit faculty. The older teachers just adopted us."
My teacher is mrs jeudy I don't think see like me it's ok I don care
i dont like her ethier

I recently graduated from this school in June 2011. I did really well, but was forced to attend a bad zoned school, 356, that had nothing positive. Ms. Colomussi, Ms. Sanchi, Ms. Caldon, and Ms. Ruland. I loved it there. There was so much to do, along with the challenging yet not overwhelming curriculum.

About the cafeteria: "They let them go crazy down there," said a teacher. "In upper schools, they put in security guards. We can't suspend anymore. More needs to be done. After lunch, we have to calm them down. Suspended kids go to other schools."
"Teachers share what they have," said a teacher. "We're very supportive of each other."

"It's nice and small, a nice community," said a teacher. "I know kids in other grades, and they know me. We would love to have a library. They need the experience of checking out books. And I would like all of the kids to be in the same building. I like the portables. The heat is good, and there is air conditioning in the summer. Mr. Murray has done his best to get us supplies."
A school aide was arrested for inappropriately touching students. Read more: Queens school aide pervert rap.

A grand jury declined to indict the school aide who was arrested for inappropriately touching students but the Education Department is still reviewing the case and he remains suspended without pay. Read more: Queens Teacher Cleared by Grand Jury of Abuse Allegations.

Recent graduate Megan shares some of the interesting assignments she had at the school: "We dressed up as important characters and held a talk show, set up the room to look like a rainforest, and made a quilt in honor of the anniversary of Sept. 11," she writes. "I definitely learned a lot at PS 52."
"The staff is wonderful," says Principal Linda Pough. "They are very cooperative. They're happy about the improvements."

"Things are now moving for the better," a longtime teacher says. "There's a lot of innovation -- you can see it in the children. It seems like there's a future." She adds that teachers "talk to one another more. We didn't talk as much before. Now there's more collaboration on a grade."
The New York Post reports that an eighth grade teacher at IS 59 was caught stealing over $8,200 worth of supplies on the first day of school.
Is SSA Jacqueline Wright still there? When I attended that school in 2006 and graduated June 2007, she was a security guard. She was one of the best.

when I attended this school in 2001, I was invited.  you had to have high honor class scores (hence the name gifted and talented ). but the onslaught of new children from other schools in the area...you can see why it's on a slippery hill. not only do they take in children with awful attitudes and lack of talent (educational or otherwise ) but the budget cuts mean that children don't even get the chance to turn around. they don't get the much needed attention,  and the parents need to rally around these children instead of just accepting the today's standard ad normal because the truth is that ten years ago their child wouldn't even be able to attend that school without any proof of true interest in learning, skill building and other academic achievement.
i.s.59 are also very talented and has a very cool progam for kids for very high science state test scores. at least they have that

I was shocked to hear that 59 is on the list of schools being watched for closure. This was once one of the best in Queens. What's going on?

I watched this school flourish as it was run by Dr. K'Tori.  He put this school on the map.  Then after he left so did his hard work.  The leadership never remained the same and the respect in the building declined greatly.  I loved participating in school events, but that slowly went away along with the school spirit of 59.  New leadership needs to be in order here, these kids don't even know what school pride is, especially since they are not being taught to enjoy school and respect it, they seem to only be instructed to respect it.   No child learns by instruction alone, they need example.

I taught at IS 59 from 1995 to 2005 under the leadership of Dr. K'Tori. He most definitely put the school on the map. He turned a failing school into a school of excellence. Once Dr. K'Tori left, it was a revolving door of administrators non of which could follow on his footsteps.

"IS 59 is on the raise the Math & ELA scores are only part of the story. The Student productions are outstanding. There is something there for EVERY CHILD in terms of programs and enrichment opportunities. The school has 3 smaller Academies making it 3 schools in One! The commitment to the true Middle School Experience still shines trough the halls of IS59."

Principal Carleton Gordan received a 2008 Cahn Fellowship, a 15-month program at Teachers College designed to recognize outstanding principals. Cahn fellows attend workshops at Teachers College and continue serving as principal at the school.
"The school is really changing," writes student Kareen. "Now they have different academies and are very strict."

Khaliah Calloway, a 1999 graduate, writes: "I loved the school then and I still love it now. We were the first graduating class to have the code of uniformity established. At first we thought of it as a bad thing but then is became all good. I had an excellent education. Dr. K'Tori made sure that we all were doing our best and made us work hard. That hard work and discipline paid off. I was able to go to the high school of my choice and do what I love to do."

Ebony Y., a recent alum, writes that she has "a lot of good memories in [IS 59] with faculty and [her] fellow students," and that she thinks the criticisms of IS 59 are " a shame." She writes, "The students that graduated with me knows that senior year was the best year and in a way the worst because we were moving on yet leaving something we loved dear behind."

Jackie, a student, writes, "IS 59 is an okay school. When I first attended this school in the 6th grade, I adjusted very well. My teachers were very friendly." She complains that things are worse at the school than they used to be, and that some students cut class.

"When I was going to this school, it wasn't that bad," Ashley, a former student, writes. "Even though we had two different principals, they managed to keep it in check. My little sister goes there now (she's in the 8th grade) and she tells me that it's gotten so bad she can't wait until she gets out."

A parent writes that the school was once a great place "to learn and to have fun doing it." However, she writes that the school has become less in control in recent years because of student behavior and "lack of guidance" from the administration.
PS 95 has one of the largest numbers of faucets with high lead levels among all New York City public schools, the New York Times reports.
More than one third of the PS 95 Eastwood water taps tested elevated levels of lead, the New York Post reports.
The Department of Education has announced that PS 95 will have a Spanish dual language program from the start of the 2016-2017 school year.

I'm currently a student in the 8th grade and doing online learning. Most of these comments are old so i thought i should do this for the incoming 6th graders in 2020. 109 isn't that bad. The teachers in 6th grade help but after that your on your own. The teachers expect you to know stuff you might not know. I'd say at least there's 1 or 2 bad teachers for each grade. They're usually older. The 7th grade art teacher looks and acts like shes on drugs but dont take her serious, kids mess with her a lot like kicking her door and making fun of her ( I dont judge them, i was one of them :/ )  When i came into 109 i was super scared and a completely different person then i am today. 109 changed me, not just physically but mentally. I was able to take insults better and i learned to ignore those people who are miserable and take it out on you. Like every other school there's drama but please dont get involved in it. Every like month there's a real fight ( Sometimes in schools most of the time its not ) Most of the fights in school are fake fights with the boys to see whos stronger. My best advice is to mind you business, don't talk bad about anyone AT ALL!!!! (You will get jumped or beat up),  do your work on time and please for the love of god take a shower everyday wash your hair and clothes and wear deodorant ( and maybe cologne or perfume ) Reply if you want more info on other things in 109. I'm going to Queens High School of Teaching, Liberal Arts, & The Sciences. I recommend it. Good luck in 109 ( you'll need it )

Terrible school staff!!! Second week of school and they already hate their job. I called to get information regarding High School code for online, the receptionist didn't even wait until I finished asking my question, she automatically cut me off in mid question to give me an answered that was WRONG. I knew her answer was wrong. When I corrected her, her attitude got even worse and she transferred me to someone else, where I got a VM. It's a shame the teachers are doing such an amazing job with the kids and the staff is pulling the school down. Shame on Jean Nuzzi Intermediate School 109 Staff!!!
A proposal to co-locate a New Visions charter school at IS 109 has been withdrawn, The Queens Chronicle reports. The DOE Panel for Educational Policy was set to vote on the proposal.
The PTA is protesting the proposed co-location of New Visions Charter High School with IS 109, reports Queens Chronicle.
A public hearing was held to discuss the possible co-location of a New Visions Charter High School with IS 109, the Queens Chronicle reports.

Terrible school staff, they have nothing organized, they barely ever do any real work yet still complain. The only helpful people actually working in the school are the deans, guidance counselors and a handful of teachers. The young teachers are great, very helpful and teach with a positive attitude every day and keep up with the students while the older teachers have problems disciplining the students and all they care about is getting their pay checks and going home (I've over heard them shouting it at most of the students). The school needs a lot of work with the school security and the students safety in and outside of school in my opinion. Also, people need to learn to respect personal space in that school. The real problems is how the school is run and how the way it affects the students. Reminder: Every school has it's ups and downs and this school is no different though I would not recommend this school to most people only if it were their last resort. The environment in this school is not very inspiring for the students, and kids need some thing to boost them to learn not just "they need to pass" and parents need to learn that. Another downside to this school is their lacking of detecting bullying when it's right on Their faces, that's why a few years ago a student had committed suicide after being bullied at school and online (there was a leaked video of the students fighting as well)

I am a graduate of class 2014-2015. I was a student that was part of the sp (honors) program at Jean Nuzzi. I have to say the kids in my grade were really bad but since I was in the SP (honors) program I did not have to interact or be around those kids at all. The teachers that I had were very caring teachers. They always pushed me to do my best and to give my full effort in every assignment or task I did. The staff at school were also very caring, there were moment where I didn't feel comfortable speaking to a teacher about something so I would speak to either my guidance counsel or another adult at school. My advice to a person going to this school is to one try to get into the SP (honors) program and to try and stay away from all the drama and gossip. Once you stay away from the drama and gossip you will have no problems. Just stay focus on your school work and have a couple of really good friends and you should be fine.

To many of the people (most likely students) that are posting with incorrect grammar and complaints on dress code, I believe that parents and prospective students should not take your comments seriously. I graduated from I.S. 109 (Class of 2009). I also participated in the Pre-Nursing program. Being that I am now a college student, I realize I did not like the school very much while I attended it but now that I look back I see that this school has helped me very much. I had transferred from Lehman Intermediate School (in Stroudsburg, Pennsylvania). I made friends right away and excelled in my studies. The teachers helped me GREATLY, and from what I understand some of my teachers are still there. excellent job disciplining us

Attention to all readers:
I.S.109 will be under new administration. Current principal Miatheresa Pate has recieved a promotion and AP Comrie will take over.
The change will take place starting Friday, December 2

Okay, so the reviews and information about this school are EXTREMELY old. I am currently an eighth grader in the SP (Honors) program. This school is big, 5 floors, no escalators. There is tons of walking up stairs, especially to the girls gym. The boy's gym is HUGE, spacious, with a big nice locker room. The girls gym is small, kind of dirty I guess, with a crammed locker room. You will get used to it and learn to 'love' it, but it takes some time to adjust. The teachers are AWESOME, but the administration is confusing. You will most likely not be very fond of your assistant principals, but the Deans and Counselors are going to be the greatest, hard working people you'll ever meet...especially Dean Clark. As for being in the honors program, it is a BLESSING. The teachers are wonderful and the amount of work and challenges you can face are great. The environment is totally different from the rest of the school and you get so many privileges...such as going on trips and being treated specially. I actually feel super prepared for the competitive high school I plan going to. As for everyone else, its average. You just have to accept the craziness of everyone else and move on. There are RARELY fights and as long as you mind your own business, you can make great friends. We have an iMac LAB with Ms. Symmonds, who is the coolest teacher ever. After school, we have the beacon program open to everyone. It has some really good options. There is NO MORE pre nursing or pre engineering. We just have four core subjects, technology, gym, language, and enrichment courses due to budget cuts. In eighth grade, you have the opportunity to take several regents exams as honors students. I am part of the ARISTA community this year and cannot wait to graduate. These 3 years are a huge life changing experience, where you learn the academic and social aspects of life. Any questions, you can comment. (:
How do you know if the boys gym and locker room are big, and the girls locker room is cramped?

I am a girl. I change in the girls locker room about 3 times a week. As a senior, I have been in the boys locker room because we pass through it in order to enter their gym, where many school events are held.

Thanks, and my current middle school has half a gym, no locker rooms, no lockers, and classes are terrible. The children never stop talking even in gym. It is MS 356. Is this a bad school or not? Please reply.

I.S.109 is not a bad school. We are very 'family' like. You will probably like your teachers and make really good friends. As for classes, they are challenging, especially if you are in the honors program.  For SP seniors: In ELA, we are reading Of Mice and Men (10th-11th grade literature) and writing critical lens essays. We take integrated algebra and biology, both regents classes. We also take Spanish. The kids in all of the classes are well behaved, some may be more abnoxious than others. I enjoy it here.
OMG THANK YOU FOR THE DETAIL! I am in 5th grade and really scared to go here but you make it seem better.

Oh, its nothing to be afraid of. I remember that feeling, but once you get here, you realize that this school is not bad at all. It's a wonderful place if you are in SP and eager to learn. The other classes are kind of filled with distracted students. Work hard...try to get fours on both of your state wide tests this year and do extra well on your report card. This way you can be guaranteed a spot in the honors program from 6th grade. Trust me, its a great thing. The kids in those classes are really awesome and the teachers are incredible. Anymore questions, you can comment!
I also want to add that the student population is very diverse. There are more asians each year.
Quite true.

I am a parent that was recommended this school for a special education program (Intergrated Co-Teaching).  I have also heard/read that if you are not in an honors program the school may not be the best choice.  My child will not be in the honors program so I am nervous about sending him here.

Hi! I am so sorry for the late reply. Yes, I agree if your child is not in the honors program...it might not be the best place. However, they can work themselves up. For example, if you continuously receive averages above 90's (which are easier in normal classes) and maintain them, you will receive admittance into the honors program and it will feel like a whole new world! There is also 623, 723, and 823-they are less honorable classes but do accelerated work with really awesome kids. Some of my best friends are in that class and are doing exceptionally well. None of this is guaranteed but I hope I helped you make your decision!

"I spent my three years here and I grew from it," writes recent graduate Joan. "I participated in the Pre-Nursing and Advanced Science/Spanish/Math Program and it was the best ever! I was able to take the Physical Science/Earth Science Regents (the other class took Living Environment) and the Spanish Proficiency. The Math A exam was going to be anticipated but it didn't happen. I got my high school credits and I miss the school's programs and dedicated teachers. My high school is far less challenging than this school."

A student praises Principal Blake, noting that "scores on the state exams have had an enormous increase of level 3s and 4s (almost doubled since 2002). We're working to be one of the top schools in NYC."  This student complains that some students act out in classes and school materials are "a bit old" but notes that the building is being renovated and there are many "supportive teachers."

A parent writes that while she thinks that Mr. Blake "is doing a very good job as principal," she is worried that the zero tolerance code does more bad than good, especially for the male students. "It seems that anything and everything they do is a major problem and warrants a suspension (ex. having no tie on, looking at a girl, speaking their mind, etc.). Many students are suspended on mere accusations without the opportunity to tell their side of the story. Therefore many of the suspensions are not justifiable or necessary," she says.

A student says that while the principal is "the best thing that happened to the school," the halls are a problem. "It's too crowded," he writes. He also says that school materials, including the desks, "are in very poor condition" and the janitors and lunch monitors do not handle their jobs well.

In response to the comment above, Principal Shango Blake writes that with 1,550 students, "during passing the hallways can become crowded, [but] after the late bell rings the hallways are clean and quiet." In addition, while the building is old and requires a lot of work, the custodians do their best and the school has "recently received several capital improvement grants."
"I have no problem with the dress code," writes a student. "In fact, I think it preserves order."

"I believe that this school has more cons than pros and there is definitely room for a lot of improvement and yes, I know that our principal, Mr. Shango Blake is working on them," writes a senior student, who notes that the building is very old and is needs renovations. She says that after the persistent rains of the past week, "there was rain water dripping from the lockers, the 4th and 5th floors were flooded and not a lot was being done to improve the conditions of these 2 floors." She adds: "The desks are dirty, there are not enough textbooks for a whole class which usually consists of over 30 students. The school is overcrowded and when the students are dismissed from class, the hallways are crowded. The textbooks have gum in them. There are not enough classrooms for the teachers. None of the social studies teachers have classrooms. The principal is focusing on the new school music c.d./video too much." However, she notes the positive aspects of the school: a pre-nursing program and "very good teachers."

In response to the above comment, Principal Shango Blake writes: "The School is an old building. The school construction authority is in the process making necessary renovations. We have a professional custodial staff that is diligent about keeping the building clean. We have a very rigorous academic program and intensive professional development for teachers that is on going and focused on improving student achievement. If you look at our school report card we have made impressive gains in both reading and math. In fact our math scores have gone up by 8% in a climate where the citywide average for math dropped by 1.9% on math state assessment.

The DVD project is just one of many enriching programs we have for the student at IS 109. There is a whole instructional focus around the video that is rooted in raising student achievement. The hallways are always clear after student passing. School Safety records indicate that cutting has dropped in our school significantly. We are overcrowded, but this is largely due to renewed community confidence. There has been an influx in student enrollment. I have been here for two years and the turn around of the school has been phenomenal. There are programs that engaged students that I put in place that were not in place prior to my appointment ie. Pre -nursing Pre -engineering, drama, dance, Student run film studio ( connected to the DVD) Americas Choice school reform design, after school programs like Tennis, Girls Basketball, Boys Basketball, etc. However, the biggest room for any building is the room for improvement. We will take the students comment in stride."
An 8th-grader, complains that the school is too strict, and that punishments are too harsh "for people rolling their eyes and ... really ludicrous things like that."

Yashoda, a student, complains about the school's dress code, and describes it as "very dirty and it is very hard to work in. The desks have writing on them, chewed gum in them and have garbage and food left in them. The textbooks are very disgusting. Gum, and unknown foods are stuck to it, and some pages are ripped out, or have many bad words written in them." This student adds: "However, this school does have many good things to it. They are working on the next trip to the bowling alley, after our last trip, a skating trip. We are having fun, our principal, Mr. Blake, is making a music video about the dress code. This started after the CD! But I still think we need more and better solutions to [the problems in] our school."
A parent writes: "Mr. Blake the principal of I.S. 109 has done a wonderful job revamping the school and applying the uniform policy (it is a very safe and progressive environment)."

Parents, DO NOT SEND YOUR CHILD HERE. The school is HIGHLY dysfunctional, students with behavioral problems are coddled and consequences are rarely given (and if they are it’s a mere slap on the wrist). Check the school’s stays with the NYC DOE and you’ll see suspensions are very low, this is why. Your child deserves much better, they will NOT learn here.

PS/IS 116 William C. Hughley is among 40 middle schools selected for an extended learning day pilot with 2.5 more learning hours in the school day for all students, and daily literacy tutoring for high needs students. Sponsored by the New York City Council, Robin Hood, The After School Corporation, and Harvard Ed Labs, the Middle School Quality Initiative aims to help at risk students stay on track with their academic goals, as well as accelerate students' progress towards reaching the Common Core literacy standards. With this expansion, MSQI will be in 89 schools in the city. Read the press release here.

When was the last time this review was updated? Firstly I am a parent with a son who attends this school right now, and little of this report is accurate. I am desperately trying to get him out of this placement. The neighborhood is unsafe. The "children learn to speak Chinese" has NOT taken place in YEARS (not since the former principal left. Said principal is also now retiring (from ANOTHER school), so that SHOWS you how long ago such a program took place). There is no longer a "strong" reading program as BOTH "Reading Specialist" were placed in the classroom as homeroom teachers by the new principal. My son has one such "reading specializing" teacher now in 1st grade--I am not impressed. 

In addition to the woman having zero control within her class, zero parent-teacher communicative abilities and zero classroom handling aptitude; she also has little patience with the students. My son if anything has become a WORSE reader from what I have seen (meaning the woman has undone even the general basic skills I and his Kindergarten teacher instilled). Furthermore, her class is so noisy that my son complains of it (this from a child who can watch SPONGEBOB and the TRANSFORMERS cracked up to near deafening levels no problem). According to he and other students his teacher "screams all the time" and "no ever is quiet" in the classroom.Honestly, I would have to say the "bullying" is probably the biggest problem at the school. The Principal is not addressing it AT ALL--as a matter of fact even letters to her office go UNATTENDED to! My son has come home numerous time with "accidents" that I was neither contacted about or had my questions answered about. Also, there is some kind of weird picking order as well. . . Parents who are known trouble makers are the ones whose badly behaved children are allowed to run rampant over the quieter more well-behaved students. I really DO NOT recommend this school! If you are zoned for it FIND A WAY OUT! Move if you have too!

I started at PS 134 in the sixth grade in 1960. Back then, it was an 8B school but in 1962, the 7th and 8th grades at PS 134 and several other schools in the area were re-organized as JHS 192, Linden Junior High School. However, the new school's building was still under construction when we graduated in 1963, so we were still 
housed at our old school buildings. One of the others was PS 118.

It's been a very long time since I was in my old neighborhood. We moved away in 1965 when my father, who worked at the old Brooklyn Navy Yard, was transferred to Long Beach California. I expect to be in New York for a few days in December. I'll try to find time to come have a quick look at my old school.

"I went to this school when it was K through 8. I made my own graduation dress at the school and learned to type here," said Principal C. Marmon-Halm. "It gives the children hope to see that I attended this school and now I'm its principal."

A parent complains: "The students have limited space outside because there is no playground, because there is a small outside school that takes over the playground." Highly recommend it!!!

According to the city Department of Education Quality Review Report, "The school is at the stage where it has only recently begun to make use of the Comprehensive Education Plan as tool to influence school development. While the principal is now aware that this is vitally important, she has not made sure that other members of the staff understand its relevance.

It's sad to say, but to put an influential child in this school, is throwing them into the belly of the beast. The teachers have absolutely no control over the behavioral incidents presented to them and appear extremely overwhelmed with the children. Although there may be great kids in that school, the children with disciplinary issues appear to take precedence.  A parent can be called 3 or more times a day, which is ridiculous because at what point is a firm hand or curriculum established between the faculty and the child. I have become quite familiar with the school and its staff and feel a great empathy for them.  Parents need to be held more responsible for the behavior problems or special classes may need to be designed in order for these children to realize that certain behaviors will not be tolerated. All one has to do to assess the actions of activities in this school is take a sneak peek in the cafeteria during lunch time (I have never seen anything like it).  They can also stand outside on the street at dismissal time and boy will they get an eye and earful. Although kids are going to be kids, I would love to turn my back and know that my children are in the hands of professionals that are not afraid of doing their job without biases. We cannot be their friends, because at the end of the day children fall short on deciphering between discipline / learning and "friendship" from an individual in the authoritative position.

PS 147 is on a list of schools that the DOE may close. The schools were on the state's persistently lowest achieving list last spring and have low tests scores, with fewer than 30% of the students reading at grade level. Additionally all but one received a "D" or an "F" on the city progress reports. After last year's union lawsuit prevented the city from closing 19 schools, a judge ruled that the city needs to communicate better with the schools' communities. This year officials are also considering closing the 19 schools identified last year. Education officials will also consider alternatives to closing the schools, including removing the principals and changing staff. Check this link in the Daily News.

P.S. 147 in Queens is on a list of 12 schools that the DOE may close. The schools were on the state's persistently lowest achieving list last spring and have low tests scores, with fewer than 30% of the students reading at grade level. Insideschools, this Cambria Heights, Queens school is NOT the one under discussion in the DNAinfo article.
Thank you for your comment @mommathree:disqus. We have removed the above newslink due to confusion regarding the listing of PS/IS 176 in the article.

Chancellor Dennis Walcott attended a groundbreaking ceremony for an addition to the PS 176 building. The addition will allow for an increase in enrollment by 370 students when it is completed in 2016. Read more: Schools Chancellor Walcott and Local Officials Break Ground at a New Addition to PS 176 in Queens.

Principal Arlene Bartlett received a 2008 Cahn Fellowship, a 15-month program at Teachers College designed to recognize outstanding principals. Cahn fellows attend workshops at Teachers College and continue serving as principal at the school.

"I am very satisfied that my husband and I made the right choice by sending our daughter to PS 176, which is her zoned school, although I was hesitant at first because I prefer private schools," writes a parent. "My daughter is now in the third grade Stellar program and she is doing excellent both academically and socially. I am absolutely impressed with the pricipal, Arlene Bartlett, and her strong dedication and commitment to PS 176. She takes great pride in her work and is always patrolling after school is dismissed. I am very pleased with PS 176 and its high expectations. This is a very friendly and family-oriented school in the neighborhood. My only concern is there is not enough space in the Beacon after school program for working parents like myself."

A parent expressed concern that there is only one crossing guard outside the school, but said that "the principal is out here every day. That's the biggest thing you don't see in other schools," said a parent. "Ms. Bartlett is the crossing guard."

"I'm very happy. I'm glad I made the move," said a mother who transferred her daughter into the school from Catholic school. "This was the best move I could've made. The program is better; the teachers are better qualified."
"This school is very warm and friendly," said a mother.
"The kids do a lot of things here; they do a lot of plays and performances," said the mother of a 4th grader. "They're very concerned about the kids and they try to make sure the parents are active."
"Parents are here every day," Principal Arlene Bartlett said. "We have a lot of grandparents as well."
"You see all the kids' work, you see the warmth of the teachers and the way they talk to the kids," said a substitute teacher. "The school radiates warmth."
"I went to the school. I love it," said a mom. "I appreciate the fact that people who work here grew up in the neighborhood and still live here. Everybody knows everybody."
The principal is "a real role model," a parent said. "Ms. Bartlett comes to school prepared every day and she runs it like a school, not a circus."
A retired teacher who comes back to teach part time at the school said "things have improved in a lot of ways because [the curriculum] is more hands-on. It's a lot more work for teachers."

This school is by far the best in the neighborhood! My children have benefited immensely from the support of the teachers and staff. Principal Wheeler, Vice Principal Brown and Parent Coordinator Ms Brown are just a few of the names that stand out from the excellent team that PS181 has. Anyone in doubt must make a trip down to the school to understand that this school is your best choice if you live in this community! Bravo PS 181!! Keep up the good work!!

Although PS 181 was on the struggling schools list. This is a geat school.  The principal, Mrs. Belcher is very committed to the success of the students and the school. This school is working very hard to make progress under the leadership of Mrs. Belcher.  She is a worker and does not even have an assistant principal.  That is a shame when the school was supposed to get help, the board took away even more funds to prevent that. The teachers care more now and it shows.  If the top students are not pulled for charter schools, lottery or gifted and talented then the school won't be struggling.  The parents are supporting our principal, teachers, school and of course our children.  PS 181 is working hard to bounce back and meet the new standards.  I am keeping my kids there because there is more to progress than just a test score.  My kids are learning, safe and love school!

The DOE has begun discussions with 20 NYC schools, including PS 181, that are at risk of closing for extremely low test scores. Read more: DOE Begins To Consider Closing 20 More Public Schools.

Aside from the fact that this review is terribly outdated, the school has had a new principal for the past four years.  Due to ongoing budget cuts the school has lost its' visual arts program as well as a music program.  The so called field where the "snowy egrets" nest across from the school is in reality a swamp that has been used for toxic dumping for years.  Despite numerous calls to NYC 311 about the daily accumulation of trash and overgrown grass, the field has become a health hazard for the children, parents and staff of the school.  If such a condition existed near a school in Douglaston, Kew Gardens or Bayside I am sure the community leaders would receive greater cooperation from the city to rectify the situation.
Student Kai writes that the school offers lots of fun activities for students, such as a mother-daughter tea, a father-son breakfast, "Pajama Rama" and a spirit day.

"My daughter loves gym and computer," said a kindergarten mother. "There is one issue that I haven't brought up. I'd like them to have a sheet of contact information for other class parents, to discuss issues."
"I'd like to see more reading and after-school resources [academic support]," said a parent.
"My daughter didn't like that that music teacher quit," said a 2nd grade mother, who added that "music was fun." She said the school "needs more money for athletics, art, and music."
"It's a friendly school and not too big," said a teacher. "So you get to know everybody. Children don't feel overwhelmed."

"I like that it's a smaller building," said a teacher. "With less children, it's easier to get to know them, even if they're not in your class. I would like to see more technology in my room, maybe a large-screen TV."
"The staff is good," said a teacher. Most teachers at other schools are like squirrels: They take and don't share. But not here."
Jasmine, a student, writes: "I think that PS 181Q has improved since Ms. Auguste became the principal."

I went to 192 in Sept. 2008 and graduated in June 2011. I was in S.M.A.R.T. academy and graduated on time passing both my math and English test. I also was chosen among few students to take the Living Environment  Regents which I also passed. Honestly the teachers and staff members try to enforce discipline and respect but it really is the kids who don't care enough to listen. 6th grade year it was fine uniform students weren't as disrespectful. My 7th grade year it started getting stricter consistent hall sweeps, camera's, enforcing dress code etc. 8th grade year the incoming 6th graders were out of control. Cursing out teachers , running the halls . Inappropriate behavior in the stairwell. Always fighting with each other and other schools. Students thinking they were grown and got into physical altercations with Teachers hurting the teachers or injuring themselves. 

There was no parent support. Fashion shows, plays, talent shows students mostly filled the seats. I attended P.T.A. meetings with my mother and there have been times were only a total of 8 to maybe 10 parents showed up. ( no i'm not over exaggerating maybe it improved but I'm unaware if it did.) Not every teacher was perfect some staff members had on again off again attitudes like Ms. Swindell who worked in the main office etc. when I was there. I enjoyed the time I had there and don't regret any of it. No I was not a perfect student like some of these parents a claiming their kids are. I had my flaws etc. But at the end I kept a positive attitude and graduated. I miss the teen center, St. John's after-school and the assistant principal Ms. Smith. You were hard on me but in the end it was all worth it Thank You. And thank you 192. Through the up's and downs you still help me become the strong young woman I am today.

I went to 192 and graduated in 1998. In 2008 I graduated from NYU. The school can't be that bad. "I attended I.S. 192 when it was called the Linden Middle School in 1998-1999 when I was in the 6th grade and when the name was changed to the Renaissance Middle School in 2000-2001 when I was in the 8th grade. While I was there I was always in honors classes. There was always nonsense going on in that school no matter what class you were in. The only difference between my class and other students were that we had better grades and cared more about our studies. There were kids in my class with behavior problems like other students. Some teachers did not care what the students did while other teachers showed great concern. I think the main problem is that kids have no discipline at home so they go to school and act the fool. My parents never tolerated disrespect so I knew better than to go to school and misbehave. It is not up to the school to discipline these children, that is their parents responsibility. That is why the school is in ruins, they need to be taught at home first."

Recent graduate Jean Paul acknowledges the school has "major student behavioral problems and low test scores" but writes that the school should be considered "good. ... Most of the teachers that I know are nice. My homeroom teacher has always cared for my class, and she is very nice and very funny. When we are in trouble she also tries to help us to the best of her abilities. And other people in this school. Like the nurse, my science and English teachers, some of the cafeteria staff, one or two of the principals, and some of the janitors have always shown sincere caring for the students that has always benefited me and many of my friends."
IS 192 has been removed by the New York State Education Department from its list of Schools Under Registration Review because its performance on state math and English exams has improved.

Kristin, a 2005 graduate, writes that IS 192 "prepared me enough for high school that I can graduate in three years instead of four." She also writes that the results of the citywide exams are not as important as the fact that many IS 192 students pass the Math A Regents exam while in middle school.
"The behavior has improved slightly," says one teacher. "It's not that bad."

"This is a very good school," writes a student. "People think it was bad but it was excellent! This school has many opportunities! I took the math regents I passed it! This school was a great experience!
A 2004 graduate writes, "The school offers very prestigious honor classes such as taking Regents even though we are in middle school."

NY1 reports that PS 195 will hold a special assembly for 5th-grader Kameron Slade to deliver his classroom competition-winning speech about same sex marriage. Kameron was originally barred from making the speech at a school competition by the principal, who felt the subject matter inappropriate.

The Daily News reports that PS 195 parents rallied against the Education Department for not replacing light fixtures in the school that are known to contain PCBs, a harmful substance linked to cancer. Parents say the DOE is aware of the problem but moving to slowly to rectify it.
i am a student here and we do not have to wear yellow and green,its yellow and navy blue now and we do not have sixth grade anymore(sorry).
I was also a student there and I was in janera's class . we did not even have to wear uniform.
"This school is great," writes Ariel, who has been at the school since kindergarten. "The teachers are fun, and they prepare us for tests."

"P.S. 195 is very family oriented," Carol Randall, a parent. "Although there could be an increase in parent participation, on the whole the PTA was very active, holding fundraisers and sponsoring activities for the children and their families. Dedicated parents are at the school every day or every week. Teachers are generally very dedicated and responsive to the parents. Any parent who makes their needs known get quick response from staff and administrators. I'm only sorry that the school did not continue to the 8th grade. The 3 years my son attended (4-6) were happy ones for us. And, most importantly, his test scores improved greatly to a solid 3 in both math and English."
"I look forward to getting up in the morning and coming here," an aide in a special education class said. "The principal is wonderful; the kids are great."

"This is a very parent-friendly environment," said the PTA president. He noted that the PTA keeps regular hours, Monday, Wednesday, and Friday from 9 to 11 a.m., but PTA officers spent most of the day at the school.

A parent writes: "My children started attending this school in September 2003 (grades 3, 4 and 6). During [the] year my children had teachers who were willing to go the extra mile for my children and who were willing to call me if anything (good or bad) came up. They always answered my notes and /or telephone calls. My husband and I appreciated that." However, she does complain that the PTA Executive Board was unproductive and sometimes broke the rules. She writes: "We all hope that with the new Executive Board will also come POSITIVE and PRODUCTIVE change!" Also, she is concerned that the parent coordinator and dean of students seem to have more control over students' behavior than the principal does. She concludes, "As a parent of three attending P.S. 195, I must say that overall my experience with this school has been great. The entire staff is doing a good job!!!"
"PS 195, Region 3, District 29, will have a pre-kindergarten program in September," writes a parent. "Registration began in mid April."
PS/IS 208 has one of the largest numbers of faucets with high lead levels among all New York City public schools, the New York Times reports.
Actually PS/IS 208 is in District 26, not District 29.
Yes, PS/IS 208 is physically located in District 26, but it serves District 29 students.
Ahh, yes, thank you. I was always wondering what made PS/IS 208 and PS/IS 266 different. Thank you!

Overall this is a wonderful school but this year we have encountered an unusual situation. It is my understanding that the graduating fifth graders are to move over to the middle school, yet they do not have a graduation with a special ceremony. It is also very exciting to see all of the awards that the children receive yet with the awards based on scoring the children who because of needing help have their averages lowered will not receive an award. How would this particular child feel included in the ceremony? Would this child even attend? Or rather, would they already dealing with learning difficulties feel that they are not as good as the rest of the class? If there were only a few awards per class given I could understand but to go from receiving awards every year since first grade to now as a graduating fifth grader receiving none bruises our childrens self esteem. Understanding their needs for extra help should also continue past the end of the school year. What harm is there in celebrating all of the achievements our children have attained? Despite the difficulty school presents to those children that need extra help in class they have succeeded! They are moving on! They deserve to be celebrated and in moving up from fifth grade they will know that hard work pays off.

This school is EXCELLENT! I have had to relearn all kinds of skills in order to assist my son in his academic pursuit, but IT IS WORTH IT!

I have one daughter going to 3rd grade, and another going to kindergarten in September.  I am very satisfied with this school.  It is very spacious and clean.  The academics are very rigorous.  Parents of incoming kindergarteners get ready to become a student again.  The PTA is awesome.  The All Pro Dads are a positive, much needed male influence in the school.  The administration and staff for the most part are courteous and helpful. Parents have to do their part by being involved in their children's academic career, and PS/IS 208 is not the school for a LAZY parent.  The kindergarten program will be very effective in weeding out these type of parents.  PS/IS 208 is a jewel among the schools in District 29.

I.S. 238 Susan B Anthony is among 40 middle schools selected for an extension of the Middle School Quality Initiative, a program that increases professional development with Common Core-aligned literacy strategies and gives targeted funding for literacy training and materials. Sponsored by the New York City Council, Robin Hood, The After School Corporation, and Harvard Ed Labs, the Middle School Quality Initiative aims to help at risk students stay on track with their academic goals, as well as accelerate students' progress towards reaching the Common Core literacy standards. With this expansion, MSQI will be in 89 schools in the city. Read the press release here.

I am now an 8th grader in this school, I've been here since the 6th grade back in 2010. This school is amazing!-- only if you work hard. You only see the amazing part of this school if you truly want to. This school is not at all horrible in anyway, just sort of, what can I say... lacking. Lacking in teacher discipline (most of them need to engage with the students) and in student behavior. I sometimes wonder why students come to school just to fool around, play boyfriend-girlfriend, and don't give a care about their grades and rowdy behavior. I guess it is by law, but there should be better guidance-counslers who can relate to these students instead of suspension here, suspension there. Who am I to complain, I have no idea how hard it is to discipline, I am only an 8th grader. Ever since Mr. Gates left, I had at first felt disappointed, I was looking forward to taking graduation photos with him. He was cool and everyone felt like we were all a big family with him. Due to budget cuts, the promised programs for the 1st floor were cut. I was part of the magazine club and it was hard to move from an absolutely amazing magazine club where we produced our own magazines via an online editor and publishing company. We were moved to "Creative Writing," not exactly horrible but a drastic change from our old elective. Now with Mr. Leddy, he's a great principal so far, don't get me wrong, But I sometimes wonder if all this reaching-out to students is working. He always asks questions during the morning about fun-facts of what happened this very day in history. We are currently in a presidential election right now and I am happy that he has decided to make a student council. To sum it all up, this school is 5 stars for me, maybe it's because I'm biased since I've been here for a full 3 years now but it's just my opinion. I've met countless teachers who have done their job well here. I've learned so many things, gained strength in many of my weak subjects, and have improved my self as a student. Now that I'll be graduating in June 2013, leaving this school will be a bit saddening, but hopefully the new batch of students will keep this place running well and keeping it's high reputation as a public middle school up there.

A parent writes: "I think the school is very good." However, he complains that staff sometimes punish children "before they know all the facts."
That is very True !

A teacher writes, "The Susan B. Anthony School is stronger than ever. Mr. Gates has done a fantastic job in creating a structured and nurturing academic environment. The students often go on trips to other states (Pennsylvania, Washington, and Massachusetts). We have also begun a tradition of sending students to specialized high schools. This year we have students going to Stuyvesant, Bronx Science, Brooklyn Tech, York College, and LaGuardia. We are also building two new computer labs and a state-of-the-art science lab."

A parent said: "Since Mr. Gates came in, the school has changed a lot. There's a lot of discipline, and there wasn't before. There's more control now. It used to be rowdy."

"The school is good, but I still see room for improvement," a parent said. "When one child does something wrong, they have the whole class stay after school for detention. Once someone in my son's class got in trouble in the winter, and all the parents who came to pick up their children had to wait outside in the cold. I think they should punish only the child who caused the trouble."

"The teachers give so much to the children. It's a very, very good school," said a parent, who noted that the school was helping her son adjust to a new culture following his recent immigration from Guyana. "But the classes are too big," she added.

Well i my son is going to that school and I think it will a wonderful place for him especially with the security guards and

So far I'm really impressed by the academics, arts, and extra activities offered by this school. My daughter is in Kindergarten and she's so excited about learning and grasping new things. There's a garden, playground, music room complete with keyboards for each child, science and technology as well as an intense arts program at PS 251. Principal Loncke is quite devoted and also readily available to speak or address any concerns I may have... PS 251 is a true gem!

"I was just informed that my 3rd grader's class is now holding 31 students!" writes a parent. "I as well as the other parents are outraged at the fact that a testing grade has 31 students in a single classroom at this pass/fail, make or break level in their education." This parent also writes: "When my eldest son first started to attend kindergarten at this school, I was profoudly impressed by the focus PS 251 has on early childhood development, and the committment the school had to pulling out the talents in the children."

Principal Jacqueline Jones responds to the comment above: "At the beginning of school, there were 30/31 students in the three 3rd grade classes in our school. My school usually maintains small classes. However, this year has been different. I was able to reduce the 3rd grade registers to 24/25 by opening up another 3rd grade class while closing a first grade classs (those first classes remain small with 20-24 students). As an early childhood school, our mission continues to focus on providing the very best education for all students. Parents are powerful advocates for their children's education and during challenges such as this situation requires the entire school community (parents, teachers, administrators and students) to work together for solutions.

A parent writes that the teaching in her child's special education class has been inconsistent. "Last year my child had a teacher who barely spoke English and this year my child had four substitute teachers since January!" she writes.

"I try to make the school as open as possible," says Principal Jacqueline Jones. "The environment nurtures, but doesn't coddle. It has to foster independence, so children can think, express their thoughts, and learn to be nice to each other."

Parents are eager to be part of the life of the school, says Assistant Principal Yvonne Gartner. "Parents ask for workshops--on reading levels, on test prep--and come, when they're offered," she says.
A parent writes, "I do not feel any encouragement from the school."

Im sorry but this school has had 5 spanish teachers in the last year and only 1 was actually qualified to teach. Children are ill  prepared for the state exams. The (Clique) of staff that exist are probably the above posters.

This school needs new leadership.  It is fine that the principal Chayvonne Harper and her two assistant principals are nice, and give off the appearance of efficiency and effectiveness.  In actually, it has not been proved to come to fruition.  My children attended this school from K-8, having the experience of both the previous principal Ms. Andrews, and the changes under Ms. Harper.  We have also experienced the same under the previous assistant principals and the new.  When your staff "flees" -- leaves in exodus -- that is a sign.  When some of your staff live in the area and are familiar with the community, the kids, etc. - that is also great -- but don't send their children to this school -- that is also a sign. (Maybe they don't want to be with their children all day; but, if this was a truly "great" school, they'd have them their with no problem.)  The biggest issues with the administration is lack there of.  There is very little follow-up and follow through.  When one child was "moving up" to 6th grade, the assistant principal sent a notice home requesting that all children show up in their Sunday best.  She showed up in ripped jeans and a t-shirt.  

Let's talk academics.  In relation to many schools across NYC, you have teachers who are their to teach and lead, and others their for the paycheck, the summer off, and the knowledge they can't be fired. That is evident in the lack of challenging work presented in many of the subjects.  Many people posted about a particular math teacher -- that teach remains inadequate, inefficient and ill-equipped.  She also remains a teacher in this school.  Also in relation to many schools across NYC, you will have students who shine! They are innately curious, and thereby studious and they excel and would excel no matter their circumstance or surrounding.  For the rest of the students who require focused, broken-down, explicitly explained curriculums, that will be a challenge to locate here.  The teachers appear to be on a scheduled agenda to get in a specified amount of work in a specified amount of time.  If your child is not picking up those lessons within that time-frame, they will be left behind, because the class must move on. With regard to the mention of the music teacher as mentioned below -- my children learned the recorder for 4 years - a purchase the parent has to make.  There are very few if any other instruments.  My children never returned home with an art project. 

Let's talk physical space.  The building is approximately 10-15 years old - and yet last required a completely new roof.  The gym is built for kids no older than 6th grade, yet the space is occupied with 8th graders (experiencing growth sprouts and body development).  The space was not built with middle schoolers in mind, and has not been adapted for such.  (There was a child who had to be sawed out of a desk, lawsuit pending).  There are no lockers in the school - so children must carry every book they own, and wear their coats all day through out the weather appropriate months. Retro-fitting of lockers, at least for the 60 or so kids in middle school is physically possible, but questionable if fiscally possible. 

I used INSIDE SCHOOLS to help locate a school for my children to transfer to.  I see their work in investigating every school with credibility, especially as I've met in person the leader of the organization.  Comments shouldn't be all negative but they should share the concerns -- which is what a parent what's to know honestly if they are on this site.  So, PS270Q has a very caring PTA, has "nice" teachers and administrative staff.  But if you want a great education for your child(ren) this should not be your first choice (or second).

I remember the music teacher taught students the guitar, recorder, flute, clarinet, drums, trumpet and sax.  The school had 35 guitars so that's what he used on a daily basis though. Most of the comments below are from either paretns or teachers and are really OLD. From a graduated students perspective the school has changed alot. I had gone to P.S./I.S. 270q for 9 years, from k-8th. I was with the group of kids that filled the school for its third year opened. Now I have watched principals change, colors of the building completely change, teachers leave, teachers have heart attacks; basically, I have watched the school and staff members go through thick and thin. For any child or teenager this school is a learning experinece from kindergarten till Graduation. Some of the comments are true about the teachers being rough; but, what parent doesnt want their child to have a teacher that will push them to their limits and sky high so they can succeed. Also, yes the homework is tough and they give it to you on a daily or in Middle School weekly. What the homework will do for your child in Kindergarten - 5th grade is drill the work into them so that they are prepared for what the Middle School teachers will give them. The Middle School teachers do not teach these children second grade Math, ELA, Science, Social Studies or in any subject. All of these teachers are professionals and have so many degress with years of experince added along that it would be hard for them to teach your children second grade math. Regarding the lunch situation, wehn I was younger Mrs. Andrews always had something for us little kids to do when we wanted to "releave stress". During the Fall, Spring, and Summer time all of the kids would be outside in the playground which was desginated for specific grades. The larger yard was for 5th-8th grade and the smaller yard was for K-4th, which has been changed with the new Principal Ms. Chayvonne Harper. She has had all of the children ampile time to play and enjoy their time on the larger yard. During the Winter and on rainy days, Mrs. Andrews had the younger children read books or watch television in the cafeteria. While Middle School students had opportunites to either stay in the lunch room and talk with their friends, go to the library and read there, aska teacher for permission to stay in their room and assist or do whatever work they have to do, and even the Gym teacher takes time from her lunch to have the children compete intheir own basketball games, volleyball games, or just play a sport. Mrs. Harper has still instilled quite a few of Mrs. Andrews techniques and has added more safety to it. Since in the past children would sneak out and hang out in stair cases there have been more security added to the lunch room. This incoming fall take a look inside the cafeteria and you will see children definetley letting off steam. Regarding the curiculum your students will definetley encounter some teachers their not gonna like but who ever had the perfect group of teachers with the most wonderful attitude. Honestly speaking, the school has definetely changed since Mrs.Andrews left in a negative and poistive way. Mrs.Harper is trying to do thhe best she can with students rebelling against her and the new rules she is trying to instil and learning the ropes of how all of the childrena re acustom to learning when Mrs.Andrews was her. Mrs. Allen, the assistant principal, is doing all she can too. She has been with the school from the ground up. Starting as a technology teacher and now the assistant principal. She does really well with the new children and the kids that have been with the school for years. So right now, most of the comments bbelow this are all wrong and its either your children aren't giving you the truth or you the "students" need to take time to know the schools history like i do and understand every aspect of it; including teachers, administrators,staff members, and members of the PTA before you complain about how terrible the school is.

"Very disappointed in this school. Attention is on scoring well on mandatory tests as oppose to real learning. The most cursory of attention is paid to those subjects that are not part of the grade level annual tests. For the areas not being tested teaching can be sporadic to the point of non-existent. Since there is no teaching, there is no assessment and report cards are distributed without scores in some subjects."

"Very concerned about [a] teacher. She does her utmost to discourage the children, and she is rude to parents. She assigns work that judge the children’s artistic ability rather than their academic progress. There is work from October that has yet to be entered into the grading program..."

A parent writes to say that the school favors students whose parents are involved, and that even parents are in a click. The parent adds: "I think the school is too small to be K-8.[...] The school needs to be student friendly."

Parent Kevin Hamlet writes: "PS/IS 270 is a well rounded school that promotes positive and respectable behavior. Respect maybe missing in some communities, but it is definitely taught and practiced in this school. Teachers and staff expect the best behavior from all children as if they were their own. I am glad they care like I do about my child." He continues: "There is a time and place for playing and getting academic work done. The school offers many programs [such as] drama, debate, volleyball, and cheerleading ... something to cater to every child." He adds: "I do not fear the principal I work with the principal to secure the safety of my child."

One parent complained that although the principal is not inaccessible, she "scares parents" and the "teachers are afraid of her too."  She also said the cafeteria is "very very quiet" because "kids are not supposed to talk to each other." Because the kids have no recess, she said, there is no time or place for them to "release their energy."

not any more... now a days our cafeteria is buzzing with laughter, music chatter, etc. And we always go outside to play but that is during the summer but when its winter we either watch movies or play board games.
Not anymore they have to stay quit all day long .
"This is an excellent school. They're very hands-on," said one parent.
"This is probably one of the better schools. Teachers here are more structured," said a parent who also has a child in another school in the district.

A retired music teacher who now volunteers at the school said, "This is a piece of cake compared to the schools I've been in." She praised PS/IS 270's "size, physical set-up" and the "space for everything" including a music room and an art room. "Everyone is very professional here. The children know what they are supposed to do."

A student writes: "I am a student at PS/IS 270 for my second year, and am in the sixth grade. I'm leaving next year, because I am tired of feeling like a kindergartener. I am supposed to be in junior high, but staff and aides don't treat the sixth grade that way. We don't have lockers, and cannot even travel to our classes without the teacher."

to all the people who are saying PAW is bad...SHUT UP!!!!!!!!!!! You people don't know a great school when you see one. The new principal is awesome. When you have a problem he will take time out of his day to listen and solve the problem. He knows every student by name and can tell you what their grades are. This principal doesn't sit up in his office like a snobby executive, but actually visits classrooms and helps students with their classwork. The activities he plans are great...paintball, dodgeball, game shows, indoor carnivals are only some of the activities. We have great advisories and few but great extra curricular activities such as Rachel's challenge, PAW players(a acting group), Improv, PAW Leadership Academy, Literary Magazine, Newspaper, Fashion and Fashion Magazine, and Students Government. The uniform is strict but you are allowed to wear black or khaki jeans, any kind of green, white, or black shirt as long as it doesn't have alot of graphics on it. The discipline system is also strict, but once you get a taste of it, you stop acting out alot and there are less disruptions in the classroom. Also, the teachers are adequately preparing us for the standardized test and regents. But guess what, 8th graders are allowed to take up to three regents before they get to high school (Earth Science, United States History, and Integrated Algerbra). They prepare us for those also. Our principal has also implemented a rather unorthodox way of helping the students pass all the classes. Its called Academic Probation and it is really making less students fail.  As for writing, we have to write in journals for every subject, which allows us to share our thoughts. The classes have lots of discussions and the students rotate through the work while helping each other in a nondisruptive manner. The teachers are kind and always willing to help. Most have much patience for those who are struggling and those who are very disruptive, which is very few. I have never seen a principal that is so down to Earth with the students. The school is very seperated from the other schools in terms of interactions. Most of the kids that are from the other schools in the building keep to themselves and most times you can't really hear them in the hallway. The scanning room and the metal detectors help ensure that the younger kids in the building are very safe. There is very little fighting at the school since our new principal and the other schools are buckling down as well. Preparatory Academy has turned its fate around and has finally earned its title as a College Board School. It is time that people start realizing this and start giving PAW the respect it deserves. PAW is better than what the surrounding schools have to offer. And as being a student there I can give a testimonial at any time to its progressive ways. Although I am leaving to go to The Brooklyn Latin School, I will never forget the way PAW has changed me. It changed me from a very shy and quiet person to a very eloquent leader that has taken charge of my education and now has the highest GPA in the whole school. If you are considering this school, you should choose to go to it. From the past to now, it turned from the school for the delinquents of Queens to a school that nurtures the academically gifted, and that is something to applaud.

The school was not crowded and there were no gangs.  Maybe some students that attended the school belonged to gangs but there was no gang activity in the school. Students have no respect for the teachers, the school, or each other.  As for being jumped by a high school student, maybe your parents should have thought better about sending their middle school child to a 6-12 school that shares a building with three other high schools.  Although, considering the two nearby middle schools (M.S. 231 and M.S. 72), preparatory academy is much safer.
