Chancellor Carmen Fariña announced 73 schools selected to join the Learning Partners Program, an innovative and collaborative initiative that brings schools together to share practices to improve learning in the classroom and raise student outcomes. Through the program, one host school with strong practices in a particular focus area will support two partner schools seeking to strengthen their own practices in that area. Eagle Academy for Young Men III was chosen to host Catherine & Count Basie Middle School 72 and Pathways College Preparatory School: A College Board School. Read more here.

Amidst the debate on charter schools, The New York Times held up the Eagle Academy schools as examples of successful hybrid schools, which strive to offer low-income children something like the experience of a private education within the context of the traditional public system. This school is a breeding ground for violence. There isn't one week that goes by that multiple students fights occur (some of them between male and female students). Teachers are expected to break up the fights with little help from security or administration. When a fight occurs, the students are "counseled" by guidance for a few moments, and then sent back to class. Students are rarely suspended, so they continue to fight, disrupt classes, and act in disturbing ways because they know they won't be punished. Want to know why scores are so low? Teachers can't teach because the student population is disrespectful, nasty, and cruel. With the exception of a few bright, wonderful students, most students don't care about their education because they don't receive support from home. Teachers--stay away from this school unless you want it to ruin your sense of self-worth. Parents--don't send your children here unless you want them to be involved in multiple fights per week.

Some of this review is wrong. If you are reading this, you are being fed bad information. This is coming from a student here. This is experience. This is the truth.

First off, we barely focus on community service. Did you know that the minute we were assigned our homeroom classes we had to "not waste a single moment" and launch ourselves into books and "instructional time?" And on the one day of the school year where we go to the park to pick up garbage, the teachers just allow the kids to play around and put branches in garbage bags or something. 

Next, there is favoritism. To the extreme.That's self explanatory. If a person who is a favorite is rudely talking when they aren't supposed to, don't expect them to get in trouble, or even a failing grade. In the end, they have a reputation for being a "good influence" and even get 95 grades and higher, while everyone else is trying much harder and ending up with 70s and 80s, then being called "dumb." Yeah, they call us dumb. 

We have no honors class, so gifted kids beware. We had one for a year, and I was in the honors program, but they basically skipped the whole 7th grade curriculum and went to 8th grade. And who can forget that annoying pressure we got:"Oh, you're the smartest class! So you set the example! So that means get the highest scores! Donate the highest in the food drive!" and other things like that. Now, they are saying that we "set the bar too high for other classes to reach" and they removed all honors courses. They said we were too smart so we had to lower our standards, pretty much. 

Next, this school is full of crazy kids. Believe me when I say this, because as insane as it sounds, children throw things as light as paper and writing utensils across the room during class to FOOTBALLS. And they jump on desks too! And chase each other! And I lost count to the times when some idiot slapped my rear and ran away, or groped my chest from behind and ran away. And the teachers do nothing about it. All they do is give kids they hate detention. 

I can only speak from the older grades, since I was here when the school first opened to now. Well, we have crappy supplies. I cut my hand multiple times because I was sitting at a broken desk or chair and it just so happened that I had to get something. The textbooks are worn out and most of them were here since 2006! Everything we have is a hand me down from 231. And yet they have the money to get brand new 6th grade supplies only. This school is cheap. 

This school is overcrowded, too, so beware. Advisory consist of at least 30 kids per advisory, who are all rude and ignorant. It also has all the heat in the world and less than half of the rooms have A/C. Oh wait, all the teachers rooms have A/C! Wow! Now what about the kids? 

The thing with clubs in this article is incorrect. We had lots of clubs last year, like cheerleading and step, and less than half of them are still here. We have no tech club. We have no tech. We have no cheerleaders or step team. Our only sports teams are basketball, which is shared campus-wide, and track.

We have a book overload and no lockers. I got back cramps from carrying a 30 pound bag filled to the max with books to and from school each day. As if that's not enough, I carry an additional lunchbox with me holding extra books and papers I need for the day. 

Our lunch period is 15 minutes long, this being both recess and lunch together. I counted it on my watch. 

The most common punishment for misbehaving kids is to walk 3-10 laps in the hallway. I don't even know if that's legal. That hallway is super long and narrow. They actually had 7th graders like me to walk laps in the hallway from 2:30 pm to 3:25 pm, which is dismissal time. Our feet were all cramped up. And that was because the 7th graders transitioned "noisily" instead of "silently and quickly." This is irritating. Lots of teachers there could really use the exercise instead of yelling at us to stay quiet or we would walk for 10 more minutes. 

We always have to line up in ABC order, which is considerably annoying. Even on trips. 

Too many projects! 

We have a violin in the school logo and no dance or music class. 

These are all the reasons I can think of to stay away from Community Voices. Don't make the same mistake I made. Although Ms. Collins is a pretty friendly principal, there are flaws a plenty in her school. Oh yeah, and Ms. Peters and Ms. Hooks are actually really cool. Most of the other teachers stink at teaching, pick favorites, or do nothing but yell, even if the class is in order. And they overuse that "Give me 5" symbol! What makes them think that over 100 kids scattered in a school yard are going to see one teachers hand up, the instantly get in ABC order with their class? Beware Community Voices!

"The school has a great community spirit thanks to the parents association and the teachers," writes a parent, who complains that the principal is "unapproachable and not extremely parent-friendly."

A parent writes: "I would like to say that the addition of Ms. Defalco as the assistant principal is awesome. She has made herself a part of the PS 2 family. She is very pleasent and approachable. She really loves the kids and she shows it. My two boys love her."

A parent writes, "I would like to thank Mr. Taddeo for the job he has done in his first year as principal. My kids, who transferred to PS 2 this past September, love the school and its close-knit, family-like atmosphere. I also like it very much having come from a large, factory-like, not parent-friendly school." He says that while his children were regarded as nothing more than 'test scores" at their old school, "at P.S. 2 they are people first and test scores second. The staff is so nice and friendly; I wish my kids could stay there forever."

A parent of one child currently at the school and another who graduated said it's hard for children to leave the excellence of PS 2 for the area's middle schools, which she does not consider of the same caliber. "I can't think of anything bad to say about this school," she added.

"Two of my children attend PS 2 after a recent transfer from another local school," writes a parent. "My children have blossomed under the direction of the supportive and knowledgeable staff of PS 2. The staff is extremely caring and well versed in the rigors and demands of the new curriculum without losing sight of what is most important: the children. The family like atmosphere and student focused philosophy is owed to their present leader: Mr. Joseph Taddeo. My children owe their emotional and academic growth to the very well rounded, supportive and professional educators that they have encountered this year at PS 2: Ms Ryan, Ms. Cione (classroom teachers). The children look forward to school because of these ladies as well as the specialty teachers (gym, art, computers, library, and science) who make learning not only a challenge but fun! Thank you PS 2 for making a difference!!!!!"

As a former Teacher at IS 10, I can only share positive things, specifically:

Parents - Your child will receive a solid education from a fine institution which has a hardworking, dedicated, friendly and talented staff.  Your child will become part of a community of learners that are deeply cared for and loved.  They will be very, very safe and enjoy their middle school experience.  You will never regret sending your child to this school.  

Future Teachers - If you are lucky enough to get selected to join this amazing group of educators, you won't regret it.  I can honestly say that this staff is like family and I miss them dearly.  Due to child care/transportation issues, I needed to change schools, otherwise I would have never left.  I was there 4 years, and it was wonderful.  The tone and vibe are 100% upbeat and people are genuinely nice and willing to help you.   Teachers support other Teachers and every staff member is treated with respect.  

Administration - Principal Lopes is a class act!  He runs the school with a deep concern and passion for the children.  He respects you as a professional and allows you to have a personal life.  He does not micro-manage and empowers you to grow in your profession.  He values the staff and is 100% trustworthy and fair.  He listens to you and supports you.  You aren't going to get better than Mr. Lopes.  He's the kind of boss that you want to make happy and earn his respect.  

I was lucky enough to report into Assistant Principal Altan.  There aren't enough words to describe how appreciative I am for all that she did for me.  I was the School Librarian and any time I asked for supplies or needed anything for the library she always said yes.  100% of the time.  She's kind, fair and a great listener.  I was empowered to grow in my profession and given the flexibility to improve my craft and incorporate my vision for the library.  She's a person of her word and highly trustworthy.  

Bottomline, if your child attends this school or you're lucky enough to get a job, it will be a worthwhile experience that you won't ever regret.  A happy staff equates to a positive learning experience which enhances the student's lives.  This review is long overdue and I could go on, but I'd just be raving and I think you know I'm a huge fan.

I.s10 is an awesome school. The staff is great and everything is well organized. I am a Junior in high school now and I got to say my I.s10 years were the best years of my life. I still got a lot of unforgettable memories from it. There is music, drama , arts classes. They also do plays and performances and have beacon programs with sports involved. My brother goes to this school and next my other brother will go. Also has uniform which is great because it keeps the school in order, and you don't have to think in what your going to wear or be discriminated on what you wear, because everyone is the same. Also have After school programs that help you with your classes. This school has had a Grade of A for Three years in a row!!! I Highly recommend it. The neighborhood is perfect too, your next to train and bus transportation and stores (eg: Pizzeria, grocery store, super markets and etc) and the school has a backyard which is a park with basketball courts, handball courts, a big field and it was just rebuild. The school has been under construction and it is in excellent conditions. The education is good but they barely give homework. You will feel welcomed :)

My child has been in this school for less then 3 months as a new 6th grader. I have been putting out money on school supplies and uniforms. Now a new edition to this khaki pants added to the list? These are not private school children. The economy is bad for everyone. Most families cannot afford this. This school has cost me over $200. More then the average college text book. IS 10 has been added to the state's list of schools needing improvement under No Child Left Behind because of inadequate performance on the state tests in English.
For the 2006-07 school year, IS 10 is newly identified by the State Education Department as "in good standing."

A parent who has been part of the school for more than a decade writes that the new principal has brought "amazing energy" to the building. "There are now three languages taught--Italian, Spanish and French. There is also now drama, which put on a breathless production of 'Annie' last spring, chorus, computer graphics, and student government," this parent notes.

"The school is not bad and not good either," writes a student. "Students shouldn't do group work all the time because some or your group members don't put much effort. Also lessons are only 10 minutes long and group work the rest of the period. Teachers are not allowed to write on the board but on big pieces of white paper."

The teachers' union chapter leader at the school says of the new principal, Clemente Lopes: "It's great to have a leader who's not afraid to make decisions. Morale has gone up tremendously. He's strict, but he listens." An 8th grader says problems at the school such as loitering in the hallways are improving and that "the school is getting better."

A teacher writes: "America's Choice [a school-design program implemented in some low performing schools] is the worst program to ever enter NYC public schools. It stifles creativity, is oppressive, and is intended for small classes which, this school does not have. The allegedly mandated "Workshop Model" is useless. Teachers are not allowed to write on student work. Instead they should attach "Post It notes" with a comment. This is so students don't feel their work is being taken away from them. The administrators, parents and teachers of Region 4 weren't educated with America's Choice. Why should their children be? The school is overwhelmed with behavior problems."
A student complains that the school is mediocre. She complains that the science lab "isn't even set up yet," adding, "It's the middle of the year!"

A student writes: "IS 10 was bad [last year] when I was in 6th grade, but it got so much butter now that I'm in 7th grade. I think it was because of our new principal Mrs. Leimsider ... or maybe because of the Board of Education. ... I'm just so happy that it changed."

Parent Mary Topololous writes: "My child is having great difficulty learning in groups." She says "the teachers are wonderful," but she also believes there are communication problems between the new administration and parents.

"While I can't say the school is the best, I can't say it's the worst either," writes a recent graduate. While some teachers are better than others, this student writes that the "atmosphere is like any other zoned junior high" and while she didn't always like the staff, "none of these matter as long as a child is determined to do good. I just graduated from here as one of the top ten students and am going to Townsend Harris high school. But the memories in IS 10 will always be remembered as some of the most fun-filled and joyous times."

Lanai, a student, writes, "I just graduated from IS 10 and its exactly a good school. I got accepted to Bayside High School ... ." She writes that the teachers and the principal, Jane Danapas, are very dedicated and "on top of things." She adds, "Students love the school and it's not overcrowded."
WOAH THIS COMMENT WAS 14 YEARS AGO! HI PERSON

I am extremely dissatisfied with this school and am surprised to read the positive review by insideschools.org. My daughter attended from K-5 and was in the honors class. She had a mostly positive experience, but my son, who is now in Grade 4 has had the opposite experience. Neither of my kids has ever participated in the "drama" program, and, as a parent, I have never received any notices about a career day, even though I spoke to my daughter's class about my career (at my own initiative) and wrote about my visit for a professional publication. The teachers and staff in this school are grumpy. They are constantly yelling at kids for no reason. My son is not allowed to go to the bathroom when he needs to. He is told to wait for lunch, but the lunch ladies do not let him go to the bathroom either. I find that students are regularly berated by their teachers, especially the teacher who prepares them for the 4th grade science test. However, this teacher is known for "getting results" on the test, so no criticism of him is accepted. Just today, my son was yelled at by his math teacher for no knowing how to use a protractor. I am very disappointed with the turn this school has taken in the nine years that one or both or my children have attended.
During the official opening of nearby PS 361 Woodside Community School it was revealed that students from the overcrowded PS 11 are still being temporarily housed at the new school. Read more here.

My kindergartener has 18 students in her class with a teacher & a para. BUT they share a classroom with another class of 18.  The entire kindergarten year is like this. This school is over capacity.   The safety & vibe numbers above are misleading.

DOE/ PEP passed the proposal to bus 250 students to PS 171 for the Fall 2014/Spring 2015 school year. If the 250 seats are not filled with kindergarteners, the first graders will fill these seats.  Currently the SLT team's plan is to have 25 students with one teacher & a para for each K-class. Those who remain at PS11, the entire first grade & second grade will be in co-teaching classrooms.  Which means anywhere from 38 to 46 students in one room with 2 teachers working together.  To fit everyone in the school, the 3rd 4th & 5th grades will also have one co-teaching classroom; 2 teachers with 38 to 46 students.  Please note that this does not meet current building codes.  This plan is the best the DOE can come up with. During construction, 10 to 12 existing classrooms are being demolished. The new addition which will eventually hold 300 new seats, elevator, a dance studio, a new cafeteria, science & art rooms. Old cafeteria will be converted into a larger library. The new school, currently under-construction, PS339, will hopefully open on time in Fall of 2015 and will become the annex for PS11.  PTA has pledge to help out with this one year of busing by providing daycare prior to school starting for kids who have siblings that will be bused, & assistance with transportation for emergencies. Teachers or bus matrons have also been promised to ride the buses with the students back & forth from PS11 to PS 171.

Many parents are concerned about plans to bus students to PS 171 to accommodate construction plans at PS 11; however, PS 11 Principal Anna Ekfarpides said at a PEP meeting that school and district administrators exhausted all options before choosing to bus students three miles to PS 171. Read more here.
The Panel for Education Policy delayed a vote that would relocate kindergarten students at PS 11 while their school is repaired. Read more here.
Parents and elected officials are concerned about plans to bus students three miles from PS 11 to PS 171 during the upcoming construction at PS 11. Read more here.

The DOE plans to build an annex to ease overcrowding at PS 11, where some classes have as many as 40 students. However, parents are concerned that during the two-year construction period, overcrowding at the school will become even worse. Read more here.
The Daily News reports that parents are upset about a plan to bus kindergartners to PS 171 in Astoria while PS 11 builds an annex to alleviate overcrowding.

When choosing ps 11 for your kindergartner this fall of 2014, he or she will most likely be bused from ps11q directly to ps171 in Astoria. 2014's  first graders & second graders will be in a classroom of 45 kids with 2 teachers.  The reason for the Annex is to build a new building and playground. The new addition will be beautiful and a great addition to Woodside.  Q339, a new school in Woodside, should be ready for fall of 2015.  Some of Q339 will become an the new Annex for PS11 until the new addition is complete.  Ideally this new construction should have been done 10+ years ago.

PS 69 is a an okay school, however, there is a huge inconsistency amongst teachers.  Some are extremely good, some are not.  I have two children close in age and the quality of instruction or lack of is evident in the work they bring home.  The honors class is providing more rigorous work and my child in that class is receiving a better education than my other child.  
Classes are overcrowded, recess is often indoors, in front of a screen despite three outdoor spaces.  Why?   
Communication between teachers and parents is again, inconsistent.  Some teachers are amazing, others are completely checked out. 
This school needs to reflect on where they were, where they are and where they are going.  The drastic drop in state test scores is alarming and hopefully a wake up call for all involved.

"P.S 69 is a good school, but I would like to see it become a great school. It has a warm, neighborhood feel and an amazingly diverse population. Academics seem strong, but there is no visual arts program, which leaves a huge gap in any child's education, nor is there a languages program. There is a music program, including an after-school strings program starting in kindergarten, but it seems pretty unorganized and I have yet to see any plays or musicals put on by students, despite the Performing Arts School tag in the school name. There is some additional enrichment, but only for 6 to 12 weeks out of the year. The administration seems somewhat open to change, but what this school really needs are more parents who will work hard to initiate new programs to provide a truly enriched and complete education."

A 2nd grade teacher said that the new teaching methods, in which may work in groups independently of the teacher, had helped her students hone socialization skills. She said her children have intense but respectful debates on various issues within their groups.

The nonprofit NYC Kids RISE launched a campaign called Funding Long Island City’s Future that aims to raise at least $30,000 for college savings accounts for students in kindergarten, first and second grade at PS 76 and four other Long Island City schools by Dec. 31, the LIC Post reports.

My daughters attend P.S.76Q and they are happy and doing great at school. The school environment offers a source of motivation to the students as the teachers they've had have been receptive, attentive, and dynamic. I've noticed most teachers in the school are the same way, these are compassionate and smart teachers. The teachers and administration place a great emphasis on social emotional learning. The parents are readily welcomed into the school through monthly Family Fridays where we get to experience the first period in our kids' classroom, the teachers have time to speak to you during mornings, there are parenting workshops, and it's easy to be involved with the PTA as a Volunteer. The school itself is spacious inside and the kids have a yard where they come out during recess and other times to play. Great things happen here and the Principal leads the way with positive leadership. My daughters and I love it here. I, myself, am a former students and have amazing memories here.

While PS76 is not a school that receives much "buzz" in district 30, it offers a smallish school experience...compared to many schools in the district...and relatively small class size. The principal is a former math teacher and speaks very eloquently about his teaching and curriculum philosophy. The teachers he has hired present as similarly young and dynamic, and they balanced by a team of seasoned teachers. The school does host a number of special education programs and supports, and as such has AWESOME support staff and therapists. Parents concerned with test scores should be aware of the school's commitment to special education and ELLs when evaluating the school's scores.
the school shares it's building with ps 277Q. A district 75 program which occupies some of the 2nd floor.

"This school is like no other...a public school with a private-like setting. I couldn't imagine a better place for my child to receive such a well rounded education. The principal of the school follows the philosophy"Educating The Whole Child". He proves this to be true by providing programs for every child, before, during, and after school. My child could be part of cooking, fitness, photography, enrichment programs in the Extended Day Program, as well as the SchoolWide Enrichment Model...but when he needs help I also know that he could receive after school small group assistance. I commend this principal, staff, and school community. Every school should mirror your philosophy. This school is a true GIFT to the LIC community."

"My child has been at PS 78 since 2nd grade; as she's in fifth grade, this year is her last. PS 78 is a terrific school with outstanding and dedicated teachers. In addition, the current leadership of the school is excellent, which is extremely important in terms of the tone of this school or any school for that matter as well. One of the nicest and I think most special things about PS 78 is that children of different abilities, socioeconomic and ethnic backgrounds, including children of recent immigrants or children who are immigrants themselves interact freely both in school as often socially as well with a minimum of cliques. Much of the success in this area has to do with the school's leadership and the positive and democratic attitude of the teachers. While parents' concerns and input are taken seriously, "squeeky wheels" aren't able to sway the school's mission of helping all children learn in a safe, respectful and positive environment."

"It is thrilling to arrive daily to PS 78 as a teacher," writes Scott Dennis. "It is a collegial environment where fellow teachers are enthusiastic to discuss how to best instruct their students. It is a collaborative environment where everyone brings their strengths to the table. Students and teachers are excited about learning and seek to better each other everyday."

My daughter has been here now for two years and it has been the best experience for her. Her academics have gone up, she has made great friends,  and has had amazing teachers who keep us informed with upcoming tests, trips, most recent student scores ... I would Highly recommend this school.  It is a hidden gem. I can truly say this as a parent and as an elementary teacher myself.

I had two children attend this school. This school has several issues. First of all the principal and assistant principal do not want to be bothered when you want to bring something to their attention, they brush you off a show they don't care. Unfortunately you cannot list names in this review but my daughter was treated very bad by her two fifth grade teachers. They lied to both her and me several times and disrespected her in class often. These two teachers and many of the teachers in this school pick their favorite students while the rest are ignored and treated very disrespectful. If you do your research you will see this school is failing academically. State test results are far below average and there is low progress in all aspects of learning. This school was our worst experience! Being zoned there my child started kindergarten and hated it at first. Overall this school is not good, if a child is struggling with a subject i don't think they is ANY help or advice besides - pay attention at school and study more. My comments are about the STEM Academy at PS 85. My daughter has been attending for a year and a half and she is very happy at STEM. Ms. Pang and Ms. Griner are creative, professional, experienced and very adept at challenging gifted learners without placing undue pressure on them. I had two reservations about the school when I enrolled my daughter: the train and the fact that the Academy currently only extends til 5th grade. Both of these have been allayed—the train is not nearly as rumbling inside the school as outside it. As parents we spend a lot of time just outside the school on the steps where yes, it is loud—but inside the school it's just an ambient sound. I know that the DoE is making plans to expand and grow the program, so I'm actually very pleased that STEM will soon be accepting 6th graders. 


One of the greatest surprises about PS85 and STEM in particular is how smart and active the parent body are. They are organized, creative, and friendly, and our family has become friends with other families there in a way we never quite expected. It's been a lovely exercise in community-building.

can you respond to my comment? i want to know if this school is good because i have a daughter who was offered a spot into this school? should she come? She is going to fifth grade next year, so she is currently in fourth grade now.

The school only goes to 5th grade so it may not make sense to move her for 1 year.  Would she be transferring this year or next year?  Is it for the district g&t program?  If it is for the district g&t program, I would switch because the g&t teachers are great (as are many of the gen ed teachers, although I don't know them as well) and because the district g&t program kids will likely go to PS 122's Academy for Middle school.  Where is your daughter in school now?

We have been very happy at this school since our child started last year.  Ms. Chang, the principal, has been very open to implementing suggestions from parents.  The teachers in the g&t program have been wonderful and our child loves going to school.  The other kids in the classes are super smart and they all make each other want to learn.  Our fellow parents are super-involved and down to earth.  The Parents Association is in the process of becoming a 501c3 organization in order to improve fund-raising. The parents association did pay for a free "clubs" program last spring detailed in the insideschools review.

There is no after school  club program 3 to 5, its only 2:25 to 3:07 and its only opened to a limited amount of kids, first come, first served. The after school program is a pay based program called serious fun.

Not a true G&T program, the math curriculum below any Citywide and District program.  The grade received from DOE is accurate, its a STEM program but some teacher do not know how to use a computer. The T stands for technology in name only. At a parent meeting there was a father of a child at the school almost crying because the teachers did not check the kids homework, the child told the father' why should I do my homework if the teacher does not check it?

None of the above statement is true. It is the worst kind of rumor mongering. The STEM math curriculum is the same as every other district 30 g&t curriculum. They all use the exact same NYC DOE-approved curriculum--period. There was some discussion between parents and principle Chang earlier this year about accelerating the math curriculum, though, because many of the STEM parents believed that the students were not being challenged enough by the NYC DOE-approved curriculum. Ms. Chang has agreed to a planned and controlled acceleration. 

In regards to homework, my child's homework is not only checked every single day by her teacher, but receives comments and rubric scores (1-4), which are somewhat like a "grade."
A Spanish dual language program will be starting at P.S. 92 in the fall, as reported by the Jackson Heights Post.

PS 92 Q, The Harry T. Stewart Sr. School has been awarded a federally funded magnet grant. The school magnet theme is STEM/STEAM with a focus on Engineering, Architecture and the Arts. Through this grant we have been afforded the opportunity to partner with many NY City Organizations and business. Some of these are: Center for Architecture, Salvadori Center, School of Visual Arts, The NY Hall of Science, Queens Museum, BricksforKidz (LEGO), and a number of other programs and organizations. This grant has afforded our entire school community with an abundance of new resources, experiences, curricula and opportunities that would otherwise not be available to us. This is an exciting time for our entire school community. We are thrilled to be able to provide for our students a chance to learn through innovative means, grow as life-long learners and be ready for the 21st century. GREAT THINGS ARE HAPPENING HERE!

The nonprofit NYC Kids RISE launched a campaign called Funding Long Island City’s Future that aims to raise at least $30,000 for college savings accounts for students in kindergarten, first and second grade at PS 111 and four other Long Island City schools by Dec. 31, the LIC Post reports.

At P.S. 111 paraprofessionals are "on the front lines" of the school’s efforts to improve reading instruction. The nonprofit Literacy Trust has trained teaching assistants to work one-on-one with first graders to reinforce basic reading skills, including step-by-step phonics lessons during which students learn the relationship between sounds and letters."Principal Dionne Jaggon believes the school is on the upswing and partly credits an emphasis on rigorous phonics-based instruction," Chalkbeat reports.
P.S. 111 Jacob Blackwell has made "demonstrable improvement," even though it is still struggling, the New York State Education Department said, according to Chalkbeat.

Community School 111Q is definitely a school on the rise. I have worked at CS 111Q for over 13 years and have seen positive growth throughout my time here. The partnerships and programs offered by the school are unlike any other in the area.  No doubt about it we are the Jewel of Long Island City.

PS/IS 111Q is a safe nurturing school offering our students many different ways to learn.  We offer many different programs to meet the needs of the students.  In addition, we also address the needs of the parents, including cooking classes, many different family trips, and  a pantry that is fully stock to help any family in need.  Please visit our website at http://www.Ps111q.org to see all the great things happening here, or even better stop on by we love having visitors.

I have been working as a Guidance Counselor at CS 111Q for 15 years.  I watch our scholars grow from being children into teenagers.  Our school has so many programs and offers so much support to our scholars and their families.  I enjoy working with our scholars and guide them to do the best they can to succeed in life.

PS 111Q is warm, safe, and nurturing environment for all students.  Students of all background are accepted and cherished regardless of their ethnicity.  As an educator I have seen how the curriculum is engaging, rigorous, and exciting as it prepares our student to succeed in a technologically advancing global society.  Come and visit us.  You will be greatly rewarded.

PS/IS111Q is a great school. Students are educated in a positive learning environment. Along with learning about academics, students take part in shows and other fun activities. Parental involvement is also encouraged. At this school, parents takes part in activities with their children. There is also a store where parents can collect items.

P.S 111Q is a great school. There are a lot of opportunity for the students. As an educator here i am so proud of my students and the hard work they have put in through out the school year. https://vimeo.com/118164906

I’ve been a part of the 111 team for a few years and I will have to say that our school has come a long way. The staff gives great support to our scholars and their families. Not to mention the great partnerships we have at 111. For example Lincoln center, zone 126, and our amazing after school program, Jacob Ris. All parternships have help our school develop as a community.

P.S. 111 is truly the jewel of Long Island City.  Our students are truly amazing.  Our teachers are truly dedicated to bringing the best out in our students.  We have some wonderful partnerships with other institutions such as Playworks, Museum of Moving Image, The Museum of Natural History and Studio in the School.  Our partnership with Broadway Jr allowed our students to put on a sensational production of Annie.  In ELA we have had a 15% over the last 2 years and Math last year we had a modest but encouraging 5% increase.  Overall our school is on the cusp of greatness.  Our Principal Jaggon and our Assistant Principal Ms. Guzman have provided amazing leadership that has allowed our school to thrive.  If you would like to check out our students in action please visit our school website: 

http://www.ps111q.org
Congratulations on your performance with Annie! The students did such an amazing job!

Over the years PS 111Q has made drastic improvements. The energy of the students and staff is consistently positive. This positive energy creates a school environment that is enjoyable for all. I look forward to seeing how the school will continue to flourish.

The students at PS/IS 111Q have worked diligently to work across the subject areas to culminate a project that has raised hundreds of dollars for students in Puerto Rico's hurricane ravished classrooms.

Community School 111 is a wonderful school.  There are many programs that are designed to foster the needs of the scholars . The principal makes sure that the teachers are equipped with what they need to be able to provide the academic needs of the student body. By far this school is one of the best in District 30.

As a Speech and Language teacher at PS111 I have the opportunity to work with a wide-range of students with varying needs and I am fortunate to work in a school that provides a diverse range of programs for the students to participate in and showcase their skills and abilities

PS 111 has many special programs for the students to be creative. The students  have opportunities to sing, dance act, and create art with programs such as Leap, Community Word Project, Broadway Junior, Museum of the Moving Image and of course the PS 111 art program.

PS 111 is a school with so much opportunity for their students. As an educator there, it is amazing how well-rounded the school is and how we have the opportunity to incorporate everything into our classroom.

As a 1st grade teacher, my students are offered ample opportunities for learning with the help of different partnerships.  The programs that we use are appropriate for all students to learn. I substitute teach and working at this school was hands-down the absolute worst sub job I have ever had in NYC. I didn't know it was on the persistently dangerous list before going there. Some of the older kids have a lot of needs and emotion management issues. Related to this, some students, are disrespectful to each other and to teachers, and are defiant. The paraprofessional in the room I worked in was so burnt out she just put her head down on the desk. I feared for my own safety as well as that of the students. I called the office numerous times and help did eventually come, but it took a while (sometimes an hour). I hope people wake up and support legislators that will give schools like this one the support they need.
PS 111 is one of four schools that remain on the 2016 "persistently dangerous" list, out of a previous 27 schools. Chalkbeat reports.

PS 111 is one of four schools eligible for a portion of a 75 million dollar grant issued by the state Education Department in order to increase parent engagement, implement early childhood education programs, and transform some of the Queens schools listed in the bottom 5% in academic achievement. Read more here.
PS 111 has been removed from the State Education Department's list of struggling schools and no longer faces possible receivership. Politico New York reports.

PS 111 Jacob Blackwell is one of 27 New York City schools on the 2015-2016 list of schools considered to be "persistently dangerous" by the state Department of Education, based on the number of disruptive or violent incidents. Read more here.

Four teachers have been suspended over a school surveillance video which shows first graders bullied by eighth graders at PS 111. The principal of the school, Dionne Jaggon has yet to comment on the incident. She was formerly the principal at a charter school that was shut down. Read more here and here.
Parents are outraged by school surveillance video scenes of first graders bullied by eighth graders at PS 111. Read more here.

I as a form student whom graduated back in 2013, I found the school to be good. I'm speaking for my self since I haven't been back. I had some of my best times there, lasting over 9years in one place. Honestly former Principal Randy Seabrook should have remained principle. If they say it is that dangerous as it is (assumed since I don't know about any changes), wouldn't they hire any teachers who weren't soft and get people who were tough and who can control the class.

Ninety-four low-performing schools are now called “Renewal Schools,”. They will receive increased funds designated for an hour of additional learning time, after-school and summer programs, and teacher training. The principals will also be under review. Read more here.
P.S. 111 landed on the state Education Department’s list of “persistently dangerous schools" in 2014. Schools on the list have a high number of violent or disruptive incidents. Read more here.
They are not mentioned in that article you posted
:-( All I can say, the discipline at this school is by far the worst I have ever seen in my entire life!

The information is woefully outdated.  Donna Steele has not been the Parent Coordinator for many years.   I retired in July 2009 after having served as the UFT Teacher Center Staff Developer/Mathematic Coach at P.S. 111 for six years.  Randy Seabrook has been a godsend to the school and has done many wonderful things to turn the school climate from acrimonious to relatively harmonious.

VOICE Charter School will likely move its upper grades into an empty Catholic school building across the street this fall. The proposal will be voted on May 18, 2011. Read the announcement in The Daily News: LIC public school, charters show they can share space & thrive.

The nonprofit NYC Kids RISE launched a campaign called Funding Long Island City’s Future that aims to raise at least $30,000 for college savings accounts for students in kindergarten, first and second grade at PS 112 and four other Long Island City schools by Dec. 31, the LIC Post reports.

I graduated from P.S. 112 many years ago (like 64).  At that time the school colors were scarlet and gray.  (Fred Jacobson, the principal at the time, must have gone to Ohio State.)

I just read that Ohio State was forced to change its school colors to ruby and porpoise.  Seems that some school in MICHIGAN had those colors since 1875, while Ohio State adopted them 4 years later.  In what must have been the dumbest lawsuit ever, Ohio State had to change its colors.

Are P.S. 112's colors still scarlet and gray?  Does the school even have school colors?  Watch out, the Color Police are out to get you!

I would love to see an Inside Schools review for PS 112--as a working parent, I find it hard to attend events and get a "full picture" of school life.  While the staff is generally nice, I do feel they say everything is "great"...  It's hard to discern what the actual school is like, and what the kids actually do during the day.

PS 112 has been added to the state's list of schools needing improvement under No Child Left Behind because of inadequate performance on the state tests in math.
A former student writes that "there were many opportunities for everyone" at the school. "The teachers worked us hard and prepared us for middle school. I miss 112 very much."

PS 112 now uses the Columbia Teacher's College writing and reading workshop model, notes a teacher, who also points out that the school has an annex at Laguardia Community College that holds inclusion classes for the lower grades.

PS 122 ranked third in the city on the 7th grade state math and English exams. Read more here.
PS 122 is one of many Queens schools that remains overcrowded, despite an overall reduction in overcrowding city- and borough-wide. Read more here.
PS 122 has scored well on a new school ratings system SchoolGrades.org - developed by the Manhattan Institute and Laura and John Arnold Foundation. Read more here.

I am reading all the comments/reviews as a concerned parent, who's child is going to attend this school for Kindergarten this September 2015, and I feel completely lost, as all I read is contradictions between comments, for example: I read as many reviews that say that teachers and principle is hostile to ed students, and favor the gt ones, as I read reviews that say the absolute contrary of it: the teachers and principles are hostile to gt students and favor the ed ones...
This contradiction I find it in other areas and topics too... What is it really??? How are these things measured???
PS 122 was among several Queens' schools to receive special funds for technology upgrades through City Councilman Costa Constantinide's participatory budge program. Read more here.

I just called to request a tour and was told they don't do that.  Then I was told, there are open houses in May once your kid is enrolled. Then I pushed back and was sent to a Parent Coordinator who cleared the whole thing up and took my name. But honestly,  what does this say about the people running this school? They don't know that they give open house tours to prospective K parents?

This school shows how corrupted the system and the city is. District g&t schools are only K-5 however illegally this school allows admission to its g&t middle school automatically for their students. If the school want a g&t middle school should open their seat  to all of the city/district students and not give priority to theirs. This preposterous and ILLEGAL. Where is DOE???

Actually it is legal. Elementary schoolers from PS 150 get zoned to the Academy as well. The DOE wanted to change this system a few years back, but due to parent protests, they did not change anything.

You are wrong. PS150 students no longer can enter 122 middle school without exams. Only PS122 students can do that contrary to DOE policy. They only enforce their policy to other districts. They should be sued.
PS 122 first-grader wins national student writing contest. Read more here.
Does anyone know if the entering class (2014-15) of G & T Kindergarteners will be allowed to automatically go to P.S. 122 middle school without re-testing?
Does that mean the future siblings can get into middle school or not?

Yes. HOWEVER, DOE said that they will revisit their decision which means that if your Kindergartener has a younger sibling then the sibling might not be able to enter PS122 middle school without testing. Take that into account. It seems that only citywides g&t (ps122 is not a citywide g&t) will always be guaranteed middle school placement without retesting.
yep! no need to retest, thanks to all the parents that protested a few years ago.
Only this year is sure. Parents protest could not make it permanent. DOE said will revisit their decision.

Students who live in Long Island City and take the bus to PS 122 were recently told that their bus commute would double in time after a change in its route. However, after parents complained, the DOE agreed to return the bus route to its original length. Read more here.

City Councilman Peter Vallone honored staff and students at PS 122 for the school's performance on the new state tests, attributing the school's success to the effectiveness of its G&T program. Students at PS 122 outscored both the city and state averages. Read more here.

I say 122 is a great school! Some people don't appreciate the fact that teachers work hard for their students to get a great grade! I say 122 is a perfectly amazing school and I don't know why anybody would deny it.

hi there! We are thinking of moving to Astoria (currently we live in Spain) and Mamie Fay is one of the schools we are looking at. Most of these positive reviews seem to be related to the G&T program. Does anyone have any feedback regarding the general ed classes? My sons speak English but have received all their education in Spanish and Catalan so I think they would be better suited for a slower pace to begin with. However, if all the resources and good teachers are allocated towards G&T, I'd like to know in advance. Thanks for any suggestions!

Unfortunately, the general ed classes get less attention, affection, and resources. When I attended the school (I'm currently in 10th grade), the school newspaper would always brag about the achievements of the gifted elementary classes and the academy (our gifted middle school). The best teachers are indeed part of the gifted program, and general ed staff aren't exactly top tier. But then again, the Academy is being allocated to another site, so maybe there'll be improvements? Also, what grades are your sons in?

Thanks for your reply. When we move there the younger will be either in kindergarden or first grade and the older will be going into 4th or 5th grade. Another question I have is if there are any decent middle schools in the area (other than the Academy).
IS 141 is also a very good middle school, about 10 or 11 blocks from the school, right near the subway. The school really pampers their kids, from what my friends tell me.
Go to IS 227 Louis Armstrong Middle School...the school starts in 5th grade. Very good school!
where do kids go to their middle school?
Some go to IS 227 Louis Armstrong Middle School, some to IS 141

The Department of Education has abandoned its plan to change admission to the gifted middle school program, the Academy. In a statement, the DOE said they "listened, and we know what an exceptional job P.S. 122 is doing with its G&T middle school students." Read more: DOE Abandons Plan to Alter Queens G&T Program

Schools Chancellor Dennis Walcott has agreed to meet with parents about his department's plans to reduce the school's popular middle school gifted program, DNAinfo reports. Read more: Chancellor Walcott agrees to meet with PS 122 Parents about G & T Changes

Parents are mulling over filing a lawsuit because of a plan to reduce the seats in the popular middle school gifted program. Some fear that the school will become overcrowded with the new plan to allow all PS 122 elementary students to stay for middle school. One parent said that adding more middle school seats in PS 122, would free up space at IS 141, creating a place for a Success Academy charter school. Read more:  Parents in uproar over plans to add middle school to PS 122 in Astoria .

Parents are outraged over proposed cuts in the Academy middle school gifted program and say it "makes no sense" to dismantle a program that is working. Read more: Outrage over fewer gifted and talented seats at Queens school.

Noblesse Oblige
In light of the new proposal regarding PS122Q Middle School Academy, that is to significantly cut down the number of G&T classes at PS122Q by 2019 we need to rally our school community as well as PS85, 217, 126, 150 to show that we will collectively and strongly fight for the legacy of the Academy in all of these schools. We must demand seats for our children. "Nobless Oblige" with prestige comes responsibility and tonight is a good night to teach our children about legacy. Mrs. Sabel's emotional remarks should be echoed through the halls of Tweed and City Hall. I am having my son write about what PS122Q mean to him today and for his future. Please encourage all your children to write... all the children who support great education. We will compile them and flood Tweed and City Hall with the very thoughts of the children, the future of this great city of New York.

Write this weekend and give it to your teacher or leave at the principal's office. If you are a PS122Q Mamie Fay alumni we would love to hear from you. 

We need to fight for our great institutions and we need to do it now. PS 122Q's accolades speaks for itself and we have the noble obligation to preserve the future of our children's education.
The DOE announces plans to reduce the number of G&T classes offered at the Academy in order to expand PS 122's general education classes to the 8th grade. Read more here.

As an alum of the Academy, I have to really give my props to all my teachers that I have had from my 7 years attending the school. Yes, at times the school is very stressful, however, the atmosphere, as many people have said, is extremely comfortable, and many of the teachers are always there for you to help you excel with whatever you need. Almost all of your classes are higher level classes, which is a huge plus once you reach high school. P.S. 122 Mamie Fay and The Academy are both very enriching, and an exciting place to be!

A current 8th grade student at P.S.122 writes, " I feel that there are some drawbacks to attending The Academy, yet there are a few ups to being here.  The Academy is a lot of work; it's a lot of stress to come here.  I feel that this school focuses the most on tests and projects more than anything else.  The environment here is comfortable, yet stressing at times.  I recently had a test every day a few weeks ago.  That really caused a lot of anxiety on all of the students.  It is very hard to maintain good grades; for some people, it is harder than for others.  Teachers here are very strict on grading, and when it comes to weighing all of your grades during report card time, some teachers hold tests accountable for 75% of your grade, and homework, projects and other for 25%.  Other teachers are more lenient, but overall you have to be on top of your grades and never stop.  You never know when you're going to get a pop quiz in Spanish, or a complex bonus question in History.  It's just very difficult to be a good student.
Despite all of the above, I still will say that this school definitely prepares you for a higher education. I won't deny that attending P.S.122 will help you cope with more assignments and more deadlines to worry about when you go to high school or college, but don't be too quick to think that you can handle it. It takes some getting used to."

I am an alum of The Academy, and I have to say the 3 years I have spent in this school were the most enriching of my entire academic career. At first, it was a bit of a struggle, but soon I got a hang of my grades. All the teachers know the students personally, and the atmosphere is extremely comfortable. All of the courses are one or two grade levels higher than they would be in an ordinary middle school. We were all even required to take the SHSAT, which resulted in all of us getting into a specialized high school. As a high school freshman at Bronx Science, I have to say that I am a top-tier student at my high school, all thanks to The Academy.
Does anybody know if it is true that children who fails one subject (even music) will be dropped out of school on Academy (6-8 grade)? My child is really worried about it....

As a current student at P.S.122, I can assure you that if your child fails one subject, he or she will not be at risk of being dropped out of the program, especially if it is not one of the five major subjects, such as music. If a child consistently was failing ,for example, math and english class, he or she may be put on probation, in which case he or she should try and improve their grades. However, I do not believe that only one probation will remove them from the program, but they are at risk. Hope this helps!

This is correct! my son attends ps 122 and has been placed on probation twice, i was informed that unfortunately he is going to be dropped of the program 
:(, that has left me scramble to look for another school for next year is sad because my son is very bright but Fails to give close attention to details schoolwork (forgets to submit homework/assignments on time), Has difficulty organizing tasks and activities due to his ADHD.. so wish me luck !!! otherwise a wonderful school and a very good principal

I'm a current student at this school and I am enjoying it. I have been in this school for almost three years now. I am in the g&t program in 5th grade. the only thing I am disappointed about is that my class does not have a graduation but the rest of the 5th grade does! The 5th grade g&t teacher is the best teacher I have ever had.
this is a very good school

My child has been at the school for several years and I am so grateful for the education and nurturing she has received.  Academics are important here, but the school values the arts, community service, and all those other pieces that make a child well rounded.  This is an excellent school!  Although the school is large, it is very well organized and safe, and there is a real community.  The school is not hostile to G and T parents as a poster says below.  I am one and have always felt welcome and respected.  It treats them as fairly as they treat any other parent, as it should be.  Quite frankly, the comment that the Academy plays a big part in pulling up test scores is insulting to all the children in the general ed school who do quite well.  There is only one g and t class among seven general ed per grade.  Do the math.  PS 122 is special place, which is why it is so popular and well regarded.

I chose to live in the neighborhood primarily based on PS 122's high ratings and many positive comments. My child is now in 1st grade at 122 and I am somewhat disappointed with how things are going. He routinely tells me he hates school because he's bored and many of his classmates are constantly misbehaving. He no longer has an opportunity to have a dance class because it was dropped due to "funding." He doesn't have access to an art class and only gets to go to the music room every other week. Instead of having the kids go outside for recess, most of the time he's indoors watching a movie. When he does get to go out, his class has nothing to do - they don't even get balls or jump ropes. They are expected to just play duck duck goose every time they go out. Ms. Aprea and my son's classroom teacher have been helpful in dealing with the other children's behavioral problems but the problems continue. Unfortunately some of the parents are not very proactive in helping to resolve their children's problems.I am seriously considering moving him to another school next year.

I was kind of disappointed with the school.  In the beginning of the year and until March my child hated school.  Naturally, I had to investigate and intervene.  There were a lot of issues that were not being addressed and I had to be on top of them to be sure the problems at hand were being dealt with.  I was truly not impressed on how they handled the issues.  I also found they push these kids too hard.  They practically are not allowed to have a childhood or to act as a child.  I wouldn't recommend this school.  There are better schools in Queens than this one.
this school does not have any bad things to say about.My childern three of them go here a nd they are doing great they camplain and have good things to say

I agree. My kindergartener does not like school.  She is at school 7 hours plus has 4-5 sheets of homework each night + 5-9 reading books.  They are expecting a lot from these kids, and some of them don't even turn 5 until December of their K year.  Why so much pressure on the little ones when those gains aren't making a difference in the older kids' scores?  

The movie instead of recess or some other activity should not be allowed.  She comes home and he is a zombie who just wants to veg out and watch TV.  When they do get out they are only allowed in the small courtyard area to play duck-duck-goose or hopscotch.  Why not let them run in the larger area?  I feel like I’m forcing my kid to go to prison.

Another thing that really bothers me is some of the letters and forms that come home have mistakes on them.  One form said it must be returned by Thursday...it was sent home on Thursday.  Some letters and forms don’t make sense and I’m not even sure how they want them filled out.  How can I trust these people to educate my kid when they can’t type a decent letter?

I’m not impressed with PS 122 and am looking at the Lutheran and Catholic schools in the neighborhood.

I am currently enrolled in 8th grade here, and this is a very amazing middle school, teachers say that we can get into any high-school we want, and even though it's competitive and it says it's a big school, not all of it is middle school, just 300 or so, and you know everyone's name, it's a big family full of friends :)

This school shows an active hostility to the parents of the g and t kids.Requests to start a special support group for g&t parents have been ignored. Complaints about homework load (3-4 hours a night) are ignored. Requests to meet as a group with the principal are ignored. THis school has an A and high scores and yet they forget that the G and T academy that plays a big part in pulling up the scores.

I agree completely. The Principal is definitely hostile to G and T parents and refuses to take our concerns on the homework load (3-4 hours a night for 9 year olds) seriously. Despite requests she refuses to meet the parents as a group. Various promises to look into homework load etc. have so far been unmet. Complaints are met with an attitude that basically says "If you don't like it, lump it." One teacher said that "there's a line from here to China to get in."
The increasing homework load is a schoolwide problem and is coming from the top--and not from individual teachers.

I am now in 8th grade and am in a different school, but I can firmly state that P.S.122 was the BEST school that I ever could have attended. The class work and test preperation helped me to exceed academically and prepared me for Middle School. Not to mention, they have an excellent afterschool program, and all the teachers there are amazing and wonderful. They explain all the material thoroughly, and make you feel extremely comfortable. I was extremely happy with my time spent at P.S.122 and recommend it to anyone who is interested.

"Though at first I found the fast-paced academics stressful, I became used to them and my time at 122 has been a wonderful experience," writes an 8th grader who started at the school in 3rd grade in the gifted program. "The atmosphere is fantastic because the gifted program is very small (in 3rd grade there was only one class and there are about 70 people in the current 8th grade),which creates a great sense of community amongst the students and the teachers. The kids are friendly and intelligent and the teachers are available to talk to or to help you if you do not understand what has been taught. Though there is a large emphasis on testing, it helps students excel on state and citywide tests. The majority of the students go on to the top specialized schools, such as Stuyvesant, Bronx Science, and Brooklyn Tech, and other highly selective schools. I love it here and will be sorry to leave."

This school has changed alot. The review above is 5 years old. You must visit this school again. The school had a flouroushing gifted and talented program. The teachers and administration are hands on and very supportive of the children. Sixth grade can be tough transition for many kids. With their new found freedom also comes responsibility. The administration is very aware of this. I feel so comfortable dropping my child off every day. The students are happy. The afterschool program is excellent. The teachers are very receptive to parent requests. They even changed their homework policy based on parent complaints. My son is in the GT program. He is challenged but not stressed out. More hw does not equal smarter students and the school understands this. Other middle schools in the district have received that memo yet and still bombard the children with inhumane amounts of hw.

I am guessing you are talking to me. No, I don't think you're stupid. I am a parent who has "been there, done that" in another junior high on the other side of Queens. Saw your post on the daily updates and thought I could give a suggestion. My son was badly bullied in 8th grade, emotionally and physically. He almost didn't graduate because he was failing most of his classes because of the stress. Teachers denied "seeing" the bullying.  He was coming home and locking himself in his room and not speaking to anyone. I  felt like I was being bullied too since I lost multiple days of work since I had to go to meetings with the dean about my son's multiple suspensions due to being involved in altercations. I also had to deal with my son's black moods. I didn't even want to answer my phone since I was being called by the school regularly about incidents. I talked to the teachers, the guidance counsellor, the deans. My son was suspended in school several times. Late on a Friday afternoon, I got a message that my son was getting a Principal's suspension. Of course, everyone was gone for the day when I called back. I was so angry about the situation at this point  that I had to do something! I looked up the discipline code, I found that the school hadn't followed the steps they were supposed to take in handling the situation. I sent a detailed email  explaining why my son should not get a principal's suspension to the guidance counselor, deans, assistant principal and principal. He had no history of aggression and he had tried to tell staff members about what was going on. The suspension was lifted. He and I wanted him switched out of his homeroom class because his bully had friends in the class who made my son's life difficult. Talked to the school about it and the AP counteroffered that she would separate them during homeroom period. A dean and I agreed that was ridiculous since the incidents happened all day long.  After a tag team of deans tried to railroad my son into saying he instigated problems with the bully, one of the deans was sympathetic and told me that I had to make a big deal out of it. I called the principal and the AP. The principal said he didn't think it was possible to switch classes mid way through the year due to enrollment. I called the AP and started talking "district office" to request a transfer and "lawyer" . A week later his class was switched. I made an enemy of the AP when her suggestion was disregarded. My son's class was switched midyear. He switched his homeroom, his teachers, lunch period and classmates. He was much happier and started to do better. Was it perfect? NO, the AP waited until the end of the year and did subtle but very obnoxious things to get back at me through him up until the very last day. Was it worth it? Yes.

[This parent complained of bullying, teasing and fighting at lunch and in the hallways in between classes. This parent said teachers suspend both parties for fighting instead of stopping misbehavior before a fight breaks out. This parent also says on "random mornings the NYPD will lock all entrances to the school and force these children to use only one entrance so that they can make them pass through metal detectors and search the kids book bags."]

Unfortunately, suspending both parties for fighting seems to be the norm rather than the exception in the NYC public schools. I don't know the particulars of the incident(s) you are referring to BUT if your child has resorted to self defense as a last resort and does not have a history of aggressive behavior, your best bet is to read the discipline code carefully.There are steps that the school is required to take as per the discipline code before suspending a student.If you feel that your child has been unfairly suspended,speak to the dean to determine what steps have been taken prior to suspension to stop the fighting.

I am a current parent from this school and i will not lie to you. keep your child away from this school. Teachers give work and tests on stuff they have not taught yet. My child lost a workbook and the teacher told me we COULD NOT buy another one (a lie) with no explanation why we couldn't you know like "we dont have any more workbooks right now" or something like that nothing no reason why. So my child spent almost two months writing the questions and answers for his homework from the website. Never less than 2 pages. Some nights my childs hand was hurting from all the writing. Finally the teacher must have realised the witch she was being to my child and let us purchase another workbook. Another time my child was givin a test from a teacher you know those test that you have to read a story first then answer questions. Well they were givin these question and answers as a test without reading the story first. I was told that another student informed the teacher that these test questions belong to a story they had not read yet and that they would fail the test because they had not read the story first. And the teacher did not care and still made them blindly answer these questions as a test without letting them read the story first. My child failed this test and maybe all the other kids in this class did too. That is an example of the kind of teachers and staff your child will be with in this school. I feared a complaint to the principle would have been turn around on us (it has been done to me before with this school) and would make my child be treated worst so i did not bother, but i would not suggest a dog go there to learn. Wondering if the part of the ELA that you are talking about is the part where a story or article is read to the children. The kids don't get a copy of it, they have to listen to the story, take notes while the teacher is reading and answer questions. The story is read once and then a second time. One time is for listening. One time is for taking notes. Then they answer the questions. It's hard for many kids because it is a skill they have to develop.

Speaking as a parent, I find the website introduction to the Albert Shanker School to be very innacurate and no longer at all up-to-date. My daughter goes to this middle school and loves it! The school has a great, very forward-looking principal, many excellent teachers, is upgrading its auditorium, has received new grants to improve equipment, has Smart Boards in EVERY classroom, uses iPads in many classrooms, has a newly renovated library, to which children are welcome to come--there are too many improvements to list!

In addition, the school is NOT unsafe at all. I would not send my daughter to an unsafe school. The school challenges her academically. The Albert Shanker School is becoming a real school of the performing arts; it's working to get a full complement of musical instruments again, has a good art program. Its website lists all the teachers, their DOE email addresses, and HW calendars are up on the school's website. The school also has a Facebook page now,with the monthly calendar and other info. on it. The writer of this school's evaluation really needs to come back to the school and update her review. It's too out-of-date! I would ask her to change it, asap!

Not only is there NO support for ESL teachers but there's zero  for special education teachers too. Administration keeps saying that students with IEP's cannot be placed in the SAVE room but they have yet to come up with a solution for those disruptive students.

I would like to say a few things to the staff at Inside Schools. Did principal Sanabria know in advance that you were coming? Could that be the reason why everything seemed ok. You were here for what a few minutes maybe an hour. I'm sorry but that's not enough time to see anything. Why don't you ladies and gentlemen show up unannounced. Then we can talk. 

As far as having a no -nonsense approach that's garbage. Since principal Sanabria arrived at this building student behavior has escalated not decrease. Some of the students do and say whatever they want without being reprimanded. Why... because the principal doesn't want a bad grade on her record and/or survey.  Sometimes one needs to realize that its not about themselves but about the children. It is my belief that all children need rules and those rules need to be reinforced. That is clearly not the case here at PS/IS 127 especially since Sanabria became principal. I believe the reason why some staff members have little to no confidence in principal Sananbria is her NASTY ATTITUDE toward parents, teachers and support staff. When you are new to a position it is wise not to refer to the staff as being FAT!! This woman is Nasty, Disrespectful and A Racist. Don't get me wrong it's alright to embrace your ethnicity but don't degrade another ethnicity just to uplift yours. Has she even taken the time to get to know her staff? No she hasn't. The staff at PS/IS 127 are good people but Sanabria doesn't know that because she hasn't taken the time to find out.

However, I will agree that she has improved the ESL program at the school but ESL just doesn't mean SPANISH SPEAKING STUDENTS and STAFF.  It's about recognizing all second language learners. What about the English language learners that speak Bengali, Urdu, Arabic or French? What happens to them?  Since Sanabria became principal has she hired teachers or support staff that speak those languages. NO SHE HASN'T!! The majority of newly hired teachers have been Latinos and a three or four African Americans, one or two Asians. Which I personally find disgusting!!

Ruffled Feathers!  Seriously, the people at insideschools.org were correct to report that 85% of the staff find the administrators "ineffective."  However, in what sense of the word are they ineffective? I say to insideschools.org, the chancellor and the superintendent to look at them, and rate the administration based on the publicized data!   Speaking of data, if teachers are required to provide data driven instruction, well then so I believe the administrators should be rated by the data that the city collects from the survey.  Are they effective or ineffective?  Do they provide the support that the teachers, and support staff need?  The teaching profession is all about the children, but the constant bickering, and complaining will not change anything about the administrators.  They are actually very smart!  They play the game just the way they are supposed to for the Superintendent and the Chancellor, and yes even insideschools.org fell into their web!  

Not surprisingly, the school was very quiet when they came in to visit.  Not a problem.  However, what happens to the other 99% of times when there are no administrators around to handle the ever growing problem in the middle school!  The AP does his best, but not enough! (But I believe that he doesn't have the support that he really needs, if he did--he would have a better chance of making improvements on the student behavior issue.)  The new administrator seems professional enough and actually has manners, and treats people with respect.  

As for the rest of the administrators, they do what they have to do no matter what.  Yes they do have their downfalls, but they are also human beings, just like us and make mistakes. I am not taking sides here because the only side I am on is that of the student population.  Adults need to behave like adults--and Teachers should be allowed to Teach!  Great leaders set the tone of the environment.  They praise and reward their staff when things are going well.  A great leader will not make his opinion known, but will look at the facts---and act on it appropriately without the personal involvement.  

Unfortunately, there will always be problems in any environment where you have people that don't get along!  So all personal rantings, complaints, and whining is NOT going to solve the heart of the problem.  So with that it is up to the teachers, or anyone that works at PS 127 to make long hard decisions, and decide if they are going to continue in such a hostile environment or get out!  As for me, well my future is mine to decide, and no administrator, chancellor, superindent, or boss is going to tell me that I have to put up with so many obstacles at my job!
