My child is in 7th grade right now. We are lucky to live nearby the school and he got in 6th grade in Honors program because of his good test results in 4th grade. The thing is in Honors program you have to keep at least 80% of all major subject (Ela, Math, SS and Science), otherwise in mid October they will move children around in and out Honors (that happened in the 6th grade).
In mid October of our 7th grade they terminated a class and moved all students to different classes (this can be frustrating to an adjusting child).
Other than that I have had meetings with the office people, dean, pr. assistant and all were very helpful with information and advice to my concerns. I signed for emails and i was effectively informed each week of anything happening in the school. On top of that in 6th grade i demanded a DAILY report from all my child teachers of his perform in the class.. it was really helpful!!
The school is quite big and lots of kids go there, really a diverse culture. The school has several teachers each subject to keep up with student load. 
They separate 6, 7 and 8 graders coming in and out different entrances and having their own floors, lunch times, so practically they never meet. I heard during school hours the inside halls are extremely quiet, even when pupils move from one room to another they are aligned in column and in order, walk quietly and in general i never heard no one had any (safety) problem in that school. Lunch time - they have assigned seats, so the downfall is the children cant actively interact with each other, not until the end of the school day. 
In the end i am very happy with this school, living in such an expensive part of Queens, I am glad at least the education part of our life counts.

My child just graduated from this school.  He had a wonderful academic experience the entire 3 years. He was in the honors class. The teachers challenged them to be the best they could be. There were times that the work could be overwhelming with the projects and tests but that's because Ms. Pavlou just want her students to be prepared for high school. The only thing I wish this school would improve on is the music program. My child was very lucky to have Mr.Arnold as his band teacher  for 2 years. Hopefully the new music teacher will  find a way to get the band active once again. His 2 years as a band member under Mr.Arnold was one of the memorable moments my child had at I.S. 141.
Assemblywoman Aravella Simotas honored four 8th-graders at IS 141 for their essays on Black History. Read more here.

A really amazing school if you manage to get into the special privileged classes where you're allowed to take the regents(I think they added science regents too now?). Liked all of my teachers here in the 3 years I attended, many good ones that inspired me to learn. After this school i went to a [certain] specialized high school and didn't find it that hard to maintain a 95~ average there, of course, with effort applied. But I think if you manage to get into the top classes, (6H1, E1, S1, and their "2 or 3" counterparts) you'll be very well off. 

Downside is if you're not in the top classes, this is still a great school, just slightly less so. Also i don't really believe that the top class student selection is exactly fair. If you're in 6H1, almost definitely 3/4 of the class will go to exclusively E1 or S1 and the other 1/4 go to other "1" in the other academy the 3/4 didn't go to.Usually none fall out of the 1's. 

After this, other kids from lower honors grades [or if they're really good from regular classes] get placed into 7E1 or 7S1. Thing is, after 7th grade, the 8th grade class is generally the same, even if a (E/S)1 gets like a 83ish average. Few new people get in honor classes after 7th grade, since few get removed, the process is very lazy. To get the most out of this school, work hard in 5th grade and 6th grade(maybe) so you land in the top classes.

Overall it's a good school 98/100

The parent of a 6th grader informed Insideschools that IS 141 is now divided in three academies: Einstein, Jewels, and Classics. She praised a  "beautiful program with music" at the beginning of the school year where parents met the teachers, and praised the school's jazz band and dance.

Student Nicole writes to respond to comments about the school's safety: "Even though we have a lot of food fights and fights we still have security guards, teachers and staff members who put our safety in front of everything. I have built good and bad relationships with the dean, principal and teachers but at the end they always seem to care about you."
Ashley, a student, writes that teachers were "always there" for her and she made many friends. "I would have missed out on a lot of things if I went somewhere else."

Marjorie, a student in her last year at Steinway who is about to leave for L.I.C. High School, writes: "I have LOTS of memories from this school, and I'll most definitely miss it." However, she complains about the school's academy system.

Student Shelby S. writes: "141 changed a lot this year, and many say it's 'for the better,' but I [liked] it better like it was before. We're all mixed up with other grades and I hate it. I'm gonna try to get some special activities and days for the 8th-graders like it was before, because we barely get anything."
Ashley, a student, writes: "IS 141Q is the best school. I enjoy getting up in the morning and going to school. The teachers there are really cool and they understand [the students]."
do you have to wear uniform

No. You can wear anything, but of course in the dress code. No spaghetti-straps, super ripped designed jeans that show a lot of skin, and mini shirts, clothes that shows a lot of skin, etc. You know, the usual dress code.

"The school is always full of energy," writes a student. "There's alot of smart people, just that sometimes they get lazy." She worries that "Now that we have academies there is going to be more fights etc." Still, she writes that she is fond of her school, and "something about it makes it so special and so different from other schools."

Student Ginna B. writes, "JHS 141 is a great school, many people say that its a bad school where the kids do whatever they want but its not like that, and it has changed throughout the years. I met many people and I have matured alot in this school. Im gonna miss it very much when graduating next year, it has become like my 2nd home now."

IS 145 has transformed an old storage space into a "wellness wing" where children can go for counseling and support, according to the Democrat and Chronicle. The school serves many new immigrants, homeless children and children who are separated from their parents. "We've made counseling cool," a staffer told the newspaper. 
https://www.democratandchronicle.com/videos/local/communities/time-to-educate/stories/2018/12/19/we-went-school-queens-see-program-thats-helping-students-thrive/2368399002/

ESL teacher, Ryuma Tanaka, is a recipient of the prestigious Big Apple award, which recognizes "exceptional success in instruction, impact on student learning, and overall contributions to school communities," as reported by Chalkbeat.
The IS 145 community dedicated the street corner of 80th street and 34th avenue as "Dr. Dolores Beckham Way" in honor of the school's late principal, DNAinfo reports.
Jackson Heights teacher Ramiro Cruz was arrested for assaulting a student, DNAinfo reports.

Schools Chancellor Carmen Fariña announced that 15 schools with existing Dual Language programs will become Model Dual Language Programs, including IS 145 Joseph Pulitzer, for the 2015-16 school year. School playgrounds will be open to the public afterschool and on weekends. Read more: PS 69 and IS 145 in congested Jackson Heights set to open playgrounds for public use.

IS 145 has an unusual approach to teaching new immigrants English: children write stories about their own lives and read them out loud in front of an audience. The exercise builds confidence and in some cases serves as a catharsis for children dealing with trauma, as an article in Feet in Two Worlds shows.

They weren't posted on the same day. If you look at the end of the posts, it has the true date they were originally posted: May 2008,l Oct. 2007, etc. The date at the top of the posts (10/27/2010)  is just because InsideSchools revamped its comment system so they had to re-post all the old comments. 10/27 is the date they rebooted everything.

I graduated from I.S 145 in 2006, and they were the best three years of my life. I learned so much from the teachers there. Dr. Beckham, in my eyes will always be the best principal ever. It is a great school and the kids that go there are just as great and bright. The school environment was luminous and made you want to learn. I felt safe at the school because the security agents were always on the job. I had a younger brother that passed away in October of 2008, who attended the school as well and although it was a rather short time, he loved that school almost as much as I did. I have made many friends that, till this every day, I am still very close to, mind you I am now a senior in High School. This is a school where the kids will make connections, and learn important values that will stick with them for a life time. I feel truly proud to have graduated from such a great school, and never could I have asked for better teachers and such a caring Principal.

"In January 2007, my husband, Savanna and I paid an unannounced visit to explore this school as an option as Savanna was unhappy where she was at that time," writes a mother, whose daughter Savanna submitted the comment below. "Dr. Dolores Beckham, the principal, and Beatrice Johnson, the assistant principal immediately took time from their day to speak to us at length and explore our concerns about allowing Savanna to transfer to a new school in the middle of 7th grade. Dr. Beckham and Ms. Johnson were and are extraordinary - evidenced in the respectful manner that they spoke to my daughter - their willingness to share of themselves, their wisdom and help her make her first critical decision on her own. Dr. Beckham and Ms. Johnson's obvious devotion to IS 145 was compelling and allowing Savanna to make the decision to transfer was a no-brainer after our initial meeting. Savanna loved her IS 145 days where the staff are dedicated and the children are much valued."

"I transfered to this school in January of 2007. I felt welcomed by classmates who soon became my friends. I found the teachers were great too and I always felt I could go for help whenever I needed it," writes student Savanna. "As for Dr. Beckham, the school prinicipal, I think she is amazing! She has tremendous energy and pride for the school. She really shows how much she cares about the students in every morning announcement. She is a very encouraging person and devoted to our school. Dr. Beckham coordinates trips and activities like school fairs to make IS 145 better for her students."

"IS 145 is a really good school with excellent programs," writes a student. "As I look back I have realized that the teachers go beyond the sky for us. Right now, they're giving us all the information about high schools and it's like our second home. The teachers will not only be there to teach us, but also to be our friend. IS 145 will make you feel welcome the minute you step into the door."
Recent graduate Andrew writes, "It's easy to make friends and a safe enviroment. Although the school is overcrowded it's still a good enviroment. The teachers actually know how to teach."

A recent graduate writes that IS 145 has "great clubs and activities," including a band and television studio, class sizes are "too large" for students to get much individual attention. The after school tutoring is "useful," this student writes.

Principal Dolores Beckham received a 2006 Cahn fellowship, a 15-month program at Teachers College designed to recognize outstanding principals. Cahn fellows attend workshops at Teachers College and continue serving as principal at the school.

An 8th grader says that there are "lots of trips" and the school offers a lot. "It makes me feel like they love us."

An 8th grader says there should be "more clubs" and that the school's computers are broken.

A 6th grade student says that teachers "focus on things kids want to do."

"I personally think I.S. 145 is a great school." writes Monique, who entered the school in October after Hurricane Katrina hit. "They have taken me under their wing and since I came here from Mississippi, my grades have skyrocketed."
"This school taught me a lot of stuff that I didn't know, and I met a lot of new people and made new friends," writes a student.

"In this school I learned how to speak English and live in the USA," writes Michal, a student in the International Bridge Academy for students new to the country. "It is the best school in all of Queens."

Some teachers struggle with classroom management, writes student Hannah. "Many students are rowdy and all they do is talk and carry on," she writes. "At one point the kids in my honors class were throwing paper balls at each other! The teachers think just saying "simmer down" in the front of the class will help, but it won't." She adds that many students do not wear the school uniform, and the school's windows and desks need to be repaired.

Principal Delores Beckham responds that parents voted to have a uniform and all students adhere to it. Classroom management is not a problem at the school, she said, but she agreed that the windows are old, adding that they are scheduled to be repaired.

"Most of the teachers are unhelpful and should not be teaching there at all," writes a 2004 graduate. "The material being taught is too easy and students are not challenged, therefore, making their high school years more difficult."
"This school is the bomb it has great teachers," writes student Naomi.

"I.S. 145 has an amazing teaching staff that is dedicated, for the most part, to turning the school around," writes a student. "However, the standards set for students and the material taught to them is something that they do not deserve. They are not being challenged and because of the rough environment and peer pressure, they feel like they do now want to. Too much of 145 can transform you from a caring student to someone who's first priority is being cool. I know, because I switched from I.S. 145 to M.S. 230 last year, that 145 is far from an ideal school."

"I.S.145 is a good school and has very good teachers," writes a student. "The only problem is that the students there don't take school seriously and do graffiti on tables and walls and rip many things apart in the rooms and halls."

A 2003 graduate writes: "I truly believe that my three years in that school were some of the best years of my life. Although the school has a bad reputation, this is because of the zones. The school is situated in Jackson Heights, a good neighborhood in Queens, NY. Most of the kids who live in Corona (a worse neighborhood in Queens) are zoned to IS 145. ... Because they didn't get spectacular grades in elementary school, their last resort is 145." She continues: "The principal, Ms. Beckham, is one of the most amazing women I've ever met. When I attended 145, the school offered a lot of programs, such as TV Studio, cooking class (home economics), wood shop, and different languages. The teachers loved their work and loved the students. I learned a lot about life, and I learned a lot about myself." She adds: "I now attend Bayside High School, and am enjoying it. Being a student in 145 helped me to get into a good high school. ... It disappoints me that school still has such a bad reputation."

A 7th-grader who has attend the school for three years writes: "This school is really nice. I made a lot of friends." However, he complains that, as a South Asian student, he seen some prejudice at school.
Shanice, a student, writes that although IS 145 may be called "bad and unruly," the principal, Ms. Beckham, is "wonderful" and "trying to make changes."

A student complains: "I think this school is really behind in math. Last year I was at IS 61 and I took integrated mathematics A, this year I was supposed to take Integrated mathematics B. But in this school even the honors classes are behind. We are in 8th grade and we are still learning about adding fractions! I'm being taught things that I already know! I learned all this stuff in 5th grade."

An alumna writes that "IS 145Q wasn't perhaps the best environment for learning," because of fights and unruly student behavior. However, she believes that "because of the teacher's academically fulfilling lessons, I managed to get where I am today." She adds that she does not feel the changes at the school will be beneficial, especially for 8th graders, for whom the elimination of honors classes will make high school admissions more difficult.

A parent writes: "I am not sure about the school academically but I do live across the street and see the daily crowd, and they do seem like an unruly bunch, my child is going to Middle School next year and this school would be ideal but I must say I am somewhat concerned."

"Right now they are changing the school by enforcing uniforms and different academies," writes a student. "What they are doing is taking honor classes and mixing them with regular classes. I believe this is bad because when you are applying to a high school they do not see that in fact you were in an Honors class. I am now going from an honors class to the Law and Humanities Academy. Personally, I know some of the people in my new class have a reputation for being "tough". I get scared that maybe I will be their next target." She writes that she is now afraid of being picked on for being smart and studious.

A student in the honors program writes that although she believes "IS 145 is a very good school," the physical plant could "use a little renovation": "some rooms are falling apart," she writes. "Most of the desks have graffiti. It makes the school look very nasty." She adds that some students in the school are unruly, giving the school "a bad environment."

"This school is changing," writes a student. "There are going to be uniforms and different 'houses,'" he writes. He is unhappy about these changes, which he sees as infringements on student freedom, and thinks that the changes won't improve student behavior.
A Spanish dual language program will start at P.S. 148 in the fall, as reported by the Jackson Heights Post.

PS 148 actually has five dedicated spaces for arts offerings: two for music, one for theater, and two for visual art. As of fall 2017, we also have a new principal who is focused on creating a vibrant, energized staff and a warm, welcoming school community. InsideSchools should come give us a visit and a review!

I have a daughter going into second grade, and I have been more and more pleased with the school every year she is there.  Her teachers have been very kind and creative, while academically solid. The dual language program is a fantastic opportunity. My daughter reads, writes, and speaks, not to mention does math, in English as well as Spanish. Family and friends are amazed at this ability, something you would not get at most charter or private schools.  The parent coordinator is very responsive as are the administrators. I wish that there were more forums in which parents could discuss ideas without having to run for office in the PTA, but other than that, I am happy we stuck with our neighborhood school.
Chancellor Fariña announced former PS 149 principal, Milady Baez will come out of retirement to run a newly independent office of English Language Learners in the DOE. Read more here.
DNAinfo highlights PS 149's dual language program as an effective model for teaching children both English and Spanish from an early age. Read more here.

I had the pleasure to work as a first grade teacher at this school.  It is with first hand experience that I say the teachers and staff at this wonderful school go above and  beyond to make sure all their students have a first class education.  I moved to NJ and now teach there.  I have to say that everything I learned at 149 has helped me to achieve higher goals in NJ. If I move back to NY the first thing I will do is go to 149 and beg for a chance to teach there again.  What a wonderful school!
Christine Stewart

This school is amazing.  I have such fond, great memories of it.  I went to school here 1986-1993.  There were two teachers specifically who were so dedicated and caring - Ms. Thompson, who I believe is still there, and Mr. Pisacano who is now a principle at another school.  I went back to visit Ms. Thompson when I was in college and she's still amazing.
the parent coordinator is no longer Yolanda. She left the school in 2006 because she was in an accident. This page needs to be updated!
A 3rd grader says of her class, "we work together and share thoughts and ideas." She says she has learned that it is important to "not be impatient."

A father says "the teachers work hard." He adds that student-of-the month ceremonies are held during PTA meetings and that the school's parent coordinator arranges workshops for parents on a variety of topics.
"I love my school very much," writes student Yasmen, who notes that her 4th-grade teacher had 37 students.

Jennifer, a former student who attended the school for four years, writes: "It was a great experience. ... I really miss it and my unforgettable teachers." She mentions her teachers Mrs. Baez and Mrs. Magary in particular.

Bianca, a former student, writes: "This school may be overcrowded, but the teachers and staff are exceptional. They treat the children so well and make certain to keep the children safe. I know for a fact that the faculty work very hard to help anyone and everyone they can because my mother, Yolanda Remusat, is the parent coordinator. She brings work home EVERY night! I am not saying this just because she is my mother, but she does help people, not just parents, but students and staff as well. My mother ALWAYS has a smile plastered on her face, even when she is feeling down. She says hello to everyone, even if they don't say hello back." She adds: "Honestly, the school and staff has come a very long way. The children love their teachers and love learning. Sometimes, I go to work with my mother in the mornings and pass classrooms where the children are reading or painting, they look so happy and it puts a smile on my face. The school also has Learning Leaders. They are volunteers who are certified to work in the classrooms with the children."

"I have just heard from teachers of this school that class room sizes are WAY over the limit," writes a parent. "I know of one fourth grade teacher who for the 2004-2005 found out today that she has 37 students! This is outrageous... Other fourth grade teachers have between 32-37 children."
PS 150 President Carmen Parache has created an environment where students learn by hands-on investigation and engagement with their culture and community, Queens Latino reports (en español).

Hi, I'm considering this school for next year (pre-k) and I would love to have any updates about the drama I've been reading about the teachers and the principal. Otherwise it looks like a great school.

PS 150 has a new garden, thanks to a partnership with the Horticulture Society of New York and funding from the Greening Western Queens Fund. The school is one of six in the neighborhood to get new learning gardens. Read more here.

My son just started kindergarten in the TAG program this year and I am totally amazed with his progress. In one month he has gone from letter recognition to reading simple books and writing simple sentences. This is really a wonderful school and I am very happy that he was placed in this program. Ms. Parache is a wonderful principal and I have nothing but good things to say about her. She has gone out of her way to help me. The administrative staff has been wonderful, trying to help with any problems and informing the parents of any issues. My son loves his teacher Ms. Chance and looks forward to going to school. This website however, should be updated because the kindergarten is housed in the annex which was a Catholic school not upstairs from a billiard parlor. The students have plenty of space with their own cafeteria, and outside playground.

I am a student here. When i graduate this year i will cry my eyes out! Mrs Monaster was the teacher i ever had! i hope she keeps teaching for a long time! BTW I love our graduation song! Cant wait for graduation, prom, and the senior trip.

i bet this is emmanuela! im in .... ms. rahner and ms.hernandez's class. i <3 the graduation song to! 

p.s.- love my teachers<3

I agree with the comment from a parent about Ms. Parache. It's like her energy trickles down into a bad atmosphere at the school.  Now that my daughter is out of there are in a much more relaxed and happy school, I think the tensions at PS 150 are due to the principal's antics and abuse of power.

I agree with the last comment.  At first, I did not have a problem with the principal, but after 2 years in the school, I've come to hear all sorts of things from the teachers and the parents.  The best teachers have been forced to leave because of her.  My direct  experience is not good either. Ms. Parache is rough and she doesn't even realize how much of an authoritarian she is. If I had a choice, I'd send my son elsewhere, but this school is the best in my district.
The Principal is a product of Joe Klein's "Principal Academy" she does not have enough college credits to be a teacher.
In order to become a principal, you must first be a teacher and then go to school again and go to the next level.

Not true. You can be a file clerk at a motor vehicle office, but if you can get someone to nominate you to the Principal's Academy and then endure 14 months of anti-public school indoctrination, you too can be a principal.
It is sad for me to hear that a Principal doesn't have to be a teacher first. It doesn't even make sense. How does a principle get replaced then?

I am a substitute teacher who frequents different schools within the Queens area. I can differentiate between a good school and a mediocre school.  I can honestly say I am very happy to have chosen PS 150 instead of P.S 122 for my son's education, given that I had a choice between both. I don't exaggerate when I say, in my opinion PS. 150 is one of the top elementary schools in the city due to the wonderful principal, Ms. Parache, and her surrounding teachers with whom she works very closely with. Ms. Parache consistently looks after the welfare of our children and provides a safe and healthy environment for them.	 I will never  forget her wise advice when I came to her and told her that my son passed the Gifted and Talented test but the Board of Education could not find the application. She advised me to 'keep calling, be consistent and stay on top of it'; I did exactly that and now my son is a student in the Gifted and Talented program. 	P.S 150 also has some of the best teachers in Queens, NY. They challenge and work hard with the students to ensure that they receive the best education possible so that they are ready to attend prestigious middle and high schools after graduating. My daughter attended P.S 150 in the fifth grade and she now attends a private school on merit scholarship. She is a product of the education she retained at P.S 150 and her year there has helped her become the scholar she is today. I am very pleased with all P.S 150 has done for my children. It is truly a gem in New York City.
Hey, there, I hope you see this.  My son (zoned for 122) just got placed in the TAG program at 150.  Anything you can tell me about the program, and how you feel the two schools compare?  Thanks.

The biggest problem, by far, is the Principal. Parents and teachers continuously express concern and disapproval, and there's a very high turnaround of teachers...  She does manage to bring in some good teachers, but many leave after one year or even before the school year is over.   Parent involvement is only okay.

My daughter's pre-k experience has been fantastic. Her teacher is warm, organized, efficient, experienced and best of all has made my daughter love going to school. I don't know much about the upper grades but the preschool couldn't be better.
Confirming - I toured the school today and the Kindergarten annex does indeed have an outdoor playspace and we were told that the kids get outside for recess 20 minutes per day, weather permitting.

I wish there were more comments... it's good to hear different perspectives. We're parents of a child here, and have mixed feelings. Too much homework of a mindless variety, a clear sense that the high levels of administration are out to lunch, but--on the positive side--really great families, strong teachers, nice kids, and a high level of academic achievement.
The kindergarten annex has moved to 44th St. between Skillman and 43rd Ave. It is in an old Catholic school, I believe. There is outdoor space as well as a gym and library.
School with very nice teachers and really bad principal. She makes teachers life miserable. She wants to be herself number one at any price. Everybody wants to leave. I don't like that!!

how do you know that everyone wants to leave?
 went there and all the teachers i had loved the school.
" I love this school!" writes Stephanie, a recent graduate of the school. "It has great opportunities for parents and kids. It has after school programs and it is around a great neighborhood."

A parent writes: "My daughter was in the gifted program and it was a wonderful experience. The chance to interact with peers from different backgrounds and cultures was extremely valuable. The students are motivated to learn. The teachers were top-notch." He adds: "Friends of ours have spent tens of thousands of dollars on private education for their children, and, in my opinion, my daughter's education at P.S. 150 was much better than theirs."

A student writes: "This school is a great school because [there are] a lot of great opportunities. In this school there so many nice teachers. Best of all you don't get a big pile of homework, you or the kids will only get like 3 homeworks a day."
Leo, a recent graduate, calls PS 150 a "great school" with "great teachers" and an "awesome principal." He adds that the students get a good balance of homework and playtime.

Its true I recently graduated from this school and it was the best school ever I wish I could go back. I would only if  they had a talented and gifted 6th grade class. This school has given me so many opportunities,friends and chances to be taught by some of the best teachers in Queens.
                                             - Class of 2011,5th grade, I.D

"A great place to make longterm friends," writes Yasumine M., a student. "I went there in second grade and graduated with several awards. I'm currently in high school. Most of the teachers are great and the principal is highly dedicated to her students. Alright, I'll admit that sometimes it's suffocating with all the rules. But it's a place where you'll get discipline where as in the future you won't."

151 has come a long way, but don't let it fool you, it has a long way to go.  Most of the teachers are good, but there is always at least one teacher on each grade that isn't as good as the others.  My child hardly ever spent time in the "beautiful" library as most of the times his class was scheduled the visit was cancelled.  What's the point of even having it then? My son had the same book for just about 2 months!  There are very few school assemblies or programs that are brought in, minimal trips, and few extra curriculars.  It's nice that they have a music teacher, but explain to me why my child didn't have music for 2 years in a row?  I think I heard that there may be an art teacher now, but who knows if they even see all of the students.  Oh and the gardens mentioned in an earlier post?  Take a look at the front of the building, what garden?! Luckily, my child was blessed with great teachers for the most of his time at this school, but still a clearer picture of 151 needs to  be reflected on these boards.
The Department of Education will remove transportable classroom units (TCUs) from PS 151 and relocate PS 225 students studying there, DNAinfo reports.

I am disappointed in PS151, they boast a beautiful library but it is just for show. It reminds me of my mother's living room sans the plastic covered furniture.  My child has yet to step inside of it this school year. What is the point of having it, if it is NOT being used. I will be going elsewhere next year. I am in the process now of visiting other schools.

PS 151 has a new garden, thanks to a partnership with the Horticulture Society of New York and funding from the Greening Western Queens Fund. The school is one of six in the neighborhood to get new learning gardens. Read more here.

Parent: My son will be going to ps151Q pre-k, but my concern is that i'm not gueting much of information about uniform the shool require.. So far what i heard about this school is that student must wear uniform... If anyone knows about this please let me know thx....
My daughter attended Pre-K at the school last year and a uniform was not required for Pre K.

A substitute teacher complains that the "Principal talked down to me in a condescending manner..." She said she did not receive needed assistance in "removing an unruly disrespectful student who became threatening" and was told she should have had something for the student to do. "I was not allowed to file incident report and forbidden to talk to anyone!"

I ENROLLED MY CHILD HERE THIS YEAR . I HAVE TO SAY THE STAFF TRIES REAL HARD. THEY ARE DEALING WITH ALOT OF CHILDREN WITH DISIPLINE ISSUES. HOWEVER THE PRINCIPLE IS NOT MY CUP OF TEA. VERY RUDE AND UNFRIENDLY ....JASON RIVERA

I think three years have gone by and the Principal has not made an impression  he hasn't stopped the problem with the discipline...and he get get along with his staff....he doesn't care about the kids and is disrespectful with the parents....he should of been remove from his position a long time ago...
Opps sorry! As I was saying Mr.Goldner is a very good priceable. He is really funny because he want us to be happy. He probably knows what we do if we weren't happy.

Actually I am a student from P.S.151 and we do have music and art.  Many teachers aren't mean at all they only get bad when student are loud or driving them crazy. Other than that the teachers are nice.

My son just started PS 151 in November 2011.  His 3rd grade teacher is great and the social worker was very helpful when enrolling my son.  But, there is some down fall with the students..  At lunch my son told me that the children pushes and curses on the playground.  He came home wit hthis big black and blue on his knee cap from being pushed by a older child.  The students needs to more discipline and it should start at home.  Its not the schools fault,.

Principal Jason Goldner was one of the lowest-rated principals on the 2010-11 School Survey. Among teachers, 80 percent reported that they believe the principal is a weak manager and they don't trust the principal.
The DOE needed to replace a teacher????  What teacher????  There was no teacher replaced!

There is going to be an EMERGENCY PA meeting on Monday, September 26, 2011 in the auditorium.  Please be there for all the students at PS 151Q.  Even if this doesn't affect you or your child directly, please be there to voice your opinion.  If it's not your child now, it may be in the future!  Thank you and see you all there!
Please update... We have a NYS certified Music Teacher.  We also have a teacher that does art.

The Bd of Ed shut down the French DLP at this school suddenly yesterday and without notice to parents and families, they ushered our minor children into new classes just like that! Today we met with Asst Vice Principal who stated it was due to enrollment for such program, but if it were on the chopping block, how do they justify doing it mid-day, disrupting the class and not notifying anyone until our kids get home? They must have known earlier, how can they do this two weeks into the start of the school year? May of us moved here just for the DLP, and many of us need to scramble now to find a good school, because PS151 is a failing school overrall, and Ms. Delhomme and the French DLP was the only gem at that school!

First of all, it was the Principal who shut down the French program and 2 other CLASSES!!!!!  This was not only done to the French DL students.  This affected 3 classes.  It is ironic how only the French class was reopened due to outside circumstances!  Let's protect ALL children!!!!  As far as the teacher and the French DLP being the only gem at this school, you are very mistaken.  There are excellent teachers there as well as "not so good" teachers as there are in ALL NYC public schools.  As for me, I have decided to leave my daugher in the class that she was placed because I noticed rigor in the new class and my child was extremely happy.  In one day, this was demonstrated.  I'm not bashing anyone, I'm just stating that there are some EXCELLENT teachers in that school!

PS 151 ends French immersion program - then revives it next day. According to the DOE, the school needed to replace a teacher. According to the school's parent coordinator, there was a misunderstanding and the dual-language program was reinstated the day after it was cancelled.

I'm sorry to say, there was no misunderstanding.  The principal realized he couldn't mess around with the parents from the French DLP.  They are very involved!  That is excellent on their part!!!  Fight for your children!  I wish all parents fought for ALL children and that ALL three classes would have been reopened.  In this matter, people would have been free to choose where they would place their child.

We would like  to enroll our daughter in the French-dual language program for 2011-2012 (Kindergarten) -, and I am not sure how well all the posts here reflect the quality of the school. The quality of the french dual language program seems to have a high rate of satisfaction from parents, and I am really pleased with that. However, there are quite a few complaints about the students behaviour with instances of violence, and also "abusive" teachers behaviour towards students. As a prospective parent, I am concerned. I would like to know how frequent are these instances of violence. How does that compare to other schools in the area, like PS152.

Keep your daughter at P. S. 152.  The reason for students' behavior with instances of violence is that there is lack of discipline from the Principal.  Children need to be held accountable for their actions regardless of their status.

I am very happy that I sent my child to pre-k at PS 151. I  was very hestitant at the begining. I heard from previous PS 151 pre-k's parents that pre-k is good, and they were absolutely right. I have talked with other pre-k parents from other schools (from Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens, private) and they were impressed with the work that my child did. I am so proud of her pre-k teachers. Unfortunately, I have to say the higher grades are not so good. Maybe looking at what makes a good pre-k class is good way to start.

Our daughter is in her second year at 151's French-dual language program.  She began with no French experience at all (English and Spanish fluency).  So far she's doing excellent and loves the school.  I look forward to how she'll speak French at the end of the program.
The school itself used to have a low rating but has made great strides since Mr. Goldner took over as principal.  I think he's doing a wonderful job.

I am glad that she is in the dual language program because I have heard that some of the other classes have had a lot of fighting, etc.  I don't blame the kids as I have seen some VERY disrespectful parents there.  I was at a breakfast with the principal and one parent went into a fit because her child would have to go to summer school.  The mother admitted she never read any of the letters sent home and never got involved in anything to do with the school (so what do you excpect?).  This lady was from across the street and made a complete ass of herself including cursing in the hallway (loudly and after swearing how she was going to be a better parent and a part of the school) afterward.  Mr. Goldner asked her to stop and everything started all over again.

What impressed me was how many other women were there from other countries and had some trouble understanding the language....  BUT were a lot more involved in the school as a whole and respectful of everyone else.  Too bad the school doesn't have more of them and their children.  

Unfortunately 151 does have some children and parents that have the "give me, give me, give me, and give me more" mentality.

My daughter is on dual language - 2nd Grade. Her teacher is wonderful and my little start to have conversation in french...  My house is far from the school but I am so please with the school that I am putting my little boy next year at PS 151 too.

First of all the crossing guard is an employee of the Police Dept., call city hall and the Dept. of Ed. and COMPLAIN loudly.  They will not listen to the school, parent's voices are the only ones that the DOE listens to.  Living in the projects has nothing to do with how well our children are listened to, I have no problems with my child being listened to and I do not live in the projects.  Is your child respectful?  or a spoiled brat?  Maybe your child or you complain and don't offer any solutions to the problem(s).  If you're not part of the solution, then you're part of the problem.  Are you an invisible parent and do not attend these breakfast with the Principal, or participate in Parents Association activites?  When was the last time you voluntered at PS151?  or even showed your face at a social function.  Make arrangements to arrive at work late or leave early -- your child's education deserves it.  As far as discipline in the lunchroom, children arrive with no respect for others or themselves. Period.  I have seen your child or someone else's behave very badly.  You would be shocked if you saw how badly the children behave at lunch.  It is a disgrace.

I can happily say that as a true concerned parent I have transferred my child to PS 70 where the parents are well informed by the principal and is doing great! Oh and the best part of all is I don't have to choose between making a living and interacting with the principal.

...too bad that you feel that you "don't have to choose between making a living and interacting with the principal", I am sure that your non-involvement in your child's education will pay-off in the long run.  Unfortunately for him/her pay-off poorly.   Being involved with the principal should be viewed as an opportunity to help build a better school community, you obviously do not care about community building; and only care about being informed (passively) and not being an active part of the decision making process.

As the parent of a student in 151 I have to admit that I am not impressed with the school at all and can not wait to transfer my daughter out of there. If your child does not live in the projects across the street from the school they have no interest in your child. The school aides are horrible and my child comes home everyday with the story of a new fight in school where the children go unpunished. I can happily say that she has been blessed with amazing teachers but there needs to be better supervision. There has not been a crossing guard on the corner of 50th st in a month and when I called to complain about it I was told there was nothing they could do about it!! I felt as if I was being told my child's safety doesn't matter!!! As for the breakfasts with the principal be honest no one really goes to those things, people in this neighborhood work who really has the time to take off from work to attend those things. They still have a long way to go!

First off all a lot of people love this school. 2nd your daughter may not be telling the truth. She may have caused those problems. The police guard can't help a lot of kids at once. What happens if you were the guard? I bet you could only help your daughter and let everyone else suffer. Mr.Goldner at breakfast with the p. he tries to get the problems fixed! Try to get your facts right before you post. Next time you post something bad about the school I will have way more good fact then you have bad facts!

I am sorry but please do not post these negative comments if you can not commit to the school and see how you can improve it.  Only showing up and complaining about things that are not happening is wrong.  In a time where all school budgets are being cut and schools are struggling to keep programs and important things alive for your children we don't need complaining parents but involved parents.  For a principal to ask you why you are a stranger, it shows that he is a caring one. Please be aware that being involved in the school, understanding what they are doing and where they might need help will only help your child and ultimately hits every issue that concerns your child.

My daughter is not yet a student at 151, but based on the two meetings for potential parents in the Dual Language Program, I am going to try to get her enrolled for 2011-12. I was very impressed with the principal, the parent coordinator, and the French teacher. I am encouraged by the school's funding for next year (they got a $1.5M grant) and the involvmen of the International Baccalaureate and the French Embassy, and feel this might be a rare opportunity to get in on the ground floor of a great program.

Really, he received that money?  Where is that money???  He just closed classes, put children in other rooms and is using teachers with almost 10 years experience as substitute teachers.  The french class was reopened because Bloomberg was hanging out with the French President when this all happened.  But our other children are in larger classes.  For the record, I'm happy that my daughter was put in one of the other classes because when she was returned to the French class after it was reopened, I asked to return her to the other class.  These other teachers work hard with these children.  There is rigor in these classes and the children get homework.  But I still would like to know where is this money??????

I am very excited about your post.  I too am planning to relocate to NY and I am contemplating to enroll my daughter there as well for the 2011-12 school year.  I currently live in FL and my daughter has been in a similar program here since KG.  It is a wonderful opportunity because the IB program is excellent and I would be thrilled that she could continue her studies of French and IB program at PS 151.

In the beginning I was very excited to enroll my son in PS 151Q where they offer french as a dual language.  My kids had been living in a francaphone country in the prior year and I very much wanted to maintain french as a second language for them.  The private french schools were way out of my budget so this school was a prayer answered.  The year started off fine which I must confess I was very relieved to see because my son is very distractable and highly active.  To make matters worse he had no english exposure for a whole year so he is more than a bit rusty in his language arts skills.  Afterwards, I began to feel that my son's teacher and given up on him.  I eventually went in to discuss on 3 separate occasions my concerns about my son with the assitant principals and principal (each one separately).  I had no appointsments on 2 of the days that I was received and I felt quite welcomed.  In each meeting I felt like I was being listened to, I felt like I was understood and I left feeling that they were going to help me find solutions.  As far as my son's language arts needs Mr. Goldner and my son's teacher gave me very useful feedback at the Parent/Teacher's Conference.  I learned from them a keyword, fluency, which has helped me to find a helpful supplemental literarcy program.  I hope my family's experience at PS151Q continue on an upward trend with minors dips if any.

I am a parent of the French Dual Language program and I am very happy with it and with this school.  My son was one of the first students in the program and I have seen great improvements on his part on all levels, reading English and French, Math and much more.  He loves the school and I will enroll my other son as well.  The PTA and the parents of the Dual Language program are hosting a movie night Nov. 19th at 6pm in the school.  Please come and join us to talk to parents of both classes K and 1/2 grade.  Here you can ask your questions and see for your self.

Maybe you need to look deeper, if your child can not read then get him the tutoring help this school offers.  My child can read very well and is above level, he is in first grade and is reading chapter books already.  I have spoken to many parents and this comment is false.

I don't know if you know anything of what is going on at this school, but this principal is doing a lot for the school so far and this is only his 3rd year. Some of the new things that are happening are a new math program, a new science lab, having all the tutoring help for the kids, parent association having one or 2 events a week, he got a grant to make the school an international baccalaureate school, the French Daul Language program, a Spanish education class for all kids, implementing an environmental education program to the school and these are only some of the things he is bringing to the school.  Please get involved in the school and see what is going on before you start saying negative things about this great school.

I am satisfied with p.s 151 school.  My son is doing very good in French class.  My other son achieved high  grades in citywide tests. and hope they'll do better in next classl.In my opinion principal is doing very hard work and he is spending a valuable time for our kids future.We should get involved as a parents in school activities and participate in school events.

I am very happy to have my son in the French dual language program.  This is his second year and I plan to have my 2nd (ho is in the Pre-K program) child start the French one next year.  I love the staff and the principal, they have been very helpful and open to all concerns I might have or questions.  I see all the hard work the principal and the staff is making to make this a better school for all the students there.  As in all schools parent participation is very important to helping the school improve as well.  People out there that are only complaining about all these great things the staff is doing, please go and get involved to help improve this school, that has so much to offer.

As a parent of one of the Dual Language program student for the second year, I must say I am happy it is still going on. Yes the school needs improvement but it is on its way to getting it, especially if we all get involved as parents. The school also received a grant to become an international baccalaureate magnet school. It is centrally located to all Queens parents interested in their kids getting languages as part of their curriculum from an early age. French and Spanish are both in the works now, it's a good start and not many public elementary schools can say the same.

Well we have made it through the 1st month of the 2010/2011 school year, what have you done lately to make your school a better place? Yes, I said your. Did you attend the "meet your teacher" night. Most of the staff was there for you, on their own time, did you make the effort? Have you read with your child? Do you talk with them? How about volunteer in your child's classroom? Remember, education starts at home. It is your resposibility to be a part of your child's education.

Dear concern Parents & Staff, I am so glad that we have parents & staff that feel that our school has grown the last few years as well as setbacks with issues that I hope we can improve. We must stand together to make P.S. 151 the school that our community & neighborhood deserve and wants. But, we need more parents involved in our school so that they know that we mean business. We want a great education for our children just like the private & charter schools or even better. OUR CHILDREN DESERVE IT. Yes, some days it feels as if it is a losing battle and that we are not being heard. But, united they will hear every word. P.S. 151 has a lot of great teachers that want to teach our children but moral is down. Change is good sometime but the staff & there leader needs to remember that we are all here for the children, our childrenâ€¦ It has been 3 years with the new principal & he along with the SLT team & the PA invited several new things to our school. The French Dual class, new curriculum, NYJTL after school tennis, all the exciting workshops the Parent Coordinator has, etc. Even though the Board of Education is cutting money all the time we are trying our hardest to keep our children up to leave. Although, somethingâ€™s that he has done has set parents off as well as the PA. I hope that together the principal, staff, PA and Parents will always address them & grow from them with every party leaving knowing that we have helped our school become stronger. To all of the parents who don't discipline your children at home the only thing that I have to say to you is START. So is doing homework with your child, get off the sofa and turn off the soaps, a Kindergarten to 3rd Grade child needs to be told to do their homework. Turn off the X-Box, PSP, etc., and read to your child, or do other things that stretch their imaginations. The teachers and staff work very hard to educate your child, but without you their time is wasted. Set a good example for your child, let them see you read a book, make an effort to learn something new everyday you would be amazed how much you don't know. A parent writes: "The teachers (especially Mrs. Sharma from kindergarten) in this school do a commendable job by paying attention to individual students. Especially as the children hail from multi-cultural backgrounds, the teachers sense the difficulty that the immigrant children face learning an altogether new language, teaching methods, culture, and values!"

Parent Sheila Ahmed writes: "This is an average school. There is not a great emphasis placed on giving children a progressive education, perhaps this is due to the high immigrant population. Also, parents are not allowed into the building when they drop off their children. This really seems to hinder parental involvement and parents getting to know each other, unless they happen to meet at the school bus stops. I think the school should try and have a more 'open-door' policy. Security is ultra-tight, its like you're sending your children off to a prison." She adds: "We are looking into other schools because of this and the lackluster academics."
Rezwan, a student, writes: "This is the best school in the world and I [would] like to complement [the school] on its good students and good teachers ... and the principals who lead the school."

"PS 152 is a great school," a parent writes. "The student population is diverse, yet there is a shared sense of the importance of education. This is most definitely a multicultural school where all the children have the opportunity to thrive." She also praises the staff, saying that "the teachers are wonderful, very skilled, enthusiastic, and involved."

Schools Chancellor Carmen Fariña announced that 15 schools with existing Dual Language programs will become Model Dual Language Programs, including PS 166 Henry Gradstein, for the 2015-16 school year. The schools will receive $10,000 for multilingual instructional materials and staff will have ongoing professional development. Read more here.

As a parent I was informed by one of the teachers that the school received HIGHLY DEVELOPED on a formal Quality Review. A quality review is when independent representative visits the school and conducts a thorough evaluation. Including parent interviews, classroom visitations and thorough analysis of classrooms, curriculum, assessments and instruction.  Highly Developed is the highest rating and is difficult to achieve.  Very few schools in D30 have achieved this status. 166 is about quality and substance not just a pretty showcase! I'm so glad I choose this school 3 years ago. Many parents spoke highly of other school in the district, however in talking with them now we made the right choice. Go with your gut..just because a school has a good reputation dowa not mean they are still providing a quality education.

Review above and post below are MISLEADING. Students entering the PS166 Gifted and talented program from 2013 on will NOT have priority at the IS126 Middle Gifted and Talented School. There is no assured path to a gifted and talented middle school from PS166 for incoming students. AVOID PS166 if you do not want your child to be tested for middle school.

http://schools.nyc.gov/NR/rdonlyres/D5369995-5FC0-41F8-BF1A-6E8BAC200A23/144097/30QTBD_Q126_Q017_EIS_vFinal.pdf

http://news.yahoo.com/blogs/lookout/years-recess-erosion-schools-try-kids-moving-again-085309920.html

Great review of the school's wellness program initiative.

The school has changed drastically since this review was conducted. It is my child's second year there and it gets better everyday. The new principal is young, enthusiastic and very open to parent involvement. Over the past two years alone they have implemented Tai CHi, fitness breaks, a successful career day, science fair, at least 3 performances per year. The performances included at least 10 classes and are made up of songs, dances and skits from students ranging from Pre-K to 5th. There is an ongoing garden and club, smartboards in at least 95% of the classrooms. They have a beautiful  well stocked library and a full size gym. Gym is serious business at the school, the gym teachers conduct formal Phys. Ed. instruction with warm-ups and drills. Students play basketball, soccer, and other sports. The have a very successful Dual Language program and a flourishing G&T program. The G&T program started with one class about three years ago and has grown to two classes per grade which is a first in the district. The teachers in G&T are creative, enthusiastic  and experienced. It is a big school with a large enrollment but the school runs like clockwork and never feels crowded.

Current G&T students at PS 166 will now be automatically transferred to a new gifted middle school program the city is launching this fall at IS 126 in Long Island City. Previously PS 166's G&T program had been the only one in the district without an automatic middle school transfer. Read more here.

Parents of students in PS 166's G&T program are upset about a proposed new middle school program for gifted students in District 30, arguing that seats should be guaranteed to kids from PS 166, who currently have no designated placement after fifth grade. Read more here.

This is a very old posting. Mrs. Farrell left the school in the middle of the 2010-2011 school year. Ms. Geller took over as acting principal and was subsequently hired as principal beginning this school year, 2011-2012. She has been a super positive force, with a young mind and a desire to change things for the better, not only inside but outside the school. We recently received a makeover from NYCares.org and are in the process of setting up a school garden that the children will use as part of their science program. I am a parent of a child in the first grade dual language program. My other child will be joining the school in the 2012-2013 school year for Kindergarten. I cant say enough how much my first child has excelled here. They could use a good outdoor space, right now it is small, but I just make sure my child gets a lot of outdoor time after school weather permitting.

I think you need to visit this school again. Your review is out of date. The Dual Language program is highly successful and there are  students enrolled from the start who didn't speak Spanish or English. The new principal is accessible to all parents and is very dedicated to the students. PS 166  now houses a district G&T program that has grown pass all expectations and even though the courtyard is small, all of our classes are taken out side for recess and the kids and parents love it.

My daughter attend to dual language program and she loves her teachers; Mrs. Ramirez and Mrs. Ioannou. She enjoys going school, and learning very well. There are many good teachers there but it is true that there are some teachers who does not seems qualified. Some of the office staff are very rude and speak with no courtesy to the parents or visitors (I often want to cover my daughters ears.) It is unfortunate to have these people who destroy the reputation of other great teacher's hard work. It seems former principal, Mrs. Janet Farrell did not care those too much. I hope new Principal I.A., Mrs Geller will act quickly for change and hire appropriate teachers and office staff.

Out of the 700 schools tested for unsafe levels of lead in the water from their water fountains, PS 171 produced 17 out of the 132 samples that showed unsafe levels of lead, DNAinfo reports.

"I have 2 daughters attending PS 171, they have been in this school since they were 3 years old. Some of the teachers are indeed snobish but for the most part, they are wonderful. I must commend the new Parent Coordinator she is doing a splendid job helping the parents, she is teaching English as a Second Language to parents in the morning and always tries her best to help everyone. No school is perfect, but, I must commend PS 171 on a job well done."

"The Parent Coordinator is no longer Maggie Nieves. After 5 fantastic years, Maggie decided it was time to move on. She resigned as of April 4,2008. The current Parent Coordinator is Dezorrie Reyes. She is a wonderful new addition to the school."

"My daughter is in Pre-K and she loves the teacher and has lots of fun," writes parent Tina Carlson. "I am very concerned about the lack of organization skills of the administration. The principal did not offer a response to the above comment.

"I like the school. My son is learning well and the teaching is very good," said Marisol Cervantes, a 4th grade parent who received her GED from a local community organization and now teaches English to other PS 171 parents.

This is a terrific school. Every time I walk in, it's like I'm walking into the best kept secret in Queens.  The class sizes are great! My child is in his first year (6th) and I have yet to meet a teacher new to the school so it looks like teacher retention is pretty good. My child is a participant of the ASD Nest program that is new to the school this year and everything seems to be going well.  The speech therapist of the program is a seasoned ASD Nest educator too!  Having transferred from a non-public school to having IS 204 to being my child's first public school, I have been nothing but impressed.  The faculty has been awesome about incorporating assistive technology as well. They are clearly open to concepts for Universal Deslgn for Learning.

My child is also a participant of the Magnet STEM program and science seems to be a big part of school. Not only do they have an enrichment teacher who is a certified gifted ed teacher, but the school has many science-based afterschool programs (1- Intrepid Museum A/S program in our school and 2- Citizen Science - kids study ecology with researchers for later publication).  These afterschool programs also host during-school field trips and so on top of the frequent field trips he goes with his class, my child ends up going on a lot of field trips! 

There are other programs at IS 204. I've heard great things about the Dual Language program and how well the students are doing there.  Additionally, there are two other major afterschool programs. (Beacon and City Year) Beacon, operated by the Greater Ridgewood Youth Council has a large variety of programs and City Year, staffed by AmeriCorps volunteers not only offer an afterschool program, they also support the school in the classroom and even on field trips! 

As a parent of a child with special needs, it's so great to have frequent conversations with administration, teachers, and even City Year afterschool program staff, both by email and phone.  The school also uses Pupilpath to communicate grades. Everyone is so responsive. I've been quite grateful. We are very happy here.
The Department of Education has announced that IS 204 will have a Spanish dual language program from the start of the 2016-2017 school year.
Best skool in NYC. I'm in a cool way

We are very new to 212, and started the year looking forward to being involved in the school and our son's education. Unfortunately, we have been unimpressed  to date with the teacher, the approach to education including: little communication with parents (no email??), excessive and ridiculous homework, little to no art in kindergarden, over reliance on disciplinary tactics rather than incentives, not enough time for exercise, and expecting 4-5 year olds to sit for hours at a desk rather than incorporate creative play, dance and art education into the curriculum. If you're looking for a progressive, creative education... and to be involved with your child's education beyond doing hours of homework... this is not the place.

My son has completed 2-4 grade at this school with honors class 3-4 grades.  We are extremely happy with our experience.  The homework level is appropriate, teachers seem happy and responsive to concerns.  They have let know if something seems to be going on with my child. Nice computer lab.  Music and art seem limited, but overall my son is having a good educational experience.

The teachers work EXTREMELY hard in keeping the school afloat. However, I am concerned with the direction that the school is heading under the current administration. There are constant interruptions over the speaker, last minute notices that are sent out on the day of an event, and a lack of an ESL/bilingual program. ESL students cannot possibly be serviced by teachers who are IN THE PROCESS of getting their ESL certification. Disruption is also caused by constant changes in the schedule almost every other day. Favoritism runs rampant in the administration and those who speak out are black-listed. The lack of professionalism in the school is appalling.

i dont have nothing else than thanks to the staff of PS212 Q , we as parents feel that the staff are very professional y and helpful in all the way. i HAVE 4 CHILDREN ASSISTING TO THE SCHOOL AND THEY LOVE IT!!!!!!. iT IS A GREAT SCHOOL AND THE PRINCIPAL MS ELLIS AND ASSISTANTS PRINCIPALS ARE DOING A GREAT JOB AS SAME AS OLGA FLORES EXCELLENT PARENT  COORDINATOR.

This is an amazing place.  It has an incredibly dedicated, fun and caring staff, with years and years of experience.  The principal, Ms. Ponella, is outstanding--visionary really.  The school's core belief is simple: every child is capable of excellence, and pre-sorting children into restrictive categories of achievement is a mistake.  And the school delivers.  Its state test scores currently match the best G&T schools in the borough.  By seventh grade, all students take accelerated math.  In 8th grade, 80% of all students take Regents classes, and of those, 100% pass the courses and the exams.  The school is particularly famous for its music and arts programs, yet it has equally great science and math programs (as the Regents results prove).  It has a competitive robotics and engineering team and a cool environmental science Green Team club.  The school looks for ways to involve students in its decisions, and to help them grow and mature.  There is an outstanding student organization that helps lead the school.  Students designed, engineered, and budgeted the new state-of-the-art outdoor play space.  Parent involvement is always welcomed.  Teachers are encouraged to keep growing professionally---many have advanced degrees.  Yet the students are always the focus.  We have been struck by how much of their free time teachers volunteer to the school--that's how much they care.  Every student has their own unique gifts, and students who are smart in one way learn from others who are smart in different ways.  It's an approach with dramatic results, which is why LAMS is called a "model school" and ranks in the Top 4% in New York State in terms of performance.  A large percentage of graduates go on to specialized and select high schools, and many come back to visit as alums, even many years later.  This is, in short, a place with high expectations, rigorous academics, and top-rate outcomes.  What a school!

About the percentage of students taking regents classes, its actually less than 50% per floor of 3 floors, this is because of limited spots so we take a test to see if we get in or not, but you are correct on the fact that 100% of the students pass.

I am the parent of a 6th grader.  I have found this school to be fantastic with supporting social and emotional development, which can be so dicey at middle school age.  The vast majority of the teachers are very good at what they do.  There is also a stronger music/arts program than at most non-specialized middle schools.  The only factor some families might perceive as a negative is that it is not an intense, highly competitive academic environment.  I do not, however, see this as negative.  Rather, the focus is on building organizational skills, interpersonal skills, and other skills that will allow for success at more rigorous academics down the line.

Entry to LAMS for middle school is in 6th grade, and is by lottery, for student living in Queens only.  I am not aware that there are seats that open up for 7th graders, as there is high demand for LAMS seats, and few students leave.  If there were any seats for 7th grade, you would have had to have applied in 6th grade; again, there is a lottery, and it is only for students living in Queens at the time of their application.  Lastly, there is no way to switch to LAMS in the middle of the school year.

This was an amazing school but to be honest if you're not in an honors class you won't get anywhere. You'll be mixed with the wrong people and you won't be pushed as much as honor students. If you're planning on going to this school try your hardest to be put in an honors class, because other than that you won't get any opportunities. The teachers are amazing and they're always there for you. They're cool and friendly, and although they get aggravated once in a while, they leave their judgement at home the next day. Ms. Terry is nice but she is like a barbie doll, sweet-talking and loving on the outside, but complete terror on the inside. She treats the teachers as dogs and only cares about grades than the students. The school is way too overcrowded but there is nothing to do about that, however, changing classes only takes about a minute so you don't face the crowd too often in a day. The classes are overcrowded but you'll probably be stuck with the same people for the next three years, they become your family and your best friends, so it doesn't become an issue. The homework isn't that bad, but sometimes it is. The teachers sometimes give all the homework on the same day so you'll have to manage a test, a essay, another essay, and a math packet. The uniform is terrible, but you can get around it because of the schools student government who gives students opportunities to not wear it, because everyone hates the uniform. The after-school clubs are an amazing addition to the school, there are many options to choose to from, it's neverending. However, science is a subject in this school that is way too undermined, there are science rooms but they are not used for what they are meant to be used for. The principal puts way more emphasis on the ELA state exams and Math state exams instead of focusing on other subjects. Chorus, band, guitar, and photography are the four talents offered in this school which is amazing. I am a bit biased because I was in choir for the three years in this school, so I'd like to say that it's the best talent and has the best teacher. You'll learn a lot and be challenged, but like I said, if you're not in honors, you're not going to be very specials. Try your best to earn the highest grades and don't slack off because that will not come in handy, because whatever habits and friends you make in this school will define you. Civics is the biggest thing in this school, it is incorporated in all our classes, although it is annoying and tiring, it's alright because even though they try to make it seem enforced it is not. The school doesn't have bullies, but don't get me wrong when I say the upperclassmen won't make fun of you but not to your face. The school has a nice vibey feel to it, it's pretty laid out once you get over the "I'm new" phase. I had the time of my life in this school but to be honest I wasn't upset when I left it, I was relieved, even though I did cry because I wouldn't see my friends again. 

Good luck in this school, it truly is amazing if you don't look at the downsides. Chose the right friends and make the right choices.
