Robin Thomas, parent of student Katie, praises the school. "Ms. Mattera, the new principal, is extremely enthusiatic and the children love her!" she writes. "She motivates them to learn without making them feel like it is a chore. She is extremely accessible to the parents and always willing to assist. Ms. Mattera has boosted school spirit and encouraged a competitive reading program. The children can't seem to get enough of reading in order to win the competition. This year is the first year my daughter has chosen to read instead of watch TV! Her teacher, Mrs. Lasardo, makes every lesson fun but extremely thorough."

"I couldn't be happier with my daughters' academic and social skills and with Principal Mattera and the staff," writes a father who complains that Insideschools' profile of PS 11 "failed to mention many of the positive things that this school offers." He writes: "Ms. Mattera is very enthusiastic and hands on. She knows each child by name and their parents. I have seen her at the school at special events, PTA meetings, plays, workshops, and open houses. She is sometimes at the school at these events until 10 p.m. She and her staff are extremely dedicated to all of the students. She is at the front entrance each morning in rain or shine and at dismissal as well. Mr. O'Keefe, the head custodian, and his staff keep the school immaculate. My daughters have lunch in the school and prefer school lunch over home lunch. My children are learning many new skills and I believe are becoming more well-rounded individuals due to this school."

A parent writes that PS 11 "has gone through alot of changes and is constantly bettering the school for all our children." She adds, " They have terrific teachers who work with the students who need extra help" and says the staff has a great rapport with the parents.
PS 13 Principal Paul Martuccio will receive the Patrick F. Daly Award for outstanding educators on Staten Island, the State Island Advance Reports.
PS 13 parents want the school to expand to 8th grade. Read more here.

PS 13 is a warm and nurturing place. The principal routinely tells students at public assemblies that the children are loved by the staff and parents. The arts are thriving, and I love that there is PE twice a week. All the staff and the afterschool people know the students' names. 

The school went to uniforms just as my daughter entered it, and I can't believe how much I love that! No fights in the morning about clothes! 
And you save so much money on clothes! 

My child has some learning and behavioral problems, so she is in the CTT class. Teachers and staff work with her as a team in a coordinated way and we have seen incredible results. She is doing so well I have to pinch myself sometimes. 

The homework requirements are manageable and age-appropriate, unlike at a previous school my child attended in Brooklyn, where teachers would throw15 worksheet pages at my child in kindergarten. The school is rigorous enough, but they rightly get the students to do most of work in school. The homework reinforces the work done in school, rather than asking students to learn new concepts at home, which is what appeared to be happening in the previous school my child attended. 

PS 13 could do a lot more to get parents involved and make the school a community hub. For example, my older daughter attended one of the top elementary schools in Brooklyn. Once a month, on a Friday morning, parents are invited into their children's classrooms for an hour as part of "Parents as Learning Partners." (Obviously, grandparents or other guardians can go instead of parents.)  Parents would then either make art with the children, or read and write comments on the children's stories, or read with the children, or play math games, depending on the theme or curricular objective that the teachers decided on. It was a great way for parents to see what was going on in the classrooms, meet other parents, learn about the curriculum, and feel invested in the school. The PTA also then had more access to the parents as they came in and out and could sell T-shirts, post announcements, etc. It was a real win-win. Sometimes they even served coffee in the lobby, and parents stood around for a few minutes and chatted before going off to work or wherever. 

Also, in all the schools both of my children have been in before this one, there was a class list every year. People could opt out if they did not want to be on this list. With the class list, people could easily make playdates, invite friends to birthday parties, and take up a collection for gifts for teachers at the end of the year. For reasons I simply cannot understand, this practice is prohibited in PS 13. For equally unfathomable reasons, there is no class parent. In the other schools I am familiar with, the volunteer class parent really helped the teachers by sending out reminders, recruiting volunteer chaperones for class trips, and connecting parents to PTA activities. 

We moved here nearly 2 years ago, and because of these restrictions, I barely know any parents at the school and my child, who is sociable and well-liked, has zero playdates. It is just impossible for me to arrange them because I work in Manhattan and have no way to meet the families of my daughter's friends. I can't get their contact information because the school won't allow class lists.

The strangest thing was during our first year when I tried to invite the entire class to my daughter's birthday party so that she could make friends in her new neighborhood. First, I tried to get a class list but was told that was not allowed, so I sent invitations to the class. The invitations were confiscated, and I was told that you are not allowed to give out invitations because children might be left out. I pointed out that I had invited the entire class, so no one would be left out. I was then told that for religious reasons, some children might not be allowed to attend birthday parties and might feel left out. I was able, with great difficulty, and leaving work early, to get invitations to a few kids after school. The party turned out ok, though some of her friends were not there because I couldn't find them to invite them. 

But that's not the strange part. The strange part is that later that month, the whole school celebrated Halloween - costumes and all, which is not allowed in many schools for - you got it - religious reasons. Some children are not allowed to celebrate Halloween and surely must feel left out when the whole school celebrates it!

Those little gripes aside, we love our school. They are doing great work there. My daughter is very happy there. As she gets older she will be able to participate more in making playdates by asking other children for phone numbers, and the obstacles to social interaction mentioned above will lessen.

A parent praises the "incredibly diverse" population at PS 13 and tells Insideschools that it is a "warm, nurturing place. The whole staff just loves the kids. It's a uniform school and the school does a good job of instilling values, teaching moral characters and values in a really sweet way." Students get PE twice a week. On the downside, parent involvement could be better, she said and the PTA is "struggling."
PS 13 receives a school salad bar and celebrates healthy eating: Five more Staten Island schools get salad bars.
At PS 13, 12 kindergartners were suspended in the 2010-11 school year, one of the highest rates in the city. Read more: Little horrors: City kindergarteners being suspended for misbehaving.
I'm wondering how the school environment has changed since Mr. Martuccio has taken the helm. The Inside Schools report is 5 years old, and so was written two principals ago.

I believe an update is necessary at this time, since this review was done when the old principal was still at the school. The new principal and her assistant principal have changed the environment of the school considerably. The students often comment on how "scary" they both are. Intimidation towards students as well as teachers seems to be the way they handle situations. Of course, as a staff memeber, I'm not prepared to put my job on the line and challenge them publicly (I've witnessed a few teachers being driven from the school), but I'm not alone in my wish for more support, positivity, and respect and less intimidation. At least for the kids...

One teacher, who asked not to be named, says the school administration stressed test prep and readiness over a more holistic, integrated educational approach. Many of her students' parents do not attend parent-teacher conferences and participate minimally in school workshops and activities, unlike years past, when the school still ranked classes by ability and she had top-level students. Parents then were much more involved, this teacher says, sometimes to the point of intrusion.
NYC DOE found no health violations in PS 16's school cafeteria after the school appeared in a state legislature report citing health violations in schools State Island Live reports.
As more schools embrace technology in the classroom, PS 16 has plans to begin a BYOD (bring your own device) program in fall 2015. Read more here.

Plans to move a new elementary school into the PS 16 building were approved by the city's Panel for Education Policy despite the objections of parents and community members. The plan is to open the new school, PS 10, in the fall and to reduce enrollment at PS 16. Read more here.

The Staten Island Advance reports that the DOE has plans to add a new school to PS 16's building, which would make the building the site of one of the borough's first school co-locations. The DOE is expected to make its plans public by the beginning of the 2013 school year. Read more here.
Parent volunteer Maria Sanchez says her 8-year-old son loves to read. "I say to him, 'Daniel! You've read three books! It's 10 o'clock at night,' and he begs, 'Mommy, one more book!'"
"We all work for the classroom teacher--the specialists, the learning experts," says Gallassio, adding: "we all assist and support her."

"My daughter transferred to this school in 4th grade from a private school," writes Jonathan Bricklin, a parent. "She is delighted with the diversity of programs, opportunities, and people. She loves her teachers, too. For me, her school feels more like a University than a grammar school. I am particularly impressed with its commitment to the arts and its auditorium and library."

"My son came to PS 16 last September having left a small private parochial school, which did not challenge him adequately. He is happily working with his group of 20 or so top performing kids, of all races and backgrounds, in Mrs. Conlin's 3rd grade," a parent writes. "... He feels most comfortable in math and reading, so we are pleased with the terrific arts and music programs he has been enjoying, rather than avoiding." She adds, "We would love to see growth in the sports and gym program, which is currently understaffed, and to see the parent commitment equal the staff as it deals with broader issues of lower income schools and preparing the kids to succeed."

The family of a PS 18 student who went into anaphylactic shock at school, is suing, saying she was fed a snack with peanut butter despite having a severe peanut allergy, which was known to staff, the Staten Island Advance reports.

The fountain was one of five taken out of service after showing elevated lead levels in April DOE tests. All five fountains were replaced, but none were retested afterwards according to DOE protocol.
PS 19 was featured in a Spotlight on Schools article in Staten Island Live. The school was noted for its dual-language program, one of the first and most successful programs of its kind in the city.

PS 19s dual language program is a farce. My son spent three years in the program, and he was  bullied for being a native English speaker and being an American citizen. My complaints fell on deaf ears. They dismissed it as horseplay and I had to take my son out of the program just to keep him from coming home injured every day. Bullying is a problem in the school, and no one does anything about it. Racism is alive and well, but because my son is white, they wouldn't view it as racism. I would not recommend this to anybody, and if I could put him somewhere else, I would. The dual language program is not dual language at all. PS 22 has a 5th grade chorus which has performed for Beyonce, Lady Gaga, and President Obama and was honored with a Webby Award for its online contribution to music in 2010. According to the August 2010 issue of Time Out New York Kids, the chorus' YouTube videos have been viewed more than 19 million times. The chorus has been led for 12 years by music teacher, Gregg Breinberg, known as "Mr B" .

According to the city Quality Review Report, "The principal has been in her position for 15 years and provides excellent leadership and management for this very popular school, which is undergoing major restructuring to accommodate increasing numbers."

"Your short visit to PS 22 is just a taste of the wonderful things that are happening there," writes a grandmother who has six grandchildren, one a graduate of PS22 and five attending this year. "Teachers that are dedicated and loving is only a small part of what make the children "want to go" every morning. This is a working relationship between educators and children that is rewarding to all. There is a bond between them that will last. People who truly care and want the children to succeed. They have incorporated learning, discipline and respect for each other as a way of life in PS 22. Ms. Costantino and her staff should be proud, because they do make a difference."

Of the 550 families at PS 23, parent coordinator Lori Klemas says, "I know at least 400 -- by name."

"I love this school, and I love the kids," says Linda Ferrera, a twice-a-week reading volunteer and mother of a high-school student. "Everything you do is appreciated."
An I.S. 24 teacher claims to have been attacked by a student and is suing the city, Staten Island live reports.
A 7th-grader with autism who used the Heimlich maneuver to save the life of a fellow student at IS 24 has become the first winner of the Advance's Inspirational Islander Contest. Read more here.

Ps 26 is a wonderful school with an amazing staff. The principal implemented the Leader in Me Program which helps develop children's character and build confidence. “As part of the new District 31 Middle School Scholars Program, Egbert, Prall, Dreyfus and Paulo intermediate schools will offer classes to higher achieving students. To get in, students would have to score a level 4 on their fourth grade English Language Arts and Math exams.”

"The new principal is doing a good job," a mother tells Insideschools. "The staff likes her, the students like her and there has been a lot of staff development." There has been "a big push for attendance" at the school, this mother says. She also reports that the local assemblyman has "agreed to put in a new library."

"The test scores have improved and they have expanded the school into three academies as of the 2004-2005 school year, which has been very successful," writes Kimberly Dross. "It has been a big drawing point for students outside the zoned school/feeder school areas. There are qualified, dedicated and caring staff members who truly care about the students. There is much more positive going on in the school and moral is higher than ever."

Despite community upset when Eagle Academy first proposed co-locating with IS 49, the two schools are getting along well, sharing facilities and staff, principals reported to Chancellor Carmen Fariña. Read more here.
PS 29 was evacuated Wednesday due to elevated carbon monoxide levels. Students returned to school following the hour-long evacuation SIlive.com reports.
Retired PS 29 Principal Augusta Mitchell, who provided strong leadership in the aftermath of 9/11, has died, Staten Island Live reports.

U-turns are now prohibited in school zones statewide, according to an announcement made by Assemblyman Michael Cusick outside of PS 29. PS 29 is located on the busy corner of Victory Boulevard and Slosson Avenue and surrounding traffic can be hectic, a paraprofessional at the school said. Read more: U-turns now banned in all Staten Island school zones.

In order to make room for more zoned students at PS 29, the DOE is closing the school's gifted and talented program. The program will not accept an incoming kindergarten class in the fall, but students already in the program will be able to continue. Read more here.

According to the city Department of Education Quality Review Report, "The school has recently undergone some refurbishment, further enhancing a quality learning setting which serves a diverse and supportive community."

PS 30 received a $2,000 Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America (PhRMA) STEM Talent Pipeline grant to support science, technology, engineering, and math programs at the school, State Island Live reports.

Love my old elementary school. Went to PS 30 in the 60's. Great school!! Love the little park nearby with the bandstand. According to the city Quality Review Report, "The newly appointed principal has been very effective in sustaining the smooth running of the school as she transferred from her previous position as assistant principal in November of last year."

After Principal Robert Turetsky retired in October 2006, Pat Baxter, a veteran teacher at the school, served as interim acting principal from October to February. At that time, according to a Feb. 16, 2007 article in the Staten Island Advance, Denise Spina, an assistant principal at PS 170 in Brooklyn, was to be named principal. A group of parents and teachers at the school protested the appointment, according to the Advance. Although the group is "not questioning Ms. Spina's qualifications," the article states, parents and teachers contend that their "voices were not clearly heard in the process." Parents "will fight for a postponement of Ms. Spina's assignment -- scheduled for Feb. 26 -- until they can get an explanation of what lay behind the decision," the article noted.

The Staten Island Advance February 16, 2007 article, "Principal's appointment at PS 30 opposed," quoted parent Jeanne McManus, a member of the school's PTA that she believe Denise Spina "was handpicked and there was some sort of political agenda" on the part of the Department of Education. "We feel like what Mrs. Baxter has implemented in the last four months is the direction we want to go."
Parent involvement is strong. More than 100 parents regularly attend PTA meetings, according to a parent at the school.

Asked to articulate his goals for the next few years, Principal Turetsky said he wanted to maintain the school's high standards for instruction and achievement. "We're not reinventing the wheel here," he said, "We just don't want to get too comfortable with our success."
PS 31 tied with PS 44 for lowest scoring Staten Island elementary school in mathematics, and second - lowest performing in reading, the State Island Advance reports.

"There is a cohesiveness. We get together and we share. I've been in schools where they throw you to the wolves," a teacher said, "and that's not this school."

Chancellor Carmen Fariña announced 73 schools selected to join the Learning Partners Program, an innovative and collaborative initiative that brings schools together to share practices to improve learning in the classroom and raise student outcomes. Through the program, one host school with strong practices in a particular focus area will support two partner schools seeking to strengthen their own practices in that area. I.S. 34 Tottenville was chosen to host I.S. 75 Frank D. Paulo and P.S. M94. Read more here.

Principal Boyle tells DNAinfo how he has worked to incorporate technology into the school environment at IS 34. Students submit assignments via Dropbox and are allowed to bring their own devices to class. Read more here.

"I had an extremely negative experience at P.S. 41. Unfortunately for the school, its principal is elusive, menacing, and patronizing, and seems to enjoy her power a tad much. The children never seem to be put first, even in dealing with security issues. Some teachers, apparently following the principal's lead, are extremely narrow-minded, very limited in their views about human diversity (while the school claims to be proud of its multiculturalism), and seem not to have the slightest idea of what the word "nurturing" means. I must completely agree. I also experienced a very negative experience with this principal. Her demeanor towards every one is very belittling. I wish I would have read this statement so much earlier. It would have saved me so much heartache and pain for my child.
Principal Kathleen Corriero says that the teachers' contract, ratified in late 2005, means no more weekly teacher training, "which we truly miss."

Assistant Principal Donna Nilsen says parents "come in droves" for a monthly "family night" and evening events like school ice-skating parties and bingo. Daytime support is harder to come by, as most parents work, and relatively few attend PTA meetings.
Website SILive reports on the memories and culture Principal, Brian Sharkey, is striving to build at PS 42.
Did you know former first lady of NYC Donna Hanover visited PS 42 in the 1990s? The Staten Island advance included a photo from her 1997 visit in a catalogue of Staten Island schools in the 1990s.
Tests of water samples in the drinking fountains at PS 42 showed elevated levels of lead, the New York Times reports.

"I am currently a student of PS 42," writes Joanna, a student. "Everyday, I look forward to seeing my friends and learning in school. PS 44's Family English Initiative program teaches English to Kindergarten through 2nd grade students alongside their family members in a joint classroom setting, the Morning Bell reports.
PS 44 ranked lowest performing Staten Island elementary school in reading, the Staten Island Advance reports.
The dual language program begins in pre-kindergarten, as of September 2015.
PS 44 receives a school salad bar and celebrates healthy eating: Five more Staten Island schools get salad bars.
For the 2006-07 school year, PS 44 is newly identified by the State Education Department as "in need of improvement."

PS 44's annex, housing the 4th and 5th grades, is a "remarkable little school" and a good example of how education problems can be surmounted "with the right leadership and determination," a recent visitor and adjunct professor wrote to the Staten Island Advance. Assistant Principal Robert Palumbo and all staff members -- teachers, security guards, and custodians -- have created a place where "safety, respect, learning, and, yes, even fun"  prevail. The writer says she has seen Palumbo in action in the lunchroom "not yelling for silence as is very common," but leading entertaining learning games, conducting a choral group he founded, and supervising sports activities he launched as a reward for those whose behavior and school work merit it. "This is education as it should be and can be," she says.
What do PS 45 students do to celebrate 100 days of school? In 1999, 6 and 7-year-old students created artwork pictured in the Staten Island Advance.

Good school if you like to see used condoms in the school yard, nasty graphiti, shirtless babies waiting around the Nurses office.  The demographis of this area has changed over time and now its a solid 3rd world school with 3rd world problems.

This informaton needs to be updated!  This school has gone from a fairly decent place where teachers were happy and children enjoyed coming to a school in desperate need of "Beyond Scared Straight."  The students run that school now - and not the intelligent, well behaved students either - that would be an improvement over what goes on there now.  My children were in classrooms where the teachers were so overburdened with behavioral problem students that I wonder how they managed to get any work done with the students. I saw firsthand during Parent Mornings (both for math and reading) how disrespectful and aggressive students can be.  My child would tell me  that if a student was disruptive they would get pulled out and would go to the counselor's office where they were seen playing on an iPad.  Really?  It saddens me as to what this school has become.
 
On a positive note- the teachers work very hard.  I appreciated the efforts of the teachers who always went above and beyond.  The Parent Math Mornings were extremely helpful and Ms. Pannunzio was always very helpful and worked to ensure that the parents understood that horrendous math program.  She provided parents with handouts and websites that offered additional support.  Ms. Vaccaro was also very helpful in understanding the purpose of the daily read aloud.  In my opinion it is because of teachers like them that this school is still functioning. 

Bottom line - this school has great teachers and if it weren't for the pervasive discipline problems this school would be phenomenal.

PS 46 will be getting "Community School" status when the 2017-2018 school year begins, SI Live reports.

The sudden death of one of the school's most beloved teachers, Martha Colella, just before spring break 2004, stunned the community -- and bound it together, too. School leaders brought in counselors to support kids and teachers. "Everyone came in on Friday morning," the day after she died, says Principal Eric Nezowitz. "Everyone showed up, to be here for each other." The street outside the school building will be renamed in her honor, and her former classroom will carry a plaque of dedication, in recognition of her contribution and service.

PS 48 is one of many Staten Island schools with overcrowded classes, says a report by Class Size Matters.

PS 48 William C. Wilcox has been selected to showcase elementary school social studies in the inaugural year of Chancellor Carmen Fariña’s Showcase Schools Program. The initiative is designed to promote collaboration and sharing of strong practices. Schools that excel in a specific learning focus area will host educators from other schools to share their successful structures and strategies. Read more here.

This week PS 48 held the official opening ceremony for its new $53 million four-story building. Read more here.

Students at PS 48 started the school year in a new building, and Chancellor Dennis Walcott stopped by on the first day of school to tour the new facilities, which feature 32 classrooms, a science demo room, a classroom for music and art, a theater and dance studio, and a fourth-floor library. Read more here.
Art  by PS 48 students is on view at the Guggenhiem Museum in the annual exhibition of the Learning Through The Arts program. http://broadwayworld.com/artic...

Chancellor Walcott released a congratulatory statement for the New York City schools that were named “BLUE RIBBON SCHOOLS” by the US Department of Education: “Today, Secretary of Education Arne Duncan named P.S. 172 Beacon School of Excellence in Brooklyn, P.S. 48 William G. Wilcox in Staten Island, P.S. 130, P.S. 159 and P.S. 173 Fresh Meadows, all in Queens, as 2011 Blue Ribbon Schools because of their students’ academic achievements last year. I want to congratulate the students, teachers, principals and parents at these five schools for all of their hard work and dedication in ensuring their students are making strong academic progress and are on track to graduate college or career ready.”

Principal Jacqueline Mammolito received a 2009 Cahn fellowship, a 15-month program at Teachers College designed to recognize outstanding principals. Cahn fellows attend workshops at Teachers College and mentor an aspiring principal while continuing to serve as principal at their school.

Principal Jacqueline Mammolito writes that "PS 48 continues to excel in all areas!" PS 48 was chosen to be both a Collaborative Community Practice School and a partner school to Teacher's College Columbia University Reading and Writing Project, which gives teachers professional development in the area of Writer's Workshop. The school was also invited to participate in Reader's Workshop in the 2006-2007 school year.

"The Arts are flourishing at PS 48," writes Mammolito. A partnership with Learning through Art (Guggenheim Museum) "supports visual arts, literacy and social studies." Third graders learn to play the recorder, fourth and fifth graders receive instrumental music instruction twice a week, and fifth graders take ballroom dancing. "The upcoming 2006-2007 will include reader's theatre for second grade and dance instruction for kindergarten and first grade students," she writes. "PS 48 is committed to an Early Childhood Program that supports the emotional, social and academic needs of students. Physical education and authentic "center time" is incorporated into our daily program." Lastly, "parents continue to play an active role in our PS 48 Family. Parent Coordinator Terry Guthrie and our PTA actively engage parents in all aspects of school life."
I.S. 49 will be getting "Community School" status when the 2017-2018 school year begins, SI Live reports.
I.S. 49 is one of two NYC schools on the state's list of "persistently dangerous" schools for the 2017-18 school year, SI Live reports.
I.S. 49 teacher Francesco Portelos is under investigation for improper behavior, as he has been accused of being a troublemaker and defying orders from his superior, as SI Live reports.
A student who lost vision in one eye after being hit by a volleyball in gym class is suing for $20 million. Read more here.
IS 49 principal Linda Hill is under investigation for procurement violations as well as for falsely claiming overtime payments. Read more "here.

IS 49 principal Linda Hill has admitted to falsely claiming overtime payments but has not been fined or disciplined for doing so. The teacher who raised the alarm, Francesco Portelos, claims he was punished for whistleblowing and is suing the Department of Education. Read more here.
Teachers at IS 49 and other city schools explore how to make the best use of 80-minute Monday professional development sessions mandated by the new UFT contract. Read more here.

Despite community upset when Eagle Academy for Young Men Staten Island first considered co-locating with IS 49, the two schools are now sharing staff and facilities and getting along well, principals reported to Chancellor Carmen Fariña. Read more here.

Plans to move a new school into the IS 49 building were approved by the city's Panel for Education Policy despite the objections of parents and community members. The plan would open the Eagle Academy for Young Men on the second floor of the building in the fall of 2014. Read more here.

The Department of Education is moving to dismiss a science and technology teacher at IS 49 for his inappropriate behavior that Chancellor Wolcott says "breeds mistrust and undermines the stability of schools." Read more here.

The Staten Island Advance reports that the DOE has plans to add a high school to IS 49's building, which would make the building the site of one of the borough's first school co-locations. The DOE is expected to make its plans public by the beginning of the 2013 school year. Read more here.

Parents express concerns about the PCBs that leaked from light ballasts in two classrooms and held a morning rally on Jan. 18 to "demand that the New York City Department of Education (DOE) test the air in the classrooms that recently experienced PCB light ruptures, and immediately replace of all 629 PCB lights in their school," according to a press release. Former Chicago Bears Defensive End Adewale Ogunleye donated 325 turkeys at PS 57, where he attended elementary school, the Chicago Tribune reports.
PS 57 will be getting "Community School" status when the 2017-2018 school year begins, SI Live reports.
Chancellor Carmen Fariña visited PS 57 to see a multi-sensory reading program for children with special needs at the school, reports Staten Island Live.

Chris Allen, a special education teacher at P.S. 57 is spending his summer days brushing up on the latest technology tools for the classroom. Allen said he thought interactive media lessons could help his students access more complex material. Read more here.

PS 57 received a $3,000 grant from the American Forest Foundation to help fund its Junior Farmer Green Team. The grant will fund a student trip to a farm in Vermont and a gardening project in which students plan and grow their own vegetable garden in a park near the school. Read more here.

PS 57 brought back its science fair in 2003, and science cluster teacher Renata Kozyra says the "huge response" was a big surprise. Even if family funds were short for tri-fold boards and presentation materials, kids "did their projects in shoeboxes" and were eager to show and share their work.

"Parent involvement is a paramount need," says Assistant Principal Sandra Barnes. The school's PTA is very small; the lack of critical mass makes it hard to build momentum.

Staten Island Live reports that the Department of Education's Academics, Career, and Essential Skills (ACES) program will expand to give intellectually disabled students in Staten Island the option of going to school in their own borough. PS 58 Space Shuttle School will be the first to offer ACES in the upcoming school year.

As a parent, I'd like to state that this is a wonderful notion, though I'd like to point out that it's unfortunate that there is little to no information available about the school and its program(s) on its official web page. The DOE literally links a Facebook page with an empty "website" tab (unacceptable). Perhaps some of the most important information that should be made available to parents are its staff/administration and academic data. There's no staff listed for the school (it links to a blank page titled "Test section"). In the least, the principal and/or AP should be listed. Even if they are not the individuals who responds directly, they can at least forward an email to the appropriate administrative professional.

"The entire staff holds each student to high standards to drive them to the utmost in academic excellence. I am always welcomed and feel involved in every event. Mrs. Mezzacappa, continue to drive us and push the limits on what our children are capable of to make them educated adults who will one day run this country!"

Principal Joseph Santello writes: All students K-5 receive art instruction. The school also has an art enrichment program for advanced art students. Science is also provided to all students. Two science teachers are on staff. One serves students in grades K-2 while the other provides instruction to grades 3-5. Kinderarten students and grade 1 receives instruction from a music teacher in violin and cello, grades 2-3 in recorder, and there is a 4th/5th grade band.We also have a K-2 dance troupe and a competitive dance troupe for grades 3-5.
"It's a beautiful school, with good teachers and a great principal to look up to," writes student Adam. "It actually makes learning fun for us."

"Everyone here was hand-picked to be part of the staff," says the school's guidance counselor. "It's a highly motivated group of people trying to achieve excellence."

Unlike many schools, where families are required to stock arts and arts closets, "all the supplies come from the school," according to the fulltime art teacher. "Asking a child to bring supplies in would be like asking kids to bring in a math book."
"Beautiful school, WONDERFUL Principal who has surrounded himself with a fabulous staff," writes Jennifer DiStefano, a parent.

SI Live highlights the work that PS 59 had done "incorporating maritime-themed curriculum into its daily teachings by focusing on the impact of the New York Harbor and the Billion Oyster Project -- which works to restore 1 billion live oysters in the harbor over the next two decades -- across all grades from pre-K to fifth grade....Going beyond classroom instruction, students go on 10 to 15 field trips each school year. They visit Lighthouse Point in St. George to view their own oyster cages and collect scientific data on water quality, oyster growth and biodiversity."
On the first day of school Chancellor Carmen Fariña visited PS 59 and talked about how school diversity comes in many forms. Read more here.

My son attends kindergarten at Harbor View. We are zoned for an excellent public school, but we were excited about Harbor View's promise of a hands-on education (the other school takes a traditional approach) so we applied for the lottery. It's been only a month since school started, but so far we're thrilled. The at-home assignments encourage critical thinking and creativity, unlike traditional homework that requires students to trace letters and perform other rote activities. My son comes home every day excited about the computer center, construction room, sand table, and more. He also takes music lessons in the school's beautiful auditorium and visual arts class in the art studio. The entire school staff is energized and involved. No class trips yet, but we're told there will be plenty of them. Now I'm just hoping the rest of the year continues to go this well!
It's been four years. Are you still happy?

I am a fifth grade parent, I have had children in this school since 2001and it is going down hill fast.  The chairs and desks have been changed at least six (6) or seven (7) times, they bought beanbag chairs two (2) for each class, and put couches and a tv in the entrance. But they took away computers and language and gave them assembly, that the kids love because they can sleep. They go outside when it is 30 degrees or above, but never take wind chill into consideration so it may read 30 degrees but with wind chill be 20 and they still go outside. They are not an arts school, the rainbow on the front doors can tell you that, they don't follow the ROYGBV rule, red, orange, yellow, green, blue, violet. Some teachers care about the students others are just doing a job.  Can not wait this is my last year with this school.

PS 60 is one of several schools in Staten Island which has seen its Progress Report grades decline in recent years. Read more: A Staten Island School Blames its Problems on Location: http://www.nytimes.com/schoolbook/2012/01/25/a-staten-island-school-blames-its-problems-on-location/
A parent said, "The staff is wonderful. They're for the children first, and they run this place like clockwork."
The PTA president said: "We have more than 100 mothers on committees." She added, "I've seen many changes in my 12 years as a parent here, and they're all to the best."
A DOE notice sent home with students of IS 61 said water samples from some school faucets contained elevated lead levels, SILive.com reports.
IS 61 barred students who had not bought $10 tickets to its summer carnival from attending just weeks after a principal at another school was dismissed for similar conduct. Read more here.

IS 61 will forge a partnership with the Staten Island Museum as part of Teen Thursdays, a new after school initiative to offer middle schoolers rich learning opportunities available at local cultural institutions. Read more here.
Eight middle school students were hospitalized after they were caught drinking alcohol in a classroom at IS 61. Read more here.

Can somebody find out the full name of Sandra Robinson I just graduated from this school 2013 and she said that she would remember me but I'm tryin to add as many of my teachers as possible so does any body know her full name she is a educational assistant and if u do know her just tell her da name Andrew lujan
this school rocks and i may only be in 6th grade but i see i have many more stuff to discover at is61 from kristiana todd in class6-604
i love I.S.61 i'm nila paramathas and the 3 year sof my life was the best, i liked every teacher we had there too. And, you can learn many things, and fun things there.

Most of the magnet programs here are very strong however I must add that the acting/drama program has declined significantly - a few years ago it was one of the anchors of the school, and unfortunately now it has become the weakest magnet at the school the honors program, however, is amazing as are many of the teachers

"While there are some wonderful teachers here, there are just as many uninspired ones and even the most excellent teachers are overwhelmed with work and large class sizes," writes a parent. "For kids, the support staff is excellent and the academy program (the name having little to do with what they learn) has a sensitive staff. School communication is the worst I have seen with important notices arriving after events have already taken place. 6th graders transitioning into the school get little help navigating such a large school with numerous discipline problems. The photojournalism magnet program is fantastic with dedicated teachers and some very creative projects."

"While there are some great teachers, the school lacks communication," writes a parent. "There was not even a letter sent over the summer to tell you where to go on the first day of school. Teachers don't communicate with parents and while the support staff is kind and empathic, they are so inundated with discipline problems, they don't call back either. Since Ms Zaregga left, the theater department has gone downhill. The teacher has drama students reading out of textbooks about thrust stages. My son has completely lost interest in theater and has no interest in learning anymore."

Principal Richard Gallo responds to the comment above: "IS 61 has a 6th grade orientation each May for incoming 6th graders. Invitations to this event are sent to all of our feeder schools to distribute to all 5th grade students, along with mailed notices to accepted magnet students. At the 6th grade orientation, the entire day of a 6th grader is reviewed along with where the students are to go when entering the school building and what to expect on the first day. Parents have opportunity to meet staff and tour the entire building. The event is always well attended and we receive many compliments from our parents.

"There is an assistant principal and a dean in place in each of the three academies and the same specifically for the special education department. It is the duty of the dean to address discipline issues, which are brought to their attention by the classroom teachers. Classroom teachers are rarely burdened with this problem and most are responsive to calls and overall parental communication.

"Two months into the school year with a new drama teacher is too soon to make any judgment as to the effectiveness of a new teacher and the state of the Drama Department. Change is difficult for any person, including children. Given time, students and parents alike will acclimate to the new teacher and may very well find an overall improvement, but this does take time to develop. We continue to strive to meet all students full potential and maintain a magnet program that is in high demand."

Student Natalia writes: "I learned so much from my teacher. Being apart of the Journalism and Photo Journalism program with Mrs. Simeone and Mr. Herron as teachers were the best experience. I learned a lot."
A Staten Island mother writes that there will be a sixth-grade class for children with Asperger Syndrome (8:1:1) at IS 61 run by District 75.

Sarah, who graduated from William Morris last year and is now a freshman at Susan Wagner High School, writes: "61 was a wonderful school. I really learned a lot there. I was in the performing arts magnet program and in the high honors classes." She adds: "The productions this school put on are wonderful and I was in one all three years I went to 61. Mrs. Zeraga, the drama teacher, taught me so much about stagecraft, drama productions and stage makeup." She concludes: "The academics in this school are some of the best. Even though there are large classes you can get all the individual help you need. For any incoming 6th graders that want to do to 61 I HIGHLY RECOMMENED IT."

A prospective parent writes, "I am aware of the wonderful work that is done by the magnet program in this school and the dedication of the teachers. But your article did not address the safety concerns that many parents have about this school. " She writes that the magnet and regular program are divided along class lines, and are of much different quality. "Of you are the parent of an "average" child you will think twice before sending your child to IS 61," she writes.
Fariña is stopping by middle school classrooms at Staten Island’s Marsh Avenue School for Expeditionary Learning on the first day of school 2014. Read more Read more here.
The founder of Marsh Avenue School for Expeditionary Learning Jessica Jenkins will now head the new 6-12 West End Secondary School of Urban Studies on West 61st Street. Read more here.

My 7th grader is so excited to return to MAELS this year.  He loves it-everything from his teachers to learning expeditions to the after-school activities.  The teachers and principal are dedicated and truly love what they do.  Cannot say enough about this place.
Principal Jenkins-Milona tells DNAinfo how Marsh Expeditionary uses student “expeditions” to create a hands-on learning environment. Read more here.

On Oct. 15 busing was restored to The Marsh Avenue School for Expeditionary Learning in New Springville, the School of Civic Leadership in Graniteville and New World Preparatory Charter School in Port Richmond for those children who qualify. Read more:Victory! Yellow bus service for 7th, 8th graders restored to 3 Staten Island schools.
Two new schools in Staten Island still without yellow bus service. Follow the link to read more:NYC rejects new Staten Island demand for bus service at 2 new schools.

My son is a 6th grade student at MAELS and we could not be happier.  The teachers are dedicated, thoughtful, and inspire students.  It is a small school with caring adults.  He has made many new friends and comes home happy - and shares his new learning - every day.

My son is a 6th grade student at MAELS and we could not be happier.  The teachers are dedicated, thoughtful, and inspire students.  It is a small school with caring adults.  He has made many new friends and comes home happy - and shares his new learning - every day.

I have a child that is currently attending MAELS and he absolutely loves it and so do I.  He was lucky enough to be the only child from his elementary school to get picked this year and though he was nervous and didn't know anyone, the staff,teachers and aides have helped make his transition into middle school a much easier one.   As a parent I love the level of involvement of the principal and the openness of the school which gives parents the opportunity to experience expeditionary learning first hand.  A great choice for any child that is lucky enough to make it in!!!

My child attended MAELS for 2 years and we finally had to transfer him because he was not learning much and the pious attitude of the staff was irritating him.  They tell the kids that they are "privileged" to attend MAELS and therefore the kids have to put up with any crap the administration or teachers throw at them.  They supposedly tailor their teaching to the particular students, depending on weather the student learns verbally, visually, or tacktilly, but they still insist that all the kids do the same work and in the same way.  Not much room for individual learning styles.  The dean of the 7th grade is a total tyrant and the kids don't like him.  Nice building, but we were quite disappointed.

Amazing that the school was founded on the principle that arts be infused everyday - they do not have an art teacher! They currently have a teacher who is NOT an art teacher (last year I believe she was an aide or assistant in some way - but NOT a trained art teacher) - teaching 'art'.  There is no music teacher, no acting or singing teacher either.

We love P.S.65! Our children are so happy here. We feel that we have found an extended family here. Our children feel safe and loved on a daily basis and never feel alone. We love all of the wonderful people who make up this school and as parents we feel very secure sending our children off to school every morning. All of you help to build up their self esteem and show them that they are all special in their own way and for that we thank you. Keep up the great work!
My nieces are very happy at that school, though I wish they went outside more in winter or at least had more options for staying inside.

We are delighted with this school. Our son is in the second grade and has been very happy. The teachers and staff pull together to make sure no child falls through the cracks. They know all the families and are friendly and welcoming. The lack of a gym will be even worse as the kids get bigger. We need to think of a way to build on. otherwise, it's all good. This is the first year we have been big enough for a parent coordinator. Ms. Santaliz is doing an excellent job. She sends email blasts and newsletters and has started a parent book club. we love our school!
Kindergarten students at PS 69, New Springville, showed their kindness by creating “care bags” for the children in the pediatric unit at Staten Island University Hospital, SI Live reports.
PS 69 was given exposure in a Spotlight on Schools article in Staten Island Live, which praised the school's "student-centric" approach to education.
At PS 69 students are encouraged to take the reigns in their own education, reports the Staten Island Advance.
PS 69 is the first of 24 New York public schools to begin construction on a solar rooftop garden, part of a $28 million project funded by the city and state. Read more here.
As parents in Staten Island are calling for more autism programs at schools in the borough, the Nest Program at PS 69 is a popular option. Read more here.

"I am very happy with this school," writes a parent. "My daughter loves it! She loves her teacher, and her teacher is so dedicated and interested in my child's growth and progress. The administrative staff is polite and work hard to meet the children's goals. I had my child evaluated for a learning dissability, and I am happy to say that in a month of her getting extra help and time, she is doing a lot better with her homework. I absolutely love the availability of the social worker, or any other person I may need to contact."

Nicole Cirillo writes: " The videos which the children watch are NOT during the teacher's preps. Videos are shown during lunch when there is inclement weather prohibiting the children from playing outside. Our "preps" consist of computers, science, visual arts, performing arts, library/media. Assistant Principal Murphy would like to clarify that "minimal homework" is given out of respect and understanding of working parents - not "under-involved" parents.
"Many students have breathing issues and lung problems," says Principal Jacqueline Barbagallo.
Staten Island Live features IS 72 as a part of Borough President James Oddo's initiative to encourage nutrition and wellness.

The school is not as bad as everyone says. It might not be the best, but it will definitely help your child work on their character. This school strongly attempts to help students become leaders, with their announcements, posters, and quotes around the school. They've even tried to incorporate more clubs for students to find more interests. (arts, animals, fitness, video games, books, history etc.) The homework is not a lot, and they try to limit the amount, in order to prevent stress for students. (they have a policy for no homework on Fridays.) Teachers are not bad, but some actually DO NOTHING. It's unfortunate, because students have to miss out on a subject or left to teach THEMSELVES. Yet, there are the best teachers that you could never find. Those teachers are like gems that make this school so UNIQUE. Of course, bullying is an issue at this school. But it's an issue at every school and it can't be prevented. Most rumors aren't true or as extreme as people say. Truly, the school is not that bad.

er actually im going to this school too next year and I did the "buddy day" and actually its a great school. The principal is awesome and the kids mind their own biz. and plus the 8th graders wont talk to you or anybody else ( which means they wont bully you) and as the article said... "I wont lie it's a tough school"  but that's how any middle school would be...
Thank you
Cya next year! ;D _Claudia_

Parents of autistic students at PS 69 fear that being sent to middle school at IS 72 will be counterproductive because  there is not enough mainstreaming.  http://www.dnainfo.com/new-york/20130214/new-springville/parents-fear-kids-with-autism-will-regress-after-moving-middle-school

I moved to the island 6 years ago. My mother in law and most of my husbands family were SINY school teachers for years. My mother in law taught in Concord and I asked her opinion about elementary and middle schools priro to relocating. She looked me straight in the eye and said " THEY ALL STINK"...but if you have to choose pick IS 72. My oldest daughter now a Wagner graduate attended I.S 72 without too much drama. My son attended shortly afterwards and there were constant fights in classrooms and bullying. Most of the teachers seem too overwhelmed to care. Mr. Freidman would tighten his belt and put some order in to his students. In six years I have seen the principal three times because he is always hidng in his office. This year is pure hell. My youngest is a student and we have had bus issues ( since they took the 7-8th graders off the cheese bus now the 6 graders run rampant). There are fights in the classrooms , hallways, school yard. Bullies do as they please. Kids disrespect teachers. No one gives a damn. Pupil path is a blessings but most of the teachers NEVER answer their emails so you have to call the school/ guidance counselor to track down their progress. Oh they still have that progress report but no one on one communication. My kid is a good quiet kid. She has gotten bullied at the candy machine ( they have made their own rule about who goes first ). She has gotten pushed numerous times. I gave 72 a nice quite kid and the school atmosphere has turned her into this stressed out child whose pleas go unheard. Now I believe they are also rezoning it? I am definitely looking at other alternatives for next year. I agree with Wferrari97 , if you child is zoned for 72 MOVE THIS SUMMER. I use to rant and rave about this school. Now in my mother in laws words IT STINKS............IF POSSIBLE DO NOT SEND YOUR CHILD. The school rated 52 out of 100, more like 25 out of of 100 to me.......

This school is horrible and disgusting. You try to call the school for a problem that your child is having and you get hung up on. If your child is zoned for this school then I suggest that you have your child transferred

Having attended this school some 10 years ago, my memories of it are awful. The education that I was afforded was nothing but subpar, for the teachers were anything but experts in their fields. The school was inadquate in preparing me for the future, and I only hope that it has improved its academics as well as its bullying problems. Despite the diversity of this school, I experienced bullying on a daily basis and by the time I reached the 8th grade, I no longer wanted to attend school because of this prevelant problem. A problem staff was very mindful of yet did nothing to rectify it. This hindered my academic progress very much so.

"I attended I.S. 72 from September of 1999 until June of 2002. This school was a failure. My first year was academically challenging, as my teachers were veterans of the school. However, grades 7 & 8 were horrific. My teachers were poor and my peers were nothing but bullies."

"This school has a serious problem with bullying and I haven't seen any changes so far," writes a parent, who notes that she has observed disappointing "disengagement among the students" and "a defeatist attitude among officials."
A current student in 7th grade complains that boys and girls are separated at lunch, writing, "We aren't going to do anything bad! We all just want to talk and hang out!"

Dean Lori Veit says that there's too much emphasis on academics. "We need to offer kids more than double periods of math and reading," she says. "They need other ways to express themselves, other ways to excel," like sports, music, and the arts.

One 8th grade girl complains that there were lots of boy-girl feuds in the school and that "the teachers can't control the classes."

PS 74 Future Leaders Elementary is one of 27 New York City schools on the 2015-2016 list of schools considered to be "persistently dangerous" by the state Department of Education, based on the number of disruptive or violent incidents. Read more here.

please do not send your kid to this school. it was the worst decision I ever made I decided to send my three children here my daughter has been bullied for the whole entire year in the school has done nothing that has landed on deaf ears so I had no other option and had to file police report against this child and her family and the school treats the bully s as the best kids in the world and the kids get picked on all the ones that suffer.it doesn't material how good ur child is the side with the bully.the office is a joke and so is the counselor tells you to feel bad for the bully cuz they don't have a good family back round or support like your child . They can pretty much do as they please along as the apologies follower right after they do something band with no consensus. Will never send my kids back here.

This school is the worst school ever !!! Do yourself a favor and dont send your child here . The principalabf staff are a disgrace . Who dont know what theyre doing . They think bullying is nornal and okay your child isnt safe I know first hand .glad I transfered my daughter
P.S. 74 landed on the state Education Department’s list of “persistently dangerous schools in 2014. Schools on the list have a high number of violent or disruptive incidents. Read more here.

This is a terrific schoo! The kids are taught the 7 Habits of Highly Effective People. The teachers are outstanding. My son started in k in 2010 (the first year the school opened) and his teacher evaluated him in September and gave him more challenging work. The principal is dynamic. She greets the kids/parents at the door every morning and knows most, if not all, by name. The school has had family events and is fostering a great sense of community. It's a very welcoming place with a truly intellingent, progressive and committed staff. Oh, and the kids get healthy snacks and free breakfast. This is going to be the crown jewel on the North Shore!

IS 75 Frank D. Paulo Principal Kenneth Zapata plans to meet with 6th grade teacher Adria Zawatsky to discuss whether she violated DOE policy by including a vocabulary question characterizing President Trump as haughty and needing to have more humility. A parent accused her of inappropriate political speech, SI Live reports.

Chancellor Fariña announced 73 schools selected to join the Learning Partners Program, an innovative and collaborative initiative that brings schools together to share practices to improve learning in the classroom and raise student outcomes. Through the program, one host school with strong practices in a particular focus area will support two partner schools seeking to strengthen their own practices in that area. I.S. 34 Tottenville was chosen to host I.S. 75 Frank D. Paulo and P.S. M94. Read more here.

Chancellor Fariña visited IS 75 in her 70 school tour. What many of the schools have in common, Fariña said, is that something is working well. I.S. 75, for instance, was the first middle school in Staten Island to offer a popular program for autistic students, Read more here.
this write up is outdated!  New info please!

Frank D. Paulo School is one of four Staten Island schools that will begin offering advanced programs to students this September, Amy Padnani of silive.com reports:

“As part of the new District 31 Middle School Scholars Program, Egbert, Prall, Dreyfus and Paulo intermediate schools will offer classes to higher achieving students. To get in, students would have to score a level 4 on their fourth grade English Language Arts and Math exams.”

Principal Mark Cannizzaro received a 2009 Cahn fellowship, a 15-month program at Teachers College designed to recognize outstanding principals. Cahn fellows attend workshops at Teachers College and mentor an aspiring principal while continuing to serve as principal at their school.
Because of improvements in its test scores, IS 75 was removed from the state's list of schools needing improvement and is now considered "in good standing" under No Child Left Behind.

According to the city Quality Review Report, "Students and staff show considerable pride in their school and this is echoed by parents who know that the school will involve them swiftly should their children to experience any difficulties."

Frank, who graduated in 2002, writes: "The school's Practical Arts department is one of very few left in today's 'higher expectations' and new curriculum state of mind. The Practical Arts that are in place at Paulo give kids the chance to sit back and relax and use their hands and their minds together to create something that will be a memory forever. It is a shame that more of these programs are not in place in more New York City Public Schools (especially high schools)." He adds: "Mr. Laureno's woodworking shop and Mrs. Quirk's ceramic studio are memories that I will remember for years to come."
A student writes, "This school is great! The teachers are helpful and nice *(most of the time)* and my classmates are wonderful!" She reserves specific praise for her teacher Mr. Hermann.

RZA, the rapper, record producer, actor and founding member of the legendary hip-hop group Wu-Tang Clan donated 30 new iPads to PS 78 in a school assembly last week. "The donation came about after teacher Jo Ann Accardi tweeted RZA last May, asking if he could help donate new technology to her students," SI Live reports.

My son attended Petrides from K-12. He needed speech and occupational therapy through middle school to help with his lisp and motor skills.  The services were provided on campus by caring teachers, which we very much appreciated.  He blossomed in HS, was on the swim & fencing teams, National Honor Society, and newspaper.  He graduated last year and earned a full ride to CSI's Verrazano Honors nursing program. No school is perfect and with so many students on a sprawling campus, there's bound to be a few incidents.  The large parking area is a luxury and having safety officers on the grounds is another plus. Overall, I credit the opportunities and challenges offered at Petrides in helping my son become the young man he is today.

Hi All,
I am a parent looking to enroll my kid for Middle School here. Reading the comments here, I'm kind of discouraged sending my child here. All the comments are from 6 years ago. Has the situation changed? Are kids still being bullied here? Has the principal changed?

Slovakian Ambassador Michael Mlyner to the United Nations visited The Michael J. Petrides School. Staten Island Live writes that the Petrides students who were a part of the city's Junior Ambassadors Program had a chance to speak with the ambassador about how they can tackle global issues and his personal experience in becoming a UN ambassador.
A Petrides school student posed with a BB gun in a school bathroom, the Staten Island Advance reports.

I dont know how much the school has changed in 3 yrs since my daughter graduated. I know from my experience i had two incidences which one i handled with the teacher, that favoritism and not liking a kid is real and mines was not disrespectful , the other the principal at the time who was very involved took care of that. 6th graders trying to bully my 2nd grader, we not having that. Otherwise the school is a good school. It may have things that need to be fixed like pta including all not your friends
 Making everyone feel accepted and their voices heard at pta. All the kids graduated and received scholarships and they all went to great schools. Parents get involved stop complaining but dont do nothing. Get involved complaints go to doe in manhattan they will not do nothing in si. The school has a lot of programs and activities for the kids. It was great learning experience for my daughter and i had no problems with noone. Its a school that offers more than regular school. If the school is allowed to simply kick out "trouble kids", then the zoned schools have more than their fair share of problem students.

A lawsuit against the city and DOE alleges that lack of proper supervision was the cause of a third-grader at Petrides suffering head injuries after being assaulted by another child at the school, reports the Staten Island Advance.

I just attended my child's kindergarten ceremony at Petrides and was very disappointed. There was a slideshow (Ms. Moore's class) and my son was hardly in it. Another parent sitting near me voiced the same concern over her son. While we both noticed that one boy in particular was in every other frame practically. I was very surprised they would do something so insensitive and unfair. If you can't give the kids equitable screen time or close to it, then don't have a slideshow. You shouldn't play favorites with certain kids and then ignore the ones you don't like or whatever. What should I have told my kid when he asked me why he was barely in the slideshow and yet so and so is in every shot? How do the teachers miss something so obvious and basic?

My daughter is graduating this year and she fairly liked the school.  I would say she mostly complained about the Principal being inactive. It's a good school however, I think it is so over rated! This school does not function like a normal HS.
Whats a normal hs?
This school is impressive.

Parents protested the decision to move troubled students into Petrides in order to keep them on Staten Island. The argued so passionately that the chancellor backed off his plans. View the report and video of the meeting: NYC Schools Chancellor Gets An Earful Over Alternative School On Staten Island and Must-watch video: Watch the public meeting that changed plans for Petrides.
Newsweek ranked Petrides 452nd in its annual list, America's Best High Schools, a listing of the top 500 high schools in the United States.

like many other public schools the class rooms are over crowded, 30+ seems like the norm in each elementary class, they need to stop enrolling so many students so that these children have a chance to have a proper education...so much is expected from the children but its not focused on target areas which can make the process difficult for child and parent.  my child has been here since kindergarden and is now in 5th grade...in my opinion only 2 teachers she has had through these years were suitable to teach.  the school has many activities outside of school going on and that is a plus but they need to improve the academics of elementary....you can check their grade reports online I believe it is currently a C......many parents agree that petrides is not what it used to be
The academics in Petrides is outstanding; the kids get one on one with the teachers not matter what.

as a parent, i didn't feel the power of the principal. She just know to say that it's unfair to get C on their report; she didn't really think about why they get C ! Some teachers even don't like their students! all teachers and administrators and other staffs should really work together to make this school better! of course, it's not easy. since this school get students from kindergarten to high school, and each grade has 3 classes; but they mix all students together, it's harder for teachers to teach, and more harder for students to learn in the same pace. some students may feel difficult to catch up; some students may feel too easy to pay attention.
the only advice i can give you is to put  spell check on your computer!!!

As talented as your daughter sounds, she is not entitled to special admission to Petrides when there are hundreds of other equally talented children trying to get into this school as well.  If you were serious about having your daughter attend this school, you probably should have moved to Staten Island two or three years earlier to get into the lottery.
Petrides' middle school test scores "are as good or better than in the elementary school," says Principal Joanne Buckheit. "It's the opposite of what's happening in the rest of the city."

"There are a lot of opportunities here to be a worldly person," says Michael Blyth, a longtime teacher at the school. "There's an emphasis on expanding people's horizons." The student body traces roots to "14 or 15 different countries," he said.

"We know every kid in the school; we can tell you your grade and your name. There's no opportunity to fall through the cracks here," says Parent Coordinator Ellen Lanzi. "And nobody says 'no,' everyone helps each other."

"I want the kids to know there's life outside of New York and New Jersey," says college advisor Carol Dennison, who begins discussions about college in the 9th grade and invites 8th graders and their families to college fairs.
One parent writes: "I found the administration to be extremely helpful in giving me information about the lottery process."

A parent whose child has attended the school since kindergarten writes: "I would like you to know that although the campus resembles a country club, the school is all business. The classes at every grade level are challenging, the children are encouraged to achieve. The teachers and staff are incredible. They are in attendance at all PTA functions and at sports activities, etc." In response to a previous comment, she adds: "As far as the admission policy, just check out the NYC Department of Education Website, the application has been available on-line for years. The application process is handled by Central not the school."

The Staten Island Advance reported on February 13, 2004 the resignation of Principal Michael Davino, effective March 31. He accepted a job as superintendent of the Springfield, NJ school district. Davino was principal at Petrides for six years, the paper reported.
A report by Class Size Matters shows that Staten Island School of Civic Leadership is one of many Staten Island schools plagued by overcrowding. Read more here.

Staten Island School of Civic Leadership is among 40 middle schools selected for an extension of the Middle School Quality Initiative, a program that increases professional development with Common Core-aligned literacy strategies and gives targeted funding for literacy training and materials. Sponsored by the New York City Council, Robin Hood, The After School Corporation, and Harvard Ed Labs, the Middle School Quality Initiative aims to help at risk students stay on track with their academic goals, as well as accelerate students' progress towards reaching the Common Core literacy standards. With this expansion, MSQI will be in 89 schools in the city. Read the press release here.

This school was removed from the SINI list. Some of the special education students failed to attain a level 3 or 4 on the state exams.  Although, their IEP established that promotional criteria for a lot of those students was 2 or 3 grade levels from where they are assessed on the state exams.  P.S. 45 consistently receives an "A" on their NYC Progress Report.  The Principal has been recognized by the Mayor and Chancellor as one of the top 10% school leaders in the city.  Furthermore, the staff provide a well-rounded curriculum where students are exposed to theatre, modern dance, museums, and character development.  I love the 4-5!

This school is the worst experience my son with special disabilities has had to deal with. They are very unorganized no sense of censorial environment for children with special needs. They do not get the gist of a complete disability vs. behavioral issues. They lack empathy beginning from their RUDE GHETTO SPOKEN ADMINISTRATION GROUP that represents an establishment of a PUBLIC SCHOOL in NYC, they are so unapproachable, they lack simple knowledge of information that DOE has on their website.  They are a just a poor representation of  what a school office members should be.  This school lack the teachers with experience that in turn equal to poor creative teaching lessons. As a concerned parent they simply do not meet any parental goals to looking to school for help for your child.  Getting children to be excited and want to go to school is a challenge all on it own, let alone having to bring them into this environment where they are not understood, manhandled and just brushed under the rug. in hopes to be forgotten. One thing is to lack DOE funding for these special education classes but another is totally different when the funds are given and they are not spent on the need of the individual child's disability ex. in providing or even outsourcing the adequate paraprofessionals they so desperately require. This is a real SHAME. They substitute pediatric psychological therapies with an inexperienced guidance counselor because they do not have one on staff, but they service special education, how is that even possible.  Instead of helping parents achieve the adequate funding from the DOE for these children, they just take and do as they deem fit.

This just not what they promote to be..

I had Susan Silvis as a teacher years go, and she was wonderful! I agree, the teachers now are very inexperienced and have a hard time handling interruptions. However, I'm studying to become a teacher and they prepare you very well in how to cope with these interruptions. Its sad to see how years have gone by,and the quality of teachers diminish.

"In my opinion, the school's 2005 review still holds true today," writes a parent. "From my and my child's experience in this school, I can truthfully say that some of the teachers are still a little green and do not have enough experience and training to teach the earlier grades. Some struggle with finding and incorporating teaching methods usually learned from years of experience. The young faculty in this school suffers from low tolerance, impatience and cookie-cutter thinking! Again, from my experience, I feel issues of low student performance in this school could be changed as I don't necessarily think it stems from the lack of parent involvement, but from teachers' hesitance to reach out to parents who are interested in their child's education. A blanket approach and grouping of good parents of this community with the negative parents are their downfall! As a parent, I feel a more proactive approach would be helpful when there is a case where a student has behavioral and/or academic issues. Having the option and/or opportunity to work with a teacher instead of waiting for parent/teacher night to notify the parents is key to supporting and caring for a student. ... Special education and diversity training should be a requirement for those who plan to serve in an ethnic community."
Because of improvements in its test scores, PS 116 was removed from the state's list of schools needing improvement and is now considered "in good standing" under No Child Left Behind.
"This school is amazing," writes student Justin. "The teachers are great, and you will love Mrs. Silvis, the literacy coach."
"It's a wonderful school," said Susan Silvis, the school's literacy coach. "We're beginning to address children individually, rather than en mass."

The school is open to all students in the five boroughs of NYC. It is a magnet school with a STEAM focus. Dual language classes from PreK-5 are excellent. There are music programs during the school day as well as after school including partnerships with Turtle Bay Music School, Studio in A School, Teatro Sea, and LeAp. Engineering, media/technology, yoga, physical education, visual art, Hydroponics and music are school day programs offered to students. This school is a hidden gem. Don’t let test scores speak for the school. Open houses, and private school tours offered as well as monthly parent STEAM workshops opened to the community. Email for more information: : Magnet@ps123k.com 
PS 123K The Suydam  Magnet School for STEAM

I have to say that I am very proud to have attended this school my brother and I graduated in 1988. We are 1st generation Americans in our family and we are proof of what a great school it is. We both attended and graduated from college I am now a Purchasing Manager at a thermoforming company and my brother is a VP for a financial firm. We are both eloquent speakers and can attribute much of our success to the diligent and caring teaching of our teachers at PS 123. Teachers like Mrs. Simon, Mrs. Sherman-Holzer, Mrs. Greenburg, Mrs. Glass, Mrs. Burgos, Mr. Halloran, Mrs. Gleason and of course our principal Mrs. Spatlor helped create the foundation that lead us out of the "stereotypical" life expected for children attending schools in the "economic status" criticized here. I encourage other schools to take tips from the way this school teaches and many more success stories will be the outcome. The teachers at this school taught me how to overcome diversity that no one can limit my accomplishments but myself. I am thankful because out in the real world there are plenty of challenges and they are not all just based on skill. A parent writes that she is "proud" of PS 274 and believes the school "has come a long way" and has seen great improvement since a change in school leadership. "I have two children attending the school and they have improved their reading and math skills because of caring teachers," she writes. "My two children also attend the band. The "administration and the parents are in unity. When we sit down for decision-making on safety measures, we come together as a team," a PTA president said.

"The leadership has changed dramatically over the years," a longtime teacher says. "When Dr. O'Gorman came in, she brought focus and brought everyone on the same page. That's why our scores went up dramatically." This teacher said there is "a positive feeling that the kids are going to succeed."
