I went to that school when the principal was Mr. Martinez back in the early 70s and the school was beautiful. As children we learned simple values such as not entering without knocking or not taking a seat in an office unless asked to do so. The little things that today mean the world to me as a professional. I actually learned who was king tut in second grade and what it meant to respect my elders. God forbid we ran in those hallways or much less fought. my point is that it's not about how many people do the job but about who and how they do it. Learning at 274 was fun as a child. I am now 40 years old and i grew up in that neighborhood when it wasn't very clean nor safe but my teachers were my role models and most of us loved them even when we studied in the rundown annex. So keep up the good work and remember that what you do today as teachers may affect a child even 40 years from now. My principal may have died long ago but not his school or the lessons he taught us individually.

Oh wow! Not only did I go to this school, but I lived across the street from it. I remember Mr. Martinez -- Great principal! I loved the teachers. if you ever saw the movie the Substitute or Dangerous Minds and wanted to see a real life example, go to 291.

I have worked at Roland Hayes a few times this year, and I think that it is a terrible place for children. Kids are still forced to go through a metal detector before entering the school. I even saw a security guard use the "wand" on a child after she had already gone through the metal detector. Classroom doors are locked at all times. When I asked a student why the doors were locked, he answered me matter-of-factly: "In case there's a shooter." The general feeling that I get from this school is that many staff members believe that students are criminals, and they treat them as such. Adults frequently scream at children, and children are expected to "learn" under duress. The learning process is didactic and predicated on fear. To say that this is a Pipeline to Prison school would be an understatement: This is the closest thing to a juvenile prison that I have seen in New York City.

As a guy who was sent there for a few days in 2011 who has also been in other schools in district 32, I can honestly say that 291 is the most out of control middle school in the district.  Kids do what they please when they please.  This place made 296's students look like kids at Brooklyn Tech.

   This School has changed so much. There are so many programs available for the students of 291 as well as the community of Bushwick.  Our loved Principal Mr. Walsh past away  in late 2011, he will be missed. I hope they would send a new person to update this review for 291.

"Unless you are in the mood for a good laugh, there is no real need to read the review given above. For, it is outdated, outmoded and just plain outlandish. This is 2008 and our school has reached unprecedented heights. With more parent involvement and ebullient, energetic students, the atmosphere has completely changed. Under the confident, yet compassionate guidance of the principal, I.S. 291 has flourished. Want cutting-edge technology classes? We got it. Aspire to be a lawyer? Why not learn from one? Want to excel in Mathematics and Science? Check out the returning experts who are behind last year's state exam success stories. Have a flair for the arts? The school is bursting with colors, textures and styles only bright middle school students could dream up. Spanish? No problemo! English Language Arts? The poet inside you will wonder where she was hiding all these years. There's so much more, but you'd really have to VISIT to get the entire perspective. I'm a middle school teacher and I approve this message!"

"I was flabbergasted while reading the accounts of the way it was at I.S. 291 in the past and I felt an overwhelming desire to let the truth about our situation in 2008 be known. Currently, we stand as one of the most improved schools in New York City that is on a fast track to the top. Roland Hayes Intermediate School 291 boasts a superior staff of qualified teachers whose expertise in content areas and capacity to care far exceed the requirement of the New York City Department of Education. As a relatively new teacher at this school I too came in with a rather stereotypical view only to be pleasantly surprised and today I find myself proud to be a part of this institution. Under enthusiastic leadership, this school has been a resounding success with clean, beautiful, picturesque classrooms that are print-rich and have a wide variety of materials designed to facilitate enjoyable and effective teaching/learning experiences. I.S. 291 is now a well-oiled machine with systems in place and support staff that will allow us to walk confidently in the present and boldly claim the future. The school has been the site for city-wide professional development sessions and activities like the marking of the state examinations. Visitors have constantly made comments about the clean environment and the atmosphere of industry that is present within the walls of the school. I have had the distinct honor of impacting the lives of many students and this experience has been mostly positive. Over the past two years, I have grown with my students to the extent that I know that I have gotten as much out of this partnership as they have. I have been a facilitator in classrooms where students have demonstrated a maturity far beyond their years. They have shown a desire to learn and grow emotionally, socially and academically. As I put these thoughts on paper, I cannot help but think that some doubting Thomas will consider this to be just rhetoric. In order to dispel this notion, I will allow anyone with the proper authorization to visit my class, even without giving me notice. I guarantee you that the intellectual pursuits that you will witness will astound you and leave you feeling more optimistic about the future of our society."

"During the 3 years I have been in IS 291, Mr. Walsh, my principal has changed the school a lot," writes Samantha, an 8th grader. "I thank Ms. Mitchell for helping and always being there for the students. I thank my teachers because they always have been there for me during the good and bad times. I think that IS 291 is the best school I have ever been to. I have learned how to be mature and responsible."
A student writes that "teachers are real nice" and "they want you to learn."

Student Gianna writes to disagree with comments that say the school is violent. "I've been in this school for a year and I haven't seen any problems," she writes. "The teachers are really nice and they just want students to have a better education."

"This school has a wonderful Science and Robotics program that I would love to see expand," writes parent Makesha Reed. "Her reading and math scores are lower level "3" and upper level "3" respectively and I am extremely thankful for her teachers and the Principal, Dr. Nicole Ambrosio. Although this school has many issues to overcome, it is surely not the hellhole you portray it to be. The teachers and faculty care; they have called my home to report issues and I am thankful for that. If what you observed is correct, then blame the parents, not the school."

"My daughter has been at 291 for 2 years and she has never had any problems," writes parent Roxana Estevez. "When I use to attend this school it was well managed," writes Jennifer, a student who graduated in 2003. "The teachers were great and they helped the students learn what they needed to know to get into the best schools in New York."

"I read your review in amazement and had to wonder out loud whether you were actually in my school," writes Vaughan Danvers, a teacher. "Classrooms that are dingy and bare and bereft of student work? "At 291 we (the staff) have a very difficult task, especially when we are always getting a disproportionate amount of students that are on level," writes teacher Lee Woods. "Our principal has an enormous amount of energy that will raise the spirit of not only the students but the community."

"I really have a great staff, who are willing to roll up their sleeves and get ready to work," says Principal Nicole Ambrosia.

Principal Gloria Turner said: "The school has shown progress in the Teacher College's model of literacy which we use in grades 4 and 5.  Since then we've also done Reading First in grades K-3.  It's different, very structured, and seems to be working very well... We've gone up in reading last year and improved in math as well."  However, P.S. 299 became a School in Need of Improvement (SINI) in 2005, said Turner.  "We have a dedicated staff.  Everybody is working hard to get off the SINI list."

According to a June 28, 2004 press release from the NYC Department of Education, Principal Charles Harrington is one of 45 public school principals "being removed from their positions for poor performance this year." Mr. Harrington will return to a position he previously held within the department, according to the DOE.

The District 32 Community Education Council highlighted I.S. 383 and two other local schools in a letter to NYC DOE Chancellor Richard Carranza, pleading to allocate funds towards a complete and thorough lead eradication after all three schools showed higher levels of lead following remediation treatments than their initial tests in 2016, Bushwick Daily reports.

School has great academics and amazing teachers. Only problem is reaching that. You have to battle your way through 5th grade nonsense teachers and petty disengaged students in order to get into honor classes which holds teachers that are fun and actually teach you stuff and students that are engaged and helpful, but also very entertaining and funny. That is the goldilock zone of Schuyler. Only a few select teachers and a fraction of the students are like that. This school builds you up to the high school experience and so far the rigorous academics are being used quite frequently, which is a good thing; preparing you for the future. But then again, that only comes with the goldilock zone of students and teachers. Even though not so pretty on the outside, when you develop deep into the school community and reflect on what has happened over the years, Schuyler was actually a very good school. Though not being good as it used, downgrading from Brooklyn Tech having most seats taken up by Schuyler to just eight people getting into Tech now, it is still a great school and I hope that most of the 8th grade teachers, who are the best at giving rigorous yet engaging instruction with them having the most years at the school, still teach to this day and in the future. In short, great school concept, amazing staff, 5th 6th grade teachers needs work, 7th 8th grade teacher absolutely amazing, school environment is ok, students terrible, and only a fraction, (like those eight people that got into Brooklyn Tech + a few more academia focused) students are amazing. Make those students your best friends. (Trust me, they are great in every way.) If you like a challenge of a game, go here. If you are super into your work and can't deal with all of the nonsense, take your chances.

Insideschools, it is time to visit this school again.. a lot has changed including the leadership, as Ms. Saunders is no longer the principal. I am familiar with the school now because this is my daughter's first year there and she loves it! I'll say my biggest concern was the change in student body that could make or break a student's confidence. But my informal assessment of the students are that they are prideful "smartypants", hip BK or Queens natives who come from supportive and stable homes. The last open school night was RIDICULOUS there were so many parents there... I was complaining and loving it at the same time. The kids ride in groups on the buses, trains and vans and although there is some loud, obnoxious typical young teen brash talk, the kids are really harmless. 
The stats and recent grade for 383 are disappointing, but it is only with the resolve of the school, parents and most certainly the kids -- that 383 can rise back to the top. I hope that the class my daughter is in will be part of the resurgence of 383, the school deserves the recognition... the kids are great and impressive!!

Both my daughter and son were accepted to 383 last year and two years ago. I had them take the test to "see" how they would do. Ten ago, 383 had a good reputation because the former principal ran that school as a no-nonsense lady. Today, it is different. Don't be fooled by the posts on this site (good, bad or even my own)! Some of the posts are genuine (good and not so good); but some posts are clearly created by others pretending to be students when they may be school staff trying to give a better impression than what it really is. The fact is that the school accepts students based largely on test scores- period. If you really want to get a flavor of how the school really is, JUST OBSERVE THE STUDENTS AND SAFF AFTER DISMISSAL ON A MILD DAY EITHER ON WILSON AVENUE OR IN FRONT OF BURGER KING ON MYRTLE AVENUE (both around the corner from the school's main entrance). What you will see are many "gifted and talented students" (not all all but MANY students) acting contrary to how a scholar is supposed to act. 383's reputation is propped up by the exam- the students will succeed even without the teachers as in many good schools. In the end, I used my sister's address based solely on what I saw during dismissal for three days- in early October, end of April and mid-May in two different years. (in two years my little one will take the test- maybe things will change- we'll see). If you are a concerned parent, base part of your decision on what your child may experience EVERYDAY as soon as the students are dismissed. I have no doubt that there are many good staff members and students in 383, but in my opinion test scores alone do not make the daily experience of what children go through during their middle school years. Parent to parent: GO AND SEE!

My experience... My little brother is a 6th grader in this school, it's his first year. He loves it. In his old school, he excelled and at times was a little lazy because the work wasn't all that difficult even in the honors classes. That being said, now that he was moved into the honors classes at this school I can honestly say that this school does a great job of teaching their students and giving them challenging work. My brother can attest to that, though begrudgingly... He's very smart but lazy... lol 

One of the other things that really caught my attention was how nice most of these students are compared to other schools. For example, my little brother was zoned to go to 93 but as a temporary substitute last year I couldn't believe the problems that took place at that school. Little 11 year old kids waving puerto rican and dominican flags in the building screaming Latin King or Trinitario... It was ridiculous... This school has none of that. Sure, there are some knuckleheads here and there, but the difference in this school is that they are the overwhelming minority as opposed to other zoned schools around the area which are the exact opposite...

At Philippa Schuyler - IS 383 My son maintained an 85 average over the course of his 3 years there.  IS 383 is a humongous large school for gifted and talented children.  The school has predominantly black and Latino students and they have been churing out excellence for 40 years.  The teachers seemed interested in keeping our children focused on the work at hand.  Their most difficult situation is there is a lot of traffic around the busy Wilson avenue and Knickerbocker train station.  The school has little to no support for children outside the school.  Because of that, the students and/or residents of a nearby junior high school who prey on the IS 383 students.  Thee is a NYPD precinct one block away but you wouldn't know it because they have no presence among several hundred children from two schools in the area..

A student from the school is among the 20 winners of the 2007 New York Times College Scholarships, which grants each winner with up to $7,500 a year for four years of college.

Asked what he liked about the school, an 11th grader active in the student council told Insideschools, "What don't I like?" He went on to say he especially appreciated the student involvement. "The military structure gives it discipline that we need," he said, adding that he wants "to serve my country in politics."
A student said he enjoyed "the classes, the gym, and sports teams."
A school dean said he had worked in other schools but that at ACLA he "went to heaven." He went on: "This is how a school should be set up. They're very structured, but students enjoy it."
A 9th grader said the school "separates us from the environment of out in the streets, where there's a lot of trouble. Here it's safe."
"Our test scores are better than the other schools," a student said. "I like that it's small."
The principal is her daughter's "dad away from home," said a mother active in the PTA. "Academically it's excellent," she added, noting that she appreciates the teacher involvement.

"Students gain leadership experience and complete community service projects," according to information about the school reported on the New Visions for Public Schools website (http://www.newvisions.org/newcenturyhs/brooklynlist.htm), which helped found the school.
